talk.start.para: —Let me begin by expressing my strong support for the statement the Prime Minister made yesterday and by saying that it is a great source of pride to me—as the Minister for Foreign Affairs—and to the government, that Australia joined the international coalition to remove Saddam Hussein’s barbarous regime. Saddam Hussein was a brutal and evil dictator. He was a threat to his own people, he was a threat to international peace and security, and he defied the international community’s expressed demand that he disarm and comply with no fewer than 17 mandatory United Nations Security Council resolutions. His regime perpetrated some of the most egregious human rights abuses that the world has seen. Prime Minister Allawi has estimated that the total number of people missing from the Saddam Hussein era exceeds one million. Since the end of the war the coalition has received reports of some 275 mass graves, containing the remains of some 300,000 slain men, women and children. We have removed a regime that sustained its rule through rape, torture and murder. Over one million people perished as a consequence of the brutal war he launched against Iran in 1980. Some 5,000 people died during chemical weapon attacks on the Kurdish town of Halabja on 16 March 1988.

speech.para: There was of course debate in this country on whether we should or should not have participated in the war to overthrow Saddam Hussein, but there is no doubt that Iraqis have embraced their newly won human rights—such as freedom of speech and freedom of assembly and association—new political parties have emerged, women and minorities are engaged and welcomed in political life, Iraqis are conducting religious ceremonies and pilgrimages which were banned previously under Saddam’s tyranny, they have access to a flourishing media, with some 170 newspapers, satellite television stations and the internet, and they have exercised their right to elect their own government in the highly successful elections of 30 January. No-one has any illusions about how difficult it has been to get to this point, the point where we are at today on 8 March 2005. Australia has made a contribution because Australia is a significant country, a country with a network of alliances and a country which has the capacity to contribute to the resolution of these problems in a more stable international environment.

We sent troops in the initial phase to overthrow Saddam Hussein’s regime and now we are proposing to send another 450 troops in order to provide support to the Japanese and ensure that they are able to do the humanitarian work that the Japanese Self Defence Force is undertaking in the Al Muthanna province. This was of course a difficult decision, as the Prime Minister said. It came, as he also said, out of the initial requests that were made firstly to Senator Hill and then to me when I was in London the day before the Iraqi elections on 29 January. I discussed this matter with Jack Straw, the British Foreign Secretary, and as a consequence of that he sent me a letter which I received in London on the Friday. The Prime Minister, Senator Hill and I and increasingly others discussed that during the next two weeks and eventually the cabinet made its final decision following a decision by the National Security Committee of cabinet.

We make no secret of the fact that it had not been our intention to send more troops until that time, that sitting fortnight—the last time the House sat—but nevertheless I believe it to be the right decision. I was supportive of the decision partly because of the role we are able to play in assisting the Japanese to ensure that there is a secure environment within which they can operate and do their humanitarian work. I think the contribution that we will make will be very much appreciated by the Iraqi people as well, and that is obviously a very important issue. My view on this overall issue is that, as other countries have made it clear—so our position is a pretty common position these days—on the question of Iraq, whatever the differences that people may have had on whether Saddam Hussein’s regime should have been overthrown or not and whatever the controversy about the weapons of mass destruction, the fact is that, like it or not—and people will take different views on that—we are now dealing with a situation on the ground in March 2005 and we have to make decisions day by day on what we do to address that situation.

If the international community showed a lack of resolve today and decided to abandon Iraq, the consequence would be that Iraq would be left in the hands of the terrorists and the insurgents who make up the remnants of the Saddam Hussein regime. The consequences for the 22 million or so people of Iraq would be quite dire, of course, if that were to happen. It would plunge their lives back into utter chaos. The consequences for the progress that is now being made with the slow spread of democracy and the stronger, more constructive and more positive climate in the Middle East would be disastrous. So many of the gains that we have seen—particularly, by the way, in the last few months—would be lost. Obviously the consequences for the United States and its allies from what is sometimes broadly described as ‘the West’ in the war against terrorism would also be utterly disastrous.

I appeal to people, whatever their political perspectives may be, to think about this issue in this context. It is reasonable enough for people to have different views over whether or not it was right to overthrow Saddam Hussein, whether the strategy on the ground has always been right since the overthrow and whether mistakes have been made—those are all important debates. I do not think there is any reason why we should necessarily walk away from those debates, but they are, in substance, historic debates. I think the real challenge for us today is to ensure that we do the right thing in the future and that the new emerging democratic Iraq is a success.

Australia is not a small country: it is the sixth biggest country in the world in area; it is the 11th or so biggest economy in the world; it has about the 50th biggest population. It is a very significant country. And Australia is a country which has the capacity to operate not just within the Asia-Pacific region; we have the capacity to operate beyond the Asia-Pacific region when we see it to be in our, our allies’ and the international community’s best interests. That is what we have done here. I think it would be a shameful thing if Australia were to cut and run from Iraq, to use a phrase—if we were to take the view that we should do nothing and abandon our responsibilities in Iraq. I think that would be a shameful thing. I think it would be Australia withdrawing in ignominy, and a matter of real national humiliation for us. I am actually, on the contrary, very proud of the fact that in Australia we continue to make a very strong contribution. Australia is committed also— (Quorum formed) As I was saying, we are very proud of the role we played in ensuring that Iraq is moving towards becoming a free country and we will continue to shoulder our share of the burden.

I must say, though, that the Labor Party’s position on Iraq has been a series of quite extraordinary outbursts over a long period of time. When the Labor Party first addressed this issue, they said they would support the overthrow of Saddam Hussein if done via a United Nations Security Council resolution or, if that resolution was not carried because of a veto, as long as there was substantial support for it. That position was abandoned, presumably as a result of a caucus decision. We had the call for the troops to be out by Christmas from Mark Latham and the claim that this had been discussed in the shadow cabinet when it clearly had not been, and that of course has been very much revealed since the federal election. The Labor Party lost the election and we then had the resurrection of the former Leader of the Opposition. Regrettably, for somebody who claims to be an expert on international security issues, he walks both sides of the street. He is not able to articulate clearly and in a way that anyone can remotely understand what the Labor Party’s aspirations for Iraq are and what the Labor Party wishes Australia’s contribution to be. We do not have enough troops there; we have too many troops there. We should bring our troops back into Asia—I am not quite sure what they would be doing in Asia. We should keep the Navy in the Persian Gulf, but we need the Navy to undertake maritime interception between the Philippines and Indonesia and we should bring it back to do that.

The series of contradictions and the waffle coming from the Leader of the Opposition are not just bamboozling but an embarrassment. I often say that the only people who would take heart from the Leader of the Opposition’s speech yesterday would be Geoffrey Barker and Alan Ramsay. It was a completely incomprehensible collection of thoughts, many of which were contradictory. The Labor Party needs to do what it said it would do before the Christmas period. It said it would go away over the Christmas-New Year period and consult with the United Nations, the Americans and the Iraqis on what Australia should do—

talk.start.para: Mr Rudd interjecting—
—Yet we have no statement from the Labor Party on what the Labor Party has concluded.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask that the member opposite refrain from the rude comment that he made a moment ago. It was unparliamentary.
—Does the parliamentary secretary seek the withdrawal of some statement?
—I ask the shadow foreign affairs minister to withdraw the comment.
—Will the member for Griffith withdraw?
—Yes.
—The member has withdrawn.
—One of the reasons the opposition are in opposition is that they have no capacity to articulate a sensible or coherent policy.
Ms Gillard interjecting—
—Personal abuse is no substitute for good policy. (Time expired)

—We have just seen exit the chamber Australia’s now longest serving foreign minister and, I think history will record, Australia’s least significant foreign minister. In terms of his contribution to this country’s long-term national security interests and foreign policy interests, historians will make the judgment. But, if they look long and hard at this minister’s performance in the parliament, at his performance before the Australian people and at what concrete actions he has taken in his portfolio to enhance this country’s national security and long-term foreign policy interests, I believe historians will cast a harsh judgment indeed.

speech.para: Dispatching troops to war in the first place is a grave decision; dispatching further troops to the same war is an even graver decision. This government has done both. Our troops of course have responded magnificently to the policy direction of the government and, as a consequence, they have done our country proud—as they constantly do our country proud wherever they serve and wherever I have seen them serve abroad, be it in Timor, Aceh or Iraq. Once again we pray for their safe return—each one of them. Each one comes from a family, from friends, from a community and from loved ones and each, therefore, is a precious life.

However, our purpose today is to debate the policy decision of the government on Iraq, the reasons for our involvement in this war, the consequences of our involvement in this war and what we can now do to build peace in Iraq. What were the government’s reasons for going to war? It is important in this debate to refresh our minds. They were very simple. They were threefold: (1) to eliminate stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons; (2) to prevent said stockpiles falling into the hands of terrorists; and (3) to eliminate said stockpiles by unilateral military means—absent the approval of the United Nations Security Council because the demand was so acute for our national security.

They were the three arguments advanced in this parliament at the dispatch box for our going to war in a foreign country. What the government did not argue was that their action in this invasion of Iraq was about international humanitarian intervention. They did not argue that they were about to liberate an oppressed people; they did not argue that they were involved in an enterprise of developing democracy in the wider Middle East. If honourable members have any doubts about any of these scores I would commend to them a quick read of the international legal opinion, which was tabled in this parliament by the Prime Minister, canvassing the reasons for this country going to war in Iraq.

Of course, if that is not a good enough test, honourable members could do a very simple word search. They could go the Prime Minister’s three statements delivered to the nation on why we were going to war and do a simple word search and note how many times they find in those three core statements these words: ‘weapons of mass destruction’. They were not just mentioned once; they were not just mentioned twice. A truck load of references were made to ‘weapons of mass destruction’ and their falling into the hands of terrorists. That is exhibit A.

Exhibit B is the statement made by the Prime Minister. If you look at the text of that statement and apply the same old word search—insert again the words ‘weapons of mass destruction’—what do you find? Not a single reference. The reason is that the entire argument which this government advanced for going to war has collapsed. Zero, zip and zilch is what you had in yesterday’s statement on the core reasons the government gave for going to war. When you have lost the reason for going to war, you have to invent a new reason. That is what this entire exercise has been about.

How many times have we in the opposition said of those who sit opposite us that they are loose with the truth. They are loose with the truth on national security and loose with the truth in putting Australian lives at risk. ‘Honest John’ is loose with the truth. The core arguments put for going to war are themselves the absolute essence of how this government has misled the Australian people, and people wonder why this Prime Minister’s reputation of trust in the Australian community more broadly is beginning to fracture.

What are the consequences of the war? Remember the objective set for this war was that it was an extension of the war against terrorism—that is, to reduce the overall terrorist threat. That was what it was about. The Prime Minister was warned, not by us but by others, as to the consequences which might arise from invading Iraq as far as terrorism was concerned. It was from no more reliable source than the British intelligence community. In February 2003, the British intelligence community wrote that the Joint Intelligence Committee:

quote.para: ... assessed that al-Qaeda and associated groups continued to represent by far the greatest terrorist threat to Western interests, and that threat would be heightened by military action against Iraq

speech.para: The date of said dispatch: February 2003. They read it; they had it before they went to war. We went to war in March 2003. We know this because it was subsequently outed through a Senate inquiry, which we requested and which they opposed, that this was presented to the Prime Minister. He knew that if he invaded Iraq it would actually exacerbate the terrorist threat. That was back in February 2003. Roll the clock forward a couple of years—the chickens have come home to roost. Who was their authority on this occasion? Porter Goss, the incoming Director of the Central Intelligence Agency. In his congressional testimony, which I commend to honourable members for a read about what has actually happened as a result of the Iraq war, he says:

quote.para: Islamic extremists are exploiting the Iraqi conflict to recruit new anti-U.S. jihadists

These jihadists who survive will leave Iraq experienced and focused on acts of urban terrorism. They represent a potential pool of contacts to build transnational terrorist cells, groups and networks in Saudi Arabia, Jordan and other countries.

speech.para: In other words, what Porter Goss, the Director of the CIA, is saying is that British intelligence warned this mob a couple of years ago. Remember that Iraq at that stage had had negligible contact with al-Qaeda, the mob that killed all those people on September 11, and its offshoot, Jemaah Islamiah, which killed our people in Bali not long after. Iraq, at the stage that we went to war, had virtually no connection with al-Qaeda—virtually none. What we have turned Iraq into—and this is the core national security issue at stake in this—is a new recruiting ground, training ground, facilitating pool, swamp, in which the new breed of global terrorists is being trained. This adds to the overall terrorist threat across the world.

If we go back again to the extraordinarily arrogant statements by this arrogant minister about his foreign policy responsibilities, I do not know how any person in conscience can walk around and say: ‘Oh, I have just gone over there and created civil war. I have also created a new training ground for a whole bunch of new terrorists. And that is all just tickety-boo; everything is just moving along fine, thanks. There are no real problems.’ This affects our security in our own region, our own neighbourhood, our own backyard. Remember the objective was to invade Iraq to reduce the overall terrorist threat. The achievement has been the reverse. Therefore, when the Australian people ask themselves the basic and legitimate question, ‘Is our security as a nation, as a people, better or worse as a consequence of this government’s decision to invade Iraq?’ any sober answer has to be, ‘It is worse.’ Because they are now out there by the thousand trained, exacerbated and excited by the events in Iraq and potentially unleashed on the world. And our authority on this? The Central Intelligence Agency.

What can we now do to help the Iraqi people, those who have suffered most from this war? First of all, let us just knock on the head some of this bogus, latter-day, post facto humanitarian concern on the part of those opposite. Remember the whole debate about whether they were going to take up their responsibilities as an occupying power in Iraq once the invasion had happened: if you are an occupying power you are responsible, once you invade the country, for the wellbeing of the civilian population of all 20 million Iraqis. They ran from that at a pace of knots. We reminded them time after time in the public debate and in here that they had formal responsibilities under the Geneva conventions, but they were out in a flash, or at least that is what they asserted—a month or two as an occupying power and flick pass the responsibility to others. This is the mob that now say they have this active role in humanitarian concern. Ask this government this question—and I am sorry Tweedledum, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is not here today, because we could ask him this question and he could give us an answer.

talk.start.para: Ms Gambaro interjecting—
—I am sorry about that. That is fine, it is done.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Griffith will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask the shadow foreign minister to withdraw that comment.
—That is fine.
—The member has withdrawn it.

—I have done it twice. Do you want me to do it three times? So here is the key question about the absolute guts of this government’s concern for the Iraqi people. Ask this government today—and we have tried to do this through Senate estimates—how many Iraqi civilians have been killed since the invasion; how many Iraqi civilians have been injured since the invasion. I would have thought that, as an occupying power in Iraq, at least until June last year, you would have a passing interest in this because you are the mob running the country. You have got rid of Saddam Hussein—and the Prime Minister has given us his reasons for doing that—you have then actually taken over the government for a period of about 18 months and you are responsible for about 20 million Iraqis, but as of the most recent Senate estimates you were not able to tell us whether there was any reliable calculation of how many people in the civilian population have been killed and injured as a consequence of the invasion.

speech.para: They say now, ‘What about the Iraqi people?’ There are things we can do when it comes to the Iraqi people. There are practical things we can do, but this Prime Minister’s response is to add this new deployment of almost 500 troops. Despite having been ‘Honest John’, loose with the truth for far too long, he said to John Laws:

quote.para: I can definitely say we won’t be adding hundreds. I can definitely say we’re not going to have a capacity to put more regular soldiers on the ground. We just don’t have that and I’ve made that clear to the Americans and the British ...

speech.para: I do not see any weasel word in that. ‘I’—John Howard—‘can definitely say we won’t be adding hundreds.’ That is what he said last April. Of course the Prime Minister now says circumstances have changed. The reasons given are tilting points, tipping points, lipping points, backflip points—you name it, they come up with it. There is a new word every day to explain what they have done. Dutch in, Dutch out; Ukrainians in, Ukrainians out; Bulgarians in, Bulgarians out; Australians up, down—all of it a series of reasons given by this mob, if you listen on any given day, relating to their assertion that circumstances have radically changed. None of them are convincing, but the Prime Minister says, ‘Not to worry, because I haven’t misled you.’ This is the key point I wish to impress upon the parliament—because it affects all of us, not just in the foreign policy sphere. It is the new prime ministerial doctrine of truth—that is, what constitutes lying to the Australian people, what constitutes misleading the Australian people.

What John Howard says is, ‘Don’t worry; I don’t regret it because it was consistent with my state of mind at the time. I like to be inconsistent with my state of mind at the time but it was consistent with my state of mind at the time.’ This is worth drilling into just a bit, because it affects all of us. That is, ‘So long as I, the Prime Minister, am convinced that what I, the Prime Minister, said last year was consistent with my state of mind at the time, bob’s your uncle. Therefore what I, the Prime Minister, actually say to the parliament and people is not relevant; it is what I think in my mind is consistent with my mind as it was back then.’ How do you know what is consistent or inconsistent with the Prime Minister’s mind back then? There is only one person who can tell you. Who’s that? The Prime Minister. He is the only person who can actually define whether he has been consistent or inconsistent with his mind when he makes a statement.

Anything the Prime Minister actually says is irrelevant, because there is a deeper, hidden, psychological, almost Freudian truth here, which is, ‘What is deeply in my mind at the time?’ That is his benchmark for deciding whether you are misleading somebody or not. So this is basically it: ‘I, Louis XIV, the person who runs the show here, do not take questions that are inconvenient. The new standard of truth is this: it is not what I say; it is what I had in my mind at the time.’ That is the new Howard doctrine of ministerial accountability in the parliament.

There are practical ways in which the Iraqi people can be helped. We on this side of the parliament have argued those for a long time, because the Iraqi people have suffered much in recent years. We argued that we can assist the Iraqi people in their continued efforts against terrorism by assisting in the protection of their oil terminals on the Gulf by the maintenance of HMAS Darwin and those ships which have preceded it and which may follow it. We have argued that we can assist the Iraqi people through enhanced border security. Why? Because there are jihadists coming in through highly porous borders with Jordan, Syria and Saudi Arabia. Based on my last visit to Iraq, one of the areas where acute assistance is needed is in enhancing the border control systems of the Iraqi border security services.

We can also assist the UN presence in Iraq itself, and we have made practical proposals on that line. How about a cancer hospital? Oncology services in Baghdad are virtually non-existent. We have a policy which says we should put our shoulder to the wheel and build an oncology hospital. Why not an Australian oncology hospital to service the needs of the Iraqi people? These are practical ways in which we can assist the people of Iraq and help build the peace, but we do not believe you can do that with a Prime Minister advancing a proposition to the country based on a lie. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Griffith will withdraw that!

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —‘Based on a lie’—withdraw that?
—What are the grounds for asking for it to be withdrawn?
—The member for Griffith will withdraw it.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —‘Based on a lie’? What’s wrong with saying that?
—The member for Griffith will withdraw it.
—With respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, could you explain to me your reasons for seeking that particular phrase to be withdrawn?
—What I heard was ‘a lie’, and that is unparliamentary—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —‘Based on a lie’!
—There is no debate!
—Oh, well, all right!
—The member for Fowler will remove herself from the parliament under 4(a)!
—The member for Griffith will withdraw it.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. You may have heard the words ‘a lie’, but it seems you must have heard them out of context. It is not unparliamentary to use the words ‘a lie’; we can use them in many, many contexts. What you cannot do is accuse somebody of lying. The member for Griffith did not accuse anybody of lying. He did say something was ‘based on a lie’, but that is a different form of words, a different form of speech, and there is no precedent of which I am aware that says that phrase should be withdrawn.

—I did not hear the full context, and I will accept that. All I heard was ‘a lie’. The member for Griffith was drifting very close to the mark all the time, as you might note, and I was watching it very, very closely. It is not beyond the realms of possibility that members do try to slip that in at the finish.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Ms Gambaro) adjourned.

talker.name: Mr ANDERSON,MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The minister may proceed.

—The member for Ballarat asked in question time about a Regional Partnerships grant for a child-care centre in my electorate, and I said that I would come back when I had more information. My department has checked the files. I can tell the House that, on 7 June 2004, I did write to the parliamentary secretary in support of this application. I would, though, just like to add a little to my answer. The child-care centre is at Bourke. It is the only centre in a 100-kilometre radius. Bourke, of course, has a very large disadvantaged community, and it would be hard to imagine a community in Australia that is doing it tougher than Bourke at the moment.
—Pretty sure we can!
—As a result—
—Oodnadatta.
—As the result of its—
—Port Hedland.
—The member for Lalor would realise that she has been warned once before about continuous interjection.

—As a result of the remote location and drought, it was having difficulty attracting staff. The grant was not to pay for the training of child-care staff; it was mainly to hire a temporary, untrained staff member so that the existing staff could study for their accreditation. The Commonwealth grant was matched almost dollar for dollar by cash or in-kind support from the applicant and a local business house. The project was strongly supported by the Orana Development and Employment Council, and the parliamentary secretary approved the project in line with the department’s recommendations.
—I’ve got a couple of those. Can I get some money?
—The member for Lyons!

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I do not know whether members on my left want to hear the continuation of business.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to deliver for Australian women.

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand it is the wish of the House for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to be the first speaker on this matter and for the time period normally allotted for the proposer of the matter to apply to her. I will allow that course to be followed.

—Unfortunately, on International Women’s Day today, we had the Prime Minister misleading the parliament on a matter that is of utmost importance to working women in particular: the government’s promise to introduce a 30 per cent tax rebate on child-care expenses. When the government went to the election last year, they promised that this rebate on child-care expenses would be payable from July this year, 2005. In question time today we had the Prime Minister in his usual triumphant and arrogant manner telling the parliament that he did not know what Labor was on about. Not only is he now up to breaking his promises but also plainly he forgets them. He said in the parliament today that we had got it all wrong and that in fact the payment was being brought forward.

speech.para: Let me inform the Prime Minister about his own promise which is now, of course, yet another broken promise. The Prime Minister has only the Treasurer to thank. Just before Christmas, the Treasurer announced that this promise to allow parents to claim the child-care rebate from July 2005 would not apply any more and that parents would have to wait until July 2006. Parents are going to have to wait another whole year before they get to see any of this tax rebate. The Prime Minister forgets that the promise he made during the election was to make sure that parents could get the benefit of this tax rebate from July 2005. So, Prime Minister, it would be a good idea to tell parents the truth, that this election promise has now been broken and parents will not in fact be able to claim this tax rebate until July 2006. This means that parents are going to have to continue to pay very high child-care fees and that they will not get any relief from those high child-care fees for another year—another year past the time that this Prime Minister promised before the election.

This is a very bitter disappointment to Australian families, and to Australian women in particular on this International Women’s Day. It should be a day of celebration, but it is a day when Australian women will have to face up to the fact that on this very important election promise this Prime Minister has yet again broken his promise. Today is a very important day to remember all the other areas where we have a very long way to go indeed. One particular area where this government continues to fall behind is in closing the gap between the average wages of men and women. If we have a look at what has happened to the gap over the time that this government has been in power, we can see that we now have a gap of over $300 a week between men’s and women’s average total wages. The gap is about $300 a week. The total average wage earned by women is just 65 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. Women’s average weekly earnings are now $587.30 while men’s average weekly earnings are $898.20. The shocking news for women, particularly for those women on lower wages, is that the gap between men’s and women’s total average wages grew from $229 a week in 1996 to $310 in 2004. This government has presided over an increase in the gap between men’s and women’s wages between 1996 and 2004.

We have also seen an extraordinary increase in the number of women working in casual jobs. Between August 1996, when this government came in, and August 2003 the number of women in casual work has increased by over 18 per cent. So we now have 1.2 million Australian women working in casual jobs. That is the reality of what this government has done to working women since it came to office. An extraordinary change has taken place in our workplace. Women in workplaces have also been treated like second-class workers under this government. We have seen the pay gap increase, and we have seen more and more women having to take casual jobs where their financial security is at risk. We have women on lower earnings, and the results of that are lower living standards and lower rates of saving and, for women in many circumstances, a chronic and precarious financial outlook. One of the major problems that this government has imposed on Australian women over its time in office is to make their living standards that much worse.

It is in the area of child care that we have some of the most serious concerns. We all know that if good quality affordable child care is not available it is just impossible for women to return to work after the birth of their babies. We know how essential it is for women to be able to choose to go back to work, and in circumstances where for their own family’s financial wellbeing some women must work. What are the problems that so many families, so many women, present to us on a daily basis? First and foremost is how hard it is to find a child-care place. Second is how hard it is to afford a child-care place. And, of course, as a result of the Prime Minister’s broken promise, the tax rebate that he promised during the election campaign will not be able to be claimed by parents for another year.

It is also the case that quality is threatened, primarily because we have an increasingly severe shortage of child-care workers. There has been a lot of discussion in the parliament in the last few days about skills shortages. It does not apply just to the traditional trades; it also applies in this very important area of child care. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, who is responsible for this area, revealed her belief earlier this year. She said in a statement that there were no child-care shortages. I will quote a statement in the Courier-Mail:

quote.para: Federal Minister for Families Kay Patterson said resources had been expanded and her spokesman said demand was being met.

speech.para: Those of you from Queensland, I am sure, would vouch for the fact that that is absolutely not the case. It just flies in the face of reality and it shows how out of touch this government is when it comes to making sure that there is an adequate number of child-care places available. This minister realised the folly of her ways just a couple of days later when she admitted grudgingly that there were ‘a few areas of unmet need’, in which case she said the market would solve it. ‘The market will solve it’, she blithely wrote in a letter to the editor of the Herald Sun.

After this second instalment of the minister’s official view on child-care availability I have no doubt that each and every one of you got an avalanche of phone calls. There were various letters to the paper about how it is absolutely necessary for the government to step in and make sure, especially in those areas where it is just not economical for private operators to work—maybe in the area that the member for Gwydir just mentioned; I think the member for Gwydir might have some areas like that in his electorate and I think in Wollongong and in many other parts of Australia there would be some areas like that—where it is just not viable for private operators to work, that child-care centres are available. We do need the government to come in and make sure that child-care centres are available.

The cost of child care has skyrocketed under this government. Just two weeks ago a task force on child-care costs—a consortium of leading employers and businesses—put out a press release. Child-care costs, according to them, have increased at 2.2 times the rate of average wage and salary earnings in the period 2002 to 2004. Just in that period we have seen an explosion in child-care costs. This task force also found that more than 37 per cent of the workers they surveyed were likely to leave the work force in the near future because of the cost of care. That is why this broken promise by the Prime Minister is so significant: women are saying they will have to leave the work force because of the extraordinary increase in the cost of care.

The government said that they want to introduce a 30 per cent child-care rebate, but only two months after the election—they did not wait very long at all—before the ink was dry, they broke the promise. They said, ‘Sorry, everyone—sorry, parents—you’re going to have to wait for another whole year before you get the benefit of this child-care rebate.’ Parents have also been left not knowing what they will have to do. Do they have to keep all receipts for two years and then present all of those receipts to the tax office to claim their rebates? Parents have not been told that this is what they will have to do, so goodness knows how they are going to find the receipts when it comes to claiming this 30 per cent rebate.

The government also broke their promise—once again, just before Christmas—when they said that the amount of child-care tax rebate that could be claimed was going to be capped. I am sure you all remember that during the election campaign the Prime Minister said that there would not be a cap on the child-care tax rebate, but now they have decided that they spent far too much money in the lead-up to the election and that they are going to have to pull the belt in in relation to child care. The savings that this Treasurer has made as a result of these two broken promises is $344 million. So it is no good the Prime Minister coming into question time and saying, ‘I don’t know what you’re talking about.’ How could it be that the Treasurer is claiming a saving of $344 million if they have not broken those election promises? Either they have the saving because they have broken their promise or they do not have the saving and they have another blow-out in their budget figures.

In question time today we had an extraordinary example from the Deputy Prime Minister of how to go about making sure you have high-quality child care in your child-care centres. Obviously, the answer is to make sure that you put in your application at the right moment and be the beneficiary, under this regional rorts program, of additional funding for a child-care centre so that you can help with accreditation. Funnily enough, none of us heard about it! None of us knew that you could apply for this money. Funnily enough the regional rorts program extends to the Deputy Prime Minister’s electorate and to his child-care centre, but to none of ours!

Everybody wants to make sure that their child-care centres are of the highest quality. All parents want that. Certainly all childcare workers want to make sure that they are delivering child care of the highest standard. One of the major problems with child care is making sure that we have properly qualified childcare workers and that they are properly paid—childcare workers receive very low pay. Very recently we had a decision from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission awarding a significant pay rise to childcare workers in Victoria and the ACT. We certainly hope that when that is implemented it will help. Parents cannot afford to see their fees go through the roof as childcare workers are appropriately paid. That is why, once again, it is so critical that this rebate be paid, and paid on time—and that the Prime Minister is held to his word so that parents ensure that their children go to centres where childcare workers are paid properly but parents are not paying through the nose or having to leave work because they cannot afford child care.

Labor had quite a different approach before the last election. We recognised that there was a serious shortage of child-care places. We wanted to add to the number of long day care places, where there are very serious shortages. We also wanted to add to the number of places for after school hours care, where there are significant shortages. I do not think there would be a parent in the country who does not know how hard it is to organise child care, especially during vacations and after school. So on this very important day, International Women’s Day, it is time for us to recognise the enormous pressure that this government is putting on parents especially, as a result of its broken promise on child-care. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I find it rather ironic that this debate, an MPI alleging the failure of the government to deliver for Australian women, should be brought into the House by the federal Labor Party, hot on the heels of a Labor Party factional brawl over the leadership of the party—a brawl which saw Labor members questioning the credentials of a woman for the leadership job, based on her marital and family status. What message does the federal Labor Party send to the women of Australia? In reference to the Labor Party, Susan Ryan, a former minister in the Hawke government, said in an interview on the 7.30 Report:

quote.para: Now we’re back in the dark ages, where a woman’s marital status and where she has children or not is being used against her by her own colleagues. We can’t even blame the media for this; it’s her own colleagues that did it.

speech.para: The member for Gellibrand went on in this interview to say, rather plaintively:

quote.para: Let’s actually have a debate about the skills and talents that women can offer to politics, rather than try to denigrate people about their personal circumstances.

speech.para: It is little wonder that former Labor member Cheryl Kernot revealed a culture of what she called ‘bullying’ in the ALP. It was enough for her to say that she was not suited to the ALP culture and would not return to politics—local, state or federal—unless the culture within the ALP changed radically. So it will obviously be a long time before we see her again.

But Labor have double standards on this and on so many other issues in terms of what they say and what they do. For Labor to raise the role of women in Australian society and suggest that their record is something to emulate just exposes their rank hypocrisy. The Labor Party elected as their leader the former member for Werriwa—a man who in his public utterances single-handedly denigrated and demeaned all Australian women when in his crude vernacular he referred to a professional journalist as a ‘dirty whore’. When he spoke so disparagingly about a woman, what did we hear from the men or women of the ALP? Did anyone ask or demand that he apologise as common decency would require?

talk.start.para: Mr Adams interjecting—
—The member for Lyons is on thin ice.
—There was not a word. There was deafening silence from the ALP, thus destroying any credibility within the Australian Labor Party—
Mr Adams interjecting—
—The member for Lyons is warned!

—to speak with any authority on the role of women in Australian society. This incident highlighted for women across Australia the double standards and sheer hypocrisy within the Australian Labor Party. At the last election, the women of Australia looked at the record of achievements for women under the Howard government and voted accordingly. I am here as a minister in the Howard government to speak with pride about the increased status of women in our society and the Howard government’s regard and respect for Australian women and their contribution to our society.

speech.para: A hallmark of the Howard government’s public policy is choice, and nowhere more so than in the area of public policy issues affecting women and their role in society. Since 1996, we as a government have recognised and embraced the changed and changing role of women within our community. We have attacked in a practical way areas of continuing discrimination. We have established practical options for Australian women—wherever they live, whatever they choose to do, whatever their personal circumstances and whatever situation they find themselves in. The government have recognised that the right solutions for women are the right solutions for the community as a whole—and they are the outcomes that women themselves want. So instead of the cliches trotted out by Labor, which reveal a mind-set that is still so out of step with contemporary Australian women—Labor are still in a seventies time warp—let us look at the undeniable facts.

This government has provided more opportunities and choice for Australian women than any previous government. We recognise that women fulfil many different roles throughout their lives. They have different needs and responsibilities, whether they be education, families, careers, retirement, health or aged care. The greatest opportunities this government has provided to women come from the benefits that flow from one of the strongest economies that Australia has ever seen. We have the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years. That means there is an increasing number of jobs for all Australians, including women. At 66 per cent and increasing, women’s labour force participation is the highest it has ever been.

In recognition of the aspirations of many women to maintain a balance of career and family, the Howard government has set record levels of support for women in many areas. Let us take child care, for example. The coalition government has spent and continues to spend more on child care than any Labor government ever did. In fact, we expect to spend around $8 billion over the next four years to support child care. Our commitment will be significantly boosted, with additional assistance of $1.1 billion to 2007-08 for the child-care tax rebate and grandparent carer measures which the Prime Minister announced in the election campaign. So we are looking at women in their roles as mothers and grandmothers. In addition, the government has funded 40,000 new outside school hours care places and 4,000 new family day care places. These have been available since December 2003. In the six years to 2003-04, around $8.8 billion has been spent on child care. That is more than double the amount spent in Labor’s last six years in office—in actual dollars.

Child-care benefit assists over 700,000 families a year using approved child care. The child-care benefit subsidises around 67 per cent of the total cost of full-time long day care to low-income families paying average fees. The latest available figures show that families receive an average child-care benefit payment of over $2,000 a year. Child-care benefit is indexed each year in line with the CPI to maintain the value of that payment to families—it was boosted by 2.4 per cent last July. The number of government funded child-care places and services has increased substantially since the Howard government came to office. Child-care places have increased by about 83 per cent from over 306,000 to 561,900. The outside school hours care places have increased by 277 per cent from 71,000 to 270,000. Family day care places have increased from 60,100 to 776,300. We are talking about massive increases. Child-care services have increased by some 28 per cent. Record numbers of children have access to Australian government funded child-care places. So it is a nonsense to suggest otherwise. The number of children using child care has increased by about 21 per cent since the introduction of the child-care benefit.

The Australian government have implemented quality assurance systems in long day care, family day care and outside school hours care to ensure the services provide quality outcomes for children. In order to be eligible for the child-care benefit and other funding support, services must comply with all applicable Commonwealth, state and territory legislation and regulations. We fund the National Childcare Accreditation Council to administer quality assurance to ensure children have a positive experience that fosters all aspects of their development. In so many ways, whether it be implementing quality assurance, the Special Needs Subsidy Scheme or the community support stream in child-care support, we are doing what we can to ensure that women have the choice to maintain their careers and go back into the work force while ensuring that their children are being appropriately cared for.

The Howard government are delivering for Australian women in a number of other areas. We have ensured that our tax policy provides support for families to give women choice within the family situation. The family tax benefit provides support for the cost of children to around two million families—about 3½ million children benefit from the family tax benefit. The vast majority of Australian families with dependent children are now eligible to receive the family tax benefit.

In recognition of the special needs of new mothers, since 1 July last year new mothers have received a non-means-tested maternity payment of $3,000 to assist with the costs associated with the birth or adoption of a new baby. The rate of the maternity payment will increase to $4,000, from 1 July 2006, and then to $5,000, from 1 July 2008. So in so many ways the Australian government is recognising the needs, the hopes, the dreams and the aspirations of Australian women.

Let us focus on women in the work force. Since 1996, full-time adult ordinary time earnings for women have increased in real terms—that is, after taking account of inflation—by $152 a week. That is a 21 per cent increase and represents an annual rate of growth in real earnings of 2.2 per cent. Under Labor, women’s real earnings grew at an annual rate of just 0.6 per cent.

The claim by Labor that the gap between male and female earnings has increased is also wrong. This can be seen in the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates of full-time adult ordinary time earnings. Women’s earnings have increased as a proportion of men’s. The proportion has risen from 83.2 per cent in February to 84.8 per cent today, so the gap is closing, not increasing.

Let us consider what has been achieved under this government’s responsible economic management in relation to women’s jobs. With strong economic management and the fiscal discipline shown by the Howard government, women have benefited from the creation of almost 820,000 new jobs—53 per cent of the total of more than 1.5 million new jobs created under the Howard government. This additional employment for women comprises nearly 340,000 full-time jobs and 480,000 part-time jobs. So this balance reflects the diversity of aspirations and choices of Australian women.

The impact of these increasing opportunities can be seen in the rising proportion of women participating in paid work. While in 1996 49.6 per cent of Australian women were in employment, with the strong growth of the economy this is now 53.6 per cent. There has been remarkable growth in the employment of older women. Support for families with children, for women entering the work force and for women remaining in the work force has enabled so many women to choose to combine both employment and the care of their children.

In my portfolio, the Ageing portfolio, the government supports women in their varying roles as carers and aged care workers. In fact, women make up 95 per cent of the aged care work force. Through increased government support, women have been able to find rewarding and challenging careers in aged care. In the last budget, over $101 million of funding was made available for increased training and education opportunities. It is a fact that most carers are women. We have increased funding for the National Respite for Carers Program fivefold. This year over $105 million is being invested in the program.

All of these measures help underline the government’s principle of choice for women. Unlike Labor, we believe that people should have choice in how they live and how they manage their work and their family. We do not believe in one-size-fits-all systems which tell people how to live, that they must work, that they must have children or that they should or should not do certain things. We do not believe in the nanny state. We do not believe in artificial quotas, and this is in line with what Australian women want.

In this government, for the first time in Australia’s history, there are now nine female ministers and parliamentary secretaries. Women from the Liberal Party side were elected first to the House of Representatives and to almost all of the state parliaments. We have a proud history of supporting women’s choice and women’s role in society. It was a Liberal government that introduced child endowment, that introduced the first national child-care office, that first recognised the rights of married pensioners in the tax system and that introduced private health insurance provision. On the international front, we can be proud that Australian women now hold 19 high commission positions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to respond to a few comments made by the previous speaker, the member for Curtin. I suggest to the member for Curtin that, if we want to conduct a debate on International Women’s Day around issues of who promotes women and who wins ballots in parties, the Liberal Party is indeed—as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, would appreciate—not always the best example. Much of the member for Curtin’s speech, where she focused on choice and the importance that the Howard government places on the concept of choice, reflected a lot of statistics and amounts of money and not much of the reality and the challenges faced by many of the families we deal with in our electorates.

speech.para: I welcome the opportunity to address the subject of this debate on matters of public importance today, International Women’s Day. There are so many areas in which the ability of Australian women to participate fully and effectively in our communities and our nation has suffered significantly under the Howard government’s policies. The Howard government constantly trumpet their two magic words—‘choice’ is one of them; the other is ‘flexibility’—and tell us how much joy and sunshine these two principles bring into the lives of Australian families. It is obvious from the real experience of families that all that has been achieved is that greater pressure has been placed on the ability of families to balance their work commitments and provide quality time for their family needs.

One of the most serious failures of the government has been its refusal to take on the crisis that exists in many areas in the provision of child care for working families. Indeed, the member for Curtin has just exhibited that failure again by fundamentally denying that there is in fact a problem. During the election campaign last year, the member for Throsby and I invited the shadow minister to visit our area. We did that because we needed to address the concerns that had been raised with us by so many local families. I will give just one example of the stories that were brought to us. There was a young couple we met who were very organised and proactive and who had registered for a child-care place on the day they discovered the woman was pregnant. At the time of the election they were still waiting to find a place; their child was 10 months old and the woman was to return to work in two months time.

The waiting lists continue to be a real issue of concern in our area, as they are in so many other places, particularly for nought- to two-year-olds. It is interesting to note the government’s speculation currently under way about requiring single mothers to return to work when their children start school. It is clear that this will place an unbearable and unrealistic demand on single mothers if they are unable to access child care. Indeed, if the existing working population is already having trouble finding child care, how much pressure will this requirement also place on the child-care providers?

For many women the ‘flexible’ work environment actually means casual or part-time work that is often unpredictable in hours and unreliable in income provision. In fact, the number of women in casual work has grown by close to 19 per cent since 1996. This has no doubt contributed to the fact that since 1996 the gap between men’s and women’s total average wage has widened by over $300 per week. Indeed, there are reports today that the lower wages we are seeing are also causing lower superannuation savings for women, affecting the financial security of women in retirement.

The other factor arising from the nature of casual work is that it severely erodes a working woman’s capacity to meet the needs of her family. I have had many local women describe the difficult dilemmas they face when a child falls sick, for example. As casuals they have no access to parental leave. They do not dare refuse a shift or ring in sick, as they know that such a black mark against their name can only mean fewer shifts in future. They do not have extended family to rely on—the reality is that many grandmothers are now working and are not readily available for emergency child care. Very often their partner is also in casual or part-time work where they cannot afford the black mark of trying to get time off work when children are sick. This is the real face of flexibility in the work force, which is wrongly represented by the Howard government as the new friendly structure that allows families to negotiate family-friendly work conditions with their employers.

The government so often also talks about the need for Australians to be having more children, yet over a quarter of women of child-bearing and child-rearing age are in precarious and family-unfriendly working conditions which become a major deterrent to young couples beginning families. Approximately one-third of women are in jobs where they have no rights to important entitlements such as sick leave, annual leave or compassionate leave—the very entitlements that make it possible for women to be working Australians and mothers at the same time without making heartbreaking choices between those roles. I also point to the growing trend of women undertaking greater responsibility for elderly parents who are often frail and highly dependent. Many women are working, looking after the needs of their own immediate family and also trying to juggle doctors appointments, banking, shopping needs and so forth for frail or elderly parents.

The shadow minister for industrial relations correctly identified today that 60 per cent of low-paid workers are women who will be seriously affected by proposals by this government to undermine the ability of the minimum wage cases to deliver some fairness to these low-paid workers. Clearly, the future for so many women workers is looking more precarious and difficult under this government. The minister for industrial relations has made it clear that fairness is not an important principle, apparently, for this government. You are only going to get the flexibility ‘f’; you will not get the fairness one.

In recent days we have also heard much from this government about how seriously it takes skill shortages. I have been taking issue with this claim in terms of the investment in addressing the growing demand for traditional trades apprentices. I would like to take this opportunity to point out that it is also failing to deliver sufficient funding for the training of child-care workers. As an example from my own area, there were nearly 100 young people turned away from child studies courses at TAFE this year. Sixty-two had applied to complete the child-care diploma and 33 had applied for the certificate III in child care. Clearly, the government is failing to recognise, and invest to address, a future shortage in the child-care industry as well as in the traditional trades. I might say that the vast bulk of those who were turned away were young women.

The other issue that we hear about constantly from child-care providers is the growing problem of recruiting workers. It is clear that the problem is not caused by any job snobbery by young people or their families, as the Prime Minister would have us believe. The problem is that funding of the TAFE sector has been frozen for so many years that young people are being turned away, even when they are looking to train in areas of skill shortage and in an industry that is critical to the capacity of families in our communities to balance their family and work commitments.

The same problem I have just described for child-care training applies to the thousands of women who are turned away each year from other critical training areas such as nursing, aged care nursing and teaching. International Women’s Day is obviously an important day on which we recognise—97 years after women in the United States first went on strike for better wages and improved workplace conditions—the importance of working to improve women’s wages and working conditions.

Women are constantly and loudly still calling for fairer access to education, affordable housing and health care, and working to expose the instances of abuse, neglect and discrimination in our society. To simply paint a picture that says that this side of the House is attempting to raise negatives in a time when all is sunshine and roses is an absolute indictment of this government for its inability to come to terms with the reality facing many families in our communities. Indeed, it does not take long in your electorate office talking to people about the challenges they face—such as the family that cannot get child care or the family that is trying to find an aged care place for elderly parents—to realise these are very real pressures and demands on working Australian families. They are very real pressures that face women in trying to make choices between work and family. It is no surprise that young people in our community who are facing the cost of housing and health care and, indeed, the pressure to work to fund their basic lifestyle are not choosing to have families. The government constantly runs the line about the importance of young families having children so that we do not have the problems of an ageing population but walks away from the things that would fix the problem. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to join the debate today on International Women’s Day. I thank all those all over Australia and the world who are taking time to mark this very special occasion. I think it was Virginia Woolf who said, ‘As a woman I have no country, my country is the whole world.’ As we used to say, the sisterhood stretches across countries, class barriers and distinctions in a way that perhaps no other connection can. I think that that is the message for today’s International Women’s Day, that we remember women all over the world.

speech.para: I urge all Australian women to reach out to women on the other side of the world, especially those who struggle with poverty and disadvantage, particularly in developing countries. We should remember and support women who have not had the advantages we have had, both in terms of living in a wealthy country and living in a society where opportunities between men and women are equal.

We should remember women who have to watch their children go hungry or not receive adequate medication. As mothers, we should understand the heartache that that produces. That should be the main message coming from this parliament and this debate today. It was disappointing to hear the member for Cunningham and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition niggle at the government over slight differences, either in policy or in philosophy. We should, as women, unite across and in spite of our political differences and recognise together how far we have come, thanks to the guts of the women who have gone before us. They made, for example, my life so easy as a woman with three children all at school, able to take my place in the parliament today and represent the people of Farrer. There are many examples opposite of women who have small children and who, in fact, have given birth while they have been members of parliament. The flexibility and the choice that they have is testimony to the society in which we live.

I want today, particularly remembering that it is International Women’s Day, to spare a thought for the women of Iraq and the women of Afghanistan who have laboured under some horrendous regimes. Now that democracy is being introduced to that part of the world, they can look forward to a brighter future. I remember during the regime of the Taliban in Afghanistan seeing some file footage of some men getting into the front of a station wagon and bundling the women into the back, where there were not even any seats, just like so much baggage. The horror of that picture is something to be remembered. This is not a religious bias—this is not a criticism of Islam, which is in fact very generous towards women—this is a cultural bias in these societies. We certainly saw it in the very secular Iraq under the very brutal regime of Saddam Hussein. We should spare a thought for the women who yearn to bring democracy to a post-Saddam Iraq and who are working hard to do that. These women appreciate the difference between totalitarianism and democracy, between the worlds that separate a person whose life is controlled by a tyrant and a person who can walk and talk freely.

This Australian government has always had a policy of opportunity and choice for women. Recent research indicates that, since 1996, full-time adult ordinary time earnings for women have increased in real terms, after inflation, by $152 a week, which is a 21 per cent real increase in wages. I point out that statistic because those on the other side today have said that wages have somehow fallen when you compare the wages women earn to the wages men earn, and that is to be refuted. It also has to be remembered that while the aggregate wages women earn probably are less, they reflect the different lifestyle choices that women make. As an example, anecdotally, women who have been in high-flying professions might choose, when they come to the child-bearing time of their life, to drop back to not working at all and then work perhaps in a part-time, less stressful job so that they can devote that time to caring and sharing with their family.

It is the role of governments to facilitate the choices that families make, not—as the Minister for Ageing so correctly pointed out—to be in there telling people what to do and how to live their lives. So it is important that we should not describe the cultural characteristics of our society as being negatives for women. The fact that women choose to stay at home or leave the work force for a while in order to have and raise children or take less pressured, lower paid jobs in order to get the work and family balance right should not be a reason to condemn the government for low wages or less opportunity for women.

Women in Australia 2004, the third in the Women in Australia series, was published today. I commend this publication to anyone who is interested in the state of women in society today. One of the things that was pointed out was that women do not have prominence in managerial and decision-making roles. I would like to see that increase—I am sure we all would. But I suppose it is reflective of the fact that the average working life for a man is, I think, 38 years and for a woman it is 18 years. That is not a problem; it is simply a feature of the fact that women bear the children and women generally take the time off to raise them. These are cultural features of our society and they should not be something that governments in some way should try and correct, even if they could.

I mentioned Women in Australia 2004. It is an excellent statistical and analytical reference publication and I commend the Office of the Status of Women for doing such a good job in conjunction, I think, with the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It provides a snapshot of the state of women in Australia today—the good and bad and the ugly. But overwhelmingly I think it gives a positive picture of where we are, where we have been and where we are going. Women are living longer. The retention rate at school for year 12 girls is now 81 per cent. The proportion of women in management and decision-making roles is not as high as I would like to see it but it is increasing.

This particular publication highlights the story for Australian women in a range of diverse areas—management, politics, rural and regional areas. As a rural and regional member in this place, I pay tribute to the work that women do, often in isolation and in very dire financial circumstances, in my own electorate and in other rural parts of Australia as they battle life on the land, with all the difficulties that that presents and continues to present as we face year after year of low rainfall and difficult commodity prices in some areas.

Of particular note in the publication Women in Australia 2004 are the significant improvements in women’s employment which demonstrate the success of the government’s economic policies in providing increased opportunities and rewards for participation. People talk a lot about what the government can provide. Of course it can only provide what the economy can produce. This economy over the last 10 years has seen record growth in productivity. We are now coming up against supply constraints in the economy so, in the context of the current industrial relations debate, that is what we as a government are quite rightly paying attention to. If we can remove industrial relations bottlenecks then we can make the economy more productive. We can make it easier for businesses and easier for employers and therefore easier for the people that work for them.

I encounter many small businesses in my electorate overwhelmed by state government red tape. They have got to have a policy for this and a policy for that. In carrying out basic day-to-day activities, they have to check somehow that they are dotting all the i’s and crossing all the t’s. These people would love to provide the conditions that, say, a government department can—a government department which is bigger and better resourced—but they are not able to do that because they are small and they are struggling under this burden. So when we have addressed the issues of industrial relations and red tape and bottlenecks for small businesses we will then be in a position to indirectly offer the people who work in those areas a much better deal and employers will be able to be more flexible and more generous with their employees.

As a government we are delivering for Australian women because we manage a strong productive economy. We provide significant family support. In her speech in this debate the Minister for Ageing demonstrated how much we provide in family tax benefits. We have provided a record number of child-care places. We understand that the work and family balance is an important agenda item for this fourth term of the Howard government. In conclusion, I urge all women—young, old, single, married, in the work force or out of it—on this International Women’s Day to stand tall, be proud and take your place in the modern intelligent economy which you are a part of. Thank those who made it possible and think of those who have still some way to go.

talk.start.para: —I think we would be entitled to say ‘here we are again’ when dealing with medical indemnity issues and the Howard government. It is like a perpetual version of Groundhog Day: we are back at it again, putting another patch through, another piece of medical indemnity legislation—another patch-up job that is required because they did not do the job right the first time around. I suspect that if I am feeling a little bit wearied by all of this there are probably some in the advisers box who have more cause than I to feel so.

speech.para: The bill which is before the House on this occasion amends legislation first implemented to address the crisis facing the medical indemnity sector in 2002-03. Specifically, the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 seeks to correct anomalies arising from that legislation’s interaction with industry practice. Labor have not at any point opposed the Howard government’s patch-up jobs on medical indemnity. Indeed, we have on more than one occasion facilitated rapid passage of bills as necessary to help dig the Minister for Health and Ageing out of the medical indemnity hole he had dug for himself and then jumped into. Whilst we have taken that approach with the medical indemnity legislation, that is not to say that we do not think all of it could have been done better. We have made consistent suggestions to the government about how it ought to be done better and there will be some matters in that regard that I want to go to today.

Perhaps we should all remind ourselves where this started or at least where it first got onto the government’s radar. In truth, anybody with a modicum of intelligence could have seen that medical indemnity issues were going to be big and bad news for Australia, medical professionals and patients, but the Howard government—arrogant as it is, out of touch and often negligent itself when it comes to addressing public policy issues—managed to do nothing until the crisis burbled up in a way that it could not ignore.

That first happened in November 2001 when Australia’s main medical defence organisation, UMP, failed to fund $460 million worth of incurred but not reported claims—referred to in the trade as IBNR claims—‘incurred’ meaning the adverse medical event which caused an injury has happened but that the injury has not been reported. Obviously, in many examples of medical misadventure there will be long lead times before even the patient recognises that there has been an injury or the true loss flowing from the injury can be assessed. Perhaps a good example of that is a baby who is injured due to some form of medical negligence at the time of birth. It will not be possible to assess the full dimensions of the impact on the child or the adult for many years and obviously there are statutory issues about when that infant can sue and has legal capacity. So in any sense of dealing with medical indemnity issues there are also a significant number of incurred but not reported claims, and it was in relation to the funding of such anticipated liabilities that UMP basically said, ‘We can’t cope.’ UMP was at that stage Australia’s biggest medical defence organisation and significantly covered doctors in New South Wales as well as in other parts of the country.

In December 2001 UMP increased its premiums by 52 per cent on average to cope with the crisis. However, for obstetricians and neurosurgeons this increase was as high as 123 per cent. In February 2002 UMP also faced pressure by the prudential regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, to raise additional capital to meet minimum capital requirements and APRA gave UMP until 30 June 2002 to raise over $30 million to meet these requirements. Finally, the crisis was in an unignorable form, even though the Howard government had gone on in their blithe and arrogant way of ignoring the real issues that affect Australia and certainly ignoring public policy issues which were on the horizon. In health they never do anything until there is an absolutely unavoidable crisis either of a political or true health policy dimension. But this crisis threatened to be one of both a political and a health policy dimension as it became clear that doctors might end up uncovered and uninsured and therefore unwilling to practise if UMP failed—or, if UMP struggled on, it would be in circumstances where doctors, particularly people in high-risk specialties, would be picking up enormous additional loads of medical indemnity premiums and would be looking for a way to pass the increased costs on either to government as a funder of medical services or, more particularly, to patients. In circumstances of an uncertain environment, another effect is that people in high-risk specialties pull back from doing the high-risk end of the work and choose to solely practise in the lower risk end of the work. So, for example, many obstetricians indicated that they intended to practise only as gynaecologists and not as obstetricians because of the additional medical negligence issues that arise when one is practising in obstetrics.

So with this crisis finally on the government’s radar, the government reacted by intervening on 28 March 2002 to provide a short-term guarantee of up to $35 million to enable UMP to meet its minimum capital requirements as required by APRA. Then in April 2002 UMP unsuccessfully sought further assistance from the Howard government to enable its directors to get personal liability insurance. On 29 April 2002 UMP filed for provisional liquidation, and a provisional liquidator was appointed on 3 May 2002. The main objectives of the provisional liquidator were to determine the company’s solvency and ability to continue trading, so the crisis was gathering momentum at that point. Finally, the Prime Minister made a commitment to ensure that, in the event of provisional liquidation, doctors who were members of UMP would be covered whilst a solution was developed to the medical indemnity crisis. The Prime Minister was blithely promising at that time that it would be a long-term solution.

Here we stand all these wearying years of the medical indemnity saga later and we certainly cannot report that the Howard government has managed to stumble over a long-term solution to the medical indemnity crisis. On 28 April 2002 the then Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer announced that the Howard government would guarantee claims arising from any procedures from 29 April to 30 June 2002, with those procedures being undertaken by doctors covered by UMP, and that it would legislate this guarantee and assist in determining the long-term viability of UMP. So there we have it: UMP staggering to a provisional liquidation point and the Howard government stepping in and saying, ‘Well, we’ll at least fix that in the short term and we’ll have a think about the longer term.’

Understandably, the AMA and doctors covered by UMP were unsatisfied by the Howard government’s guarantees and there was a climate of great uncertainty. In that climate doctors were necessarily thinking of some drastic steps such as leaving their profession entirely, leaving the high-risk end of their profession or postponing surgery until they knew, with more certainty, what the environment would be.
