There were then some exchanges of letters between the Howard government and affected doctors. In that environment, the guarantee that was offered by the Howard government was finally approved by the courts in June 2002. This approval included an extension of the guarantee until 31 December 2002.

The government also agreed to assume responsibility for the IBNR claims where the incident giving rise to the claim occurred before 30 June 2003. The Howard government indicated that it would impose a levy on members of UMP so it could recoup the amount that it had guaranteed it would cover because of the crisis that UMP had got itself into. So we have Australia’s major medical defence organisation basically not able to meet its liabilities and certainly not able to meet liabilities which will be incurred in the fullness of time as incurred claims are reported. In those circumstances the Howard government finally manages to say, ‘We’ll pick up the financial obligation for those liabilities’—which was around $460 million—‘and in exchange for that we will levy doctors over the medium term and make something that looks like our money back.’

As many members of this House would recall, because many electorates would have had patients affected by this crisis, when the Howard government moved to impose the levy there was a highly adverse reaction from doctors, and understandably so. There was little warning to individual doctors about what was going to happen next. Doctors around the country, but particularly in New South Wales, were opening up levy notices which imposed on them huge additional liabilities. They were necessarily very concerned about that and many of them were in the circumstance where they were going to down tools, close wards and walk off the job. It was in the face of that crisis that the Howard government had to react again.

Perhaps many of us would remember that, after the current Minister for Health and Ageing was appointed on 29 September 2003, one of the first things on his desk to do was to resolve this re-emerging medical indemnity crisis. A deal was struck with doctors and a high-level panel was created to talk about medical indemnity issues and seek a resolution. So we were in a situation where there was backing and filling and patching, and it was still a question of crisis. In that environment, Minister Abbott was necessarily trying to strike a deal to ensure that doctors did not desert wards full of patients because they were so concerned about their medical indemnity position.

Faced with this crisis, what did the Howard government do? Obviously some changes were made to levy arrangements which found greater favour with doctors—you could not characterise the doctors as having ended up happy in this set of arrangements—than the originally proposed arrangements. Then there was a series of other things added to try and pacify doctors and deal with the medical indemnity crisis. One of the things implemented was the medical indemnity premium subsidy scheme. This was about subsidising the premiums for obstetricians, procedural GPs, neurosurgeons and GP registrars undertaking procedural training. Typical of the Groundhog Day backing and filling and patching that has beset this area, that scheme in its original iteration was changed in 2004 to strike a new formula for the way the premium subsidy scheme would work in relation to doctors’ gross incomes. The government also implemented the High Cost Claims Scheme to further reduce pressure on medical defence organisations. Under this scheme, 50 per cent of insurance payouts over $500,000 are reimbursed to medical indemnity providers.

The government also struck a run-off cover arrangement. That was necessary because a part of the suite of changes that came into effect following the crisis manifesting itself was that the whole medical indemnity set of arrangements moved from offering doctors cover on a claims incurred basis to a claims made basis. So in the past a doctor who was in practice, say, from the age of 30 to 65 could be insured for each of the years that he or she was employed. Presuming that each year they had been working they had purchased claims incurred cover, if there was a claim that was reported when that doctor was in retirement at 68 or 72 or 75—or even if that doctor was deceased and the family was then in charge of the doctor’s estate—the claims incurred cover that the doctor had paid for whilst in work was satisfactory to meet their obligation under that claim. When the medical indemnity industry moved across to claims made cover, as it did in the course of this set of changes, it meant that, if the claim was not made in the period that you were working and paying your premiums and you had not made any further arrangements, you could end up with a claim being incurred at a time that you were uninsured.

For example, a doctor who was involved in an adverse medical event when they were 62 might find that the incident was not reported until they were 72 and out of the work force and no longer insured. As a result of that, there was a need for run-off cover to cover the set of arrangements where doctors had left the work force. There are obviously a variety of circumstances in which doctors can leave the work force. They can leave the work force because they have wholly retired, because they are moving into their older years and no longer want to work. They can move from the work force because of disability. They can move from the work force because of maternity. They can move from the work force because they have died. They can move from the work force because they have given up being a medical practitioner and gone into some other line of work.

The government has obviously found in the original iteration of the run-off cover arrangements that the definitions of when this cover was going to apply and to whom it was going to apply were insufficient, and this bill deals with the clarification of some of those arrangements. This bill also deals with another of the schemes put on to patch the medical indemnity crisis. That scheme was the Exceptional Claims Scheme, previously known as the blue sky scheme. The scheme applies when a doctor sustains a claim above $20 million—that is, a claim above an amount for which the doctor has insurance. That means that the Commonwealth will step in and pay the difference between the $20 million and whatever the claim is.

Whilst that has offered doctors some theoretical reassurance, as far as I am advised there has never been a claim of that order in Australia. I think the highest was a $14 million claim, which may then have been revised downwards on appeal. Obviously an anxiety amongst doctors, having seen a high-value money claim in the order of $14 million, was that they could end up being exposed to liabilities that topped out beyond insurable levels. That is what the Exceptional Claims Scheme was about.

All in all, the bill we have before us is another patch on the run-off cover arrangements; it is another patch on the Exceptional Claims Scheme arrangements. I think it adds to three other bills in medical indemnity that I have dealt with in the time that I have been shadow minister for health, and each of them has been about patching on a patch to try and fix the medical indemnity problem.

As I have had cause to remark in the House before, it did not need to be like this. And why didn’t it need to be like this? It did not need to be like this because a more prudent government would have seen the medical indemnity problems emerging and it would have got in first—not responded to a crisis after it had occurred. If the government had got in first then obviously it could have consulted. It could have better structured and better managed arrangements rather than waiting for a crisis, whacking down a solution, finding that solution was unsatisfactory and whacking down another solution and so on, which is what has happened with medical indemnity.

Did you need to be Nostradamus to see the medical indemnity crisis coming? Did you need to have a crystal ball of considerable power in front of you? No, you most certainly did not. All you needed to do when you were sworn into office in 1996 as a Howard government minister was to read the reports sitting on your desk. If the then minister for health, Dr Michael Wooldridge, had put himself through that process, he would have found sitting on his desk the Tito report—a report by Ms Fiona Tito, who had been asked by the outgoing Labor government to report on medical indemnity issues because the outgoing Labor government realised that medical indemnity was going to be a major issue.

In some senses we do not know whether Dr Michael Wooldridge got round to clearing that section of his desk or whether he did clear that section of his desk and decided to do nothing. Whilst we might not have great insight into everything Dr Michael Wooldridge did in the days after the swearing-in of the Howard government when he was looking at what was on the desk, we do know from his own words that he is very proud of not having done very much in this area of policy. At a conference at the University of Melbourne in 2003, Dr Michael Wooldridge, who had been minister for health for nearly six years after the Tito report would have crossed his desk, said:

quote.para: As Minister, I was accused of doing far too little on medical indemnity. That’s completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever.

speech.para: So there it is in the former minister’s own words. It is not something that I said; it is not something that anybody presently in this chamber said. There is the former minister’s own summation of his performance in this area when he was minister. He is proudly saying in a humorous formulation of words that he did absolutely nothing whatsoever to deal with the medical indemnity crisis.

What has been the consequence of the Howard government doing ‘absolutely nothing whatsoever’ until the crisis was such that they needed to scramble and act, because doctors were packing in their medical practices or walking off the job because of their medical indemnity exposure? It has certainly been lots of legislative time of this parliament as we have legislated, re-legislated and legislated again to try and get this right. It has been hundreds of millions of dollars, not all of it easily tracked and added up because it has been over a number of financial years. Hundreds of millions of dollars have flowed from the Howard government into the various patch-up schemes and, of course, the original bailout of UMP.

One can only believe—and I am sure this is the case—that, if the Howard government had reacted in a timely way and had devised a policy solution that was going to work before the crisis was a crisis, it could have been addressed for a far cheaper sum. The real underlying work that is needed to be done to resolve medical indemnity issues remains undone, despite all of this—despite legislation. It is a perpetual Groundhog Day, where we talk about medical indemnity despite many growing old and grey puzzling over the issue. Despite hundreds of millions of dollars of Howard government expenditure, some things remain completely unaddresed and unfixed that could make a real difference.

One of those obviously is the question of quality control and the quality of care in our medical system. There is always going to be human error in any system that involves human beings, but most people in the medical area say that with a better focus on quality control we could limit medical misadventure, and that not only avoids human tragedies, death and disability but feeds into medical indemnity issues. The data in this area tends to be old, but it is the best we have. Data from 1999 shows that 16.6 per cent of the 14,000 hospital admissions in New South Wales and South Australia resulted in disability or a longer hospital stay than was necessary. The adverse events were due to ‘a wide range of human and system based failures’ and half of these adverse events were considered preventable. Similar data from the UK and USA shows that adverse events are at 10 per cent and 3.7 per cent respectively as a percentage of total admissions—not 16.6 per cent.

To draw a parallel with the airline industry which is often made: if one applied the UK rate of ‘misprescribing’ of antibiotics for respiratory infection to an equivalent error rate in flying planes, there would be a thousandfold increase in the risk in dying in a plane crash. Our rate is significantly worse than the UK rate. In those circumstances there clearly is major policy work to be done on quality and quality control across our health and medical system. That is not something that the Howard government has bothered itself with. The Howard government has also not bothered itself with structuring a system to deal with people who have long-term care costs from having sustained a catastrophic injury. The issue of caring for those people arises whether or not the cause of their catastrophic injury was medical misadventure or some other problem.

To conclude my remarks in this debate, can I say that the obvious new challenge in medical indemnity—one that the Howard government needs to face up to and one that flows from the patch-up jobs and the perpetual Groundhog Day that we have been through in this policy area—is a competitive neutrality issue of considerable consequence. In November 2004, news stories confirmed that UMP, the company that was going to go under, had reduced premiums. News of this caused outrage amongst other medical indemnity providers, who have not been subject to the same level of assistance from which UMP has benefited since it was bailed out. The circumstance now is that UMP members will enjoy premium reductions of up to 30 per cent a year. The Howard government has tipped out all these buckets of money to try to fix UMP. UMP is now offering its members premium reductions as a result of having been a beneficiary of these buckets of money and the other medical defence organisations are saying, ‘What about us? We did not get the same bucketload of money, so we cannot reduce premiums the way UMP is reducing premiums, and that raises a competitive neutrality issue because it obviously means we are disadvantaged in the marketplace when we go to doctors and say, “Buy your medical defence product from us, not from UMP.”’

Treasury is currently reviewing the competitive neutrality issues in the medical indemnity sector. Some medical indemnity providers have expressed concerns about competitive neutrality issues as a result of the way in which the government has provided assistance. Treasury’s inquiry will examine the competitive advantages in the medical indemnity industry arising from measures undertaken by the Australian government specifically to assist medical indemnity providers since 29 April 2002. This is an important review of an important issue. The review is supposed to be analysing the forms of government assistance and their interactions, assessing the implications for competitive neutrality and assessing what has happened with competitive advantages as a result. That assessment is going to extend to possible advantages such as savings on reinsurance or capital servicing costs. We look forward to that report, which is due on 15 March 2005—not many days from where we are now.

talk.start.para: —The ides of March.

—The ides of March, as I am reminded. Maybe there is some significance in that, but I am not exactly sure what in this context. We could be going on about Brutus and the like. But when that report is due we will be pressing the Howard government for its release and we will be pressing the Howard government for timely answers as to what will happen next in the medical indemnity debate so that we do not find ourselves here, sitting session after sitting session, yet again helping the Howard government dig itself out of its mess on medical indemnity issues.

—During her speech on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 the member for Lalor used words to the effect that it does not need to be like this—a prudent government would have got in first. Of course, we lacked an expert on what was going to happen, which she might have been in her previous life when she and the firm for which she worked were the cause of the problem. The reality was that, until the plaintiff lawyers got into ambulance-chasing, the prudential management of UMP and other medical indemnity providers was excellent. They had a long history of the sorts of claims with which they had to deal and it was only when the American disease arrived in this country that those indemnity organisations were unable to manage. Yes, this government should have rung her and her partners up at Slater and Gordon, or wherever it was, and said, ‘What are your plans for the future so we can be ready for it when you extract $20 million in a single claim?’ To this date, they have not told us how much the legal profession kept, but I think Premier Carr on one occasion suggested that it could be over 50 per cent.

speech.para: The reality is that this is a problem of ambulance-chasing. If we want any evidence of that, the tort reforms that have been implemented, the capping of some claims and the limiting of some claims have created a real problem—a crisis, in fact—for property developers. I read in the paper the other day that it is becoming very hard to collect the rent in bar chambers. The barristers have got no work because there has been a collapse in the market by tens of thousands of claims of this nature. We have got to look at the reality of the American disease which is fast approaching this country. As you go to the outpatients clinic on your way out after some medical process, you are confronted by people with clipboards who go through a checklist with you and, if you have missed anything under the contingency requirements, they offer on a no-cost basis to pursue an action for you.

Capping of claims and some of these reforms are not unique to Australia. Certain American states undertook this process some years ago and the percentage cost of delivering health care in those states is less as a consequence—not because of the payouts to the ambulance chasers but because medical practitioners feel they no longer have to protect themselves from this avaricious arrangement by prescribing every conceivable service by way of tests and other things to make sure, if at some future time a problem arises, they cannot be accused of not taking every opportunity of care. And, of course, the pathology clinics have been one of the greatest investments in history since that issue arose. The reality is that we are told by a practitioner in that field that we ought to have been ready for it. She knew we ought to have been ready for it, but there was no reason that the government of the day—and she mentioned Michael Wooldridge—should have had to have been involved.

The other issue that has got to be confronted in these matters is that old, old saying that there is no such thing as a free lunch. What we are talking about here is government having to spread across all taxpayers a cost that was relevant to the claims of a few and beyond the resources of medical practitioners. We remember well and truly the debate on bulk-billing. If ever there was an attack on bulk-billing, it was the massive increase in medical indemnity insurance policies. Of course medical practitioners had to increase their fees and of course the general public pay, as they are paying for what the government has been forced to do, to literally keep medical practitioners in business. It is ridiculous to say that the government got it wrong. The government did have to deal with a crisis—a crisis that was not evident until the ambulance chasers got into the business. In doing so, it has had to make adjustments over time. This legislation is further work in progress as to how we deal with various circumstances as issues arise.

I well remember drawing to the minister’s attention the great consideration that comes with the major aspects of this legislation as it refers to ROCS—the issue of people who have left the industry. This was a significant problem in my electorate where a very high percentage of locums who were servicing and giving some respite to single-person practices were coming from overseas. The AMA in Western Australia were great recruiters. They actually campaigned and offered this opportunity as a sort of a holiday in Western Australia where young practitioners from other parts of the world could give locum services and, in the process, see the country. Many were taking that opportunity but, as things stood originally, arguably in leaving the country they had to pay insurance premiums here in Australia for the next 20 years. That of course was unacceptable and in fact was drying up that particular opportunity.

This legislation has recognised the aspect of certain people—younger women and others—leaving the profession for the reasons that have been mentioned by the member for Lalor. As a consequence, it is better legislation. I am pleased that, by regulation, we have addressed the issue of locums from other countries operating around Australia and particularly in rural areas. There is nothing wrong with these measures. They do not warrant criticism, other than to say it is a great pity that they ever have to be implemented. I have spoken in this place before and attracted some criticism, but I am prepared to say again that I cannot understand how money can fix any sort of problem. The payment of money, as compensation for loss of income by a breadwinner in a family and things of that nature where negligence of whatever sort has prevailed, is of course quite proper, but in so many cases the suing of medical practitioners—particularly where a death was involved and the person concerned was not a breadwinner—in my mind is an unfair burden on the rest of society. None of these things allows for the materialisation of money. Somebody has to pay and, as we speak today on these measures, the Australian taxpayer will pay or will lose some other benefit.

The question is: how should we deal with medical negligence? Why does money absolve it? Why, in circumstances I think we will see less of today, should a medical practitioner stand up and say, ‘Yes, I was negligent, let the insurance company pay’? If they are negligent, why are they still practising? Either they are negligent or they are not. Negligence, particularly if it has happened more than once, should raise a question about their entitlement to practise. I can see the sense in that. But why does a bit of money fix it, and why should the wider community have to pay that money, as they do in every case, either through the fees they pay on a consultation or through the tax system? The only certainty is that if the government had not intervened in the way that it did most medical practitioners would have closed down.

If we think that the issue is lost in this regard, we should realise just how much difficulty this attack on the medical profession by plaintiff lawyers has caused. It is virtually impossible, outside a couple of the larger cities in my electorate, to get a local doctor to deliver a baby. I put forward a very interesting photograph to get more rural child-care assistance. The photograph was of two little kids—I think they were aged three and two—who were spending the entire day with their father in the cabin of a harvester, a header, because their mother was away in Perth to have her third child delivered. It could not be done locally. She could not be at home with the kids and hop in the car in the normal fashion and go into the local hospital to have the child delivered. They could not find medical practitioners who would pay the insurance premiums relative to what was once, if you like, bread and butter for a local practitioner. The first thing these doctors did was to deliver the local babies, many of whom can be delivered without any great risk. But you never know what the risk is now. The turnover of doctors, which again is heavily subsidised by local authorities and the local people, is such that they cannot expect to pay the sorts of premiums associated with one of the fundamentally more simple medical procedures in a high percentage of cases.

So I welcome this legislation. I congratulate the minister and the government on, as I say, work in progress as issues have arisen. I am quite interested in the reference of the member for Lalor to competitive neutrality. Of course that should apply. My briefing papers suggest that these days we are talking about medical indemnity insurers, MIIs, as those who are covered by these measures. In other words, it is not just UMP, although I well understand that there was originally a very substantial grant made to UMP to keep it afloat. I think these measures today deal with all practitioners, where they receive a subsidy when their premium costs exceed 7½ per cent of their revenue and where assistance is given to their insurer when claims exceed $300,000.

As I understand it, these matters today are not specific to UMP, notwithstanding that they were the first we had to save. So, again, the legislation has moved on. I will conclude my remarks at this stage, considering that other members need the opportunity to speak, but I repeat that the criticism from the member for Lalor is a bit like the pot calling the kettle black. She could have advised us soundly when she was still in the profession and did not bother to do so.

talk.start.para: —The medical indemnity insurance crisis has been emerging since the mid-1990s. The Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 before us today is yet another attempt to patch up a crisis that could well have been avoided. It is a crisis in which doctors have threatened to walk out of hospitals, and in some cases they have done exactly that. It is a crisis in which many doctors have seriously considered abandoning their professions. At a time in Australia’s history when highly skilled, professional doctors are so scarce, it would be a national tragedy if those doctors carried out those threats. But they were confronted with some chilling realities. One reality was that doctors who had spent so many years not only training for a basic medical degree at university but also training further to achieve the high levels of specialisation and skills that they possessed could be confronted with awful circumstances and therefore have to leave. It would have been a tragedy for our country if that had happened. Yet it was a very serious risk. It was not an idle threat. They were confronted with soaring medical indemnity insurance premiums and unconscionable risks to their own incomes not only as practising medical professionals but also in circumstances where they may have retired and a successful claim was lodged against them several years after their retirement for a procedure that they performed during their working life.

speech.para: The government, confronted with this crisis, has lurched from one stop-gap measure to another. This is in fact the fourth piece of legislation in which the government has sought another stop-gap measure to try to deal with a crisis that it could have avoided. One attempt by this government was to cover through legislation the circumstances where a doctor had subsequently left the work force, the circumstances that I have just described. This is called run-off cover. The definitions of run-off cover in previous bills have proved to be deficient. This bill attempts to rectify those deficiencies. We hope that this is the last time that legislation will be needed to do that. We will be supporting this legislation in the hope that it will prove to be effective.

I said that this legislation could have been avoided. Indeed, the entire medical indemnity insurance crisis was entirely avoidable. A responsible government would have seen this crisis coming. It did not need any powers of clairvoyance. It did not need to read the tea-leaves. All it needed to do was to read a report. It simply needed to read a report that was on the desk of the incoming health minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge, in March 1996. That report was prepared by Fiona Tito in response to concerns of the outgoing Labor government that this crisis was beginning to emerge. Yet again, we have a story of a Labor government understanding the development of a problem and seeking to act on it before it became a crisis. The government changed and the incoming minister ignored that report. To this day, we do not know fully the circumstances of his ignoring the report. We do not know whether he read the report and dismissed it or, alternatively, whether he failed to read it altogether. But we do know that the minister was entirely unrepentant. Indeed, he boasted of his failure to act on the medical indemnity insurance crisis, telling a conference at the University of Melbourne in 2003:

quote.para: ... I was accused of doing far too little on medical indemnity. That’s completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever.

speech.para: What a scandal that a health minister could be so proud of his wilful negligence, and what an irony when medical indemnity insurance issues can surround allegations of negligence. I certainly make the allegation of negligence against the then health minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge. At that conference at Melbourne University he pleaded guilty to negligence and boasted about it.

The consequences of the negligence of the Howard government in relation to the Tito report have been quite horrendous. This is the fourth piece of legislation, and the cost associated with those four pieces of legislation has run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Much of that government spending was entirely avoidable. It has also had horrendous human consequences and consequences for the viability of our health professionals and our highly skilled doctors. As in all aspects of health policy, prevention is far better and far cheaper than a cure. This government should have applied that philosophy in handling a crisis that it knew was emerging. It could have prevented that crisis; instead it has sought to cure the crisis through a series of bandaid measures.

There are issues of quality control in our public hospitals. Evidence has been presented that almost 17 per cent of procedures and admissions have gone wrong in some way or another at some state hospitals. Now there is a new challenge in relation to medical indemnity insurance, and it is the one to which the member for Lalor referred. It appears that UMP—the business that was about to go under—has in fact reduced its premiums after receiving huge financial support from the Howard government. That has put other insurers—competitors to UMP—in an invidious position. UMP stands to gain market share assisted by massive subsidies from the Commonwealth of Australia at the expense of insurance companies that adopted more prudent practices and were not the beneficiaries of such largesse from the government.

So much for the government’s commitment to competitive neutrality and national competition policy reforms. Fred Hilmer would be appalled at the government’s management of this issue. A report by Treasury has been scheduled for release, we understand, on 15 March—in just a couple of weeks time. The member for O’Connor said in his contribution to this debate just a moment ago that this legislation is further work in progress. That is a very ominous statement for the member for O’Connor to make. We will be interested to see what the Commonwealth does, in response to this report, about the very clear evidence that the principle of competitive neutrality has been violated by the government’s handling of the medical indemnity insurance crisis and by the financial support that it has provided to UMP. This is yet another example of the mismanagement of the Australian health system by the Howard government.

Many will recall that the previous coalition government that ruled from 1975 to 1983—a seven-year period—had seven different health policies in those seven years. The one commitment that the government had was to the dismantling of Medibank, the Labor creation of the previous period.

talk.start.para: —Medicare.

—It was Medibank, not Medicare. The government did indeed dismember Medibank, but it did not know what to put in its place so it made seven different decisions in seven years. It took the incoming Hawke government to address the situation where two million Australians were without insurance cover. Some of those Australians who then did get admitted to hospital had their hospital expenses covered by a benevolent hospital. But it is completely unacceptable in a modern society for two million Australians to be living without the knowledge that they have insurance cover against some bad health experience. Medicare, introduced by the Hawke government, ensured universal health insurance. Those two million Australians could breathe and live a bit more easily upon the election of the Hawke government.

speech.para: The trouble is that this government does not believe in Medicare. It does not believe in a public health insurance system. Indeed, the Prime Minister said just a couple of years ago that he recalls the health system that was in place—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on the grounds of relevance. I am not sure the history of the health system prior to medical indemnity dispute is relevant to the debate of the bill today.
(Mr McMullan)—The member for Bowman raises a point of relevance. The debate has ranged widely and continues to. I think it is within the parameters that are allowed, but I will continue to listen.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am talking about health insurance cover. I certainly would have expected the member for Bowman to understand that health insurance cover to Australians is entirely relevant to this debate because we are in fact discussing medical indemnity insurance, and I am speaking about the issue of health insurance cover more generally. I pointed out that in the period since this government has been elected the Prime Minister has not been committed to a national health insurance scheme. He in fact referred publicly, just some time ago, to the system that was in place before the introduction of Medibank, before 1972. The Prime Minister declared that he believed that to be a very good system, a system which did not provide health insurance cover for all Australians.

speech.para: So where to from here in respect of insurance and the provision of affordable quality health care to Australians? The health minister before the last election attacked Labor on the basis of assertions that Labor supported the pooled funding system for health care in Australia. He described it as a $60 billion behemoth. Yet, straight after the election, the health minister said that it would be a good idea if the states gave their hospital systems to the Commonwealth so that there would be a pool of Commonwealth funds covering both hospitals and aged care. The irony here is that this was the fundamental philosophy behind Medicare Gold—an arrangement where there would not be cost-shifting between the Commonwealth and the states in respect of health and aged care. At present, hospitals are a joint responsibility and aged care is a federal responsibility. There is an ongoing problem of cost-shifting as one level of government seeks to push patients into the care of another level of government.

The truth of the matter is that the health minister himself is advocating a pooled funding arrangement. Yet the Prime Minister has said: ‘No, it is not going to happen. There will be no transfer of hospitals to the Commonwealth.’ I understand why the Prime Minister would do that. Every day we see in the media reports of hospital waiting lists and the occasional horror story in hospitals. Probably the Prime Minister thinks it would not be a very clever idea for the Commonwealth to be taking responsibility for those adverse news stories. There is certainly a conflict over this between the Prime Minister and the health minister. I do note that the New South Wales Premier, Bob Carr, thought it was a pretty good idea to give the running of hospitals to the Commonwealth.

This has to be the most centralist government that the Australian people have experienced. The health minister says he wants to take over hospital cover, and we know what is happening with industrial relations and other areas. If it did happen, the Commonwealth could pool funds for hospitals and aged care. But in my view, if there were to be any sort of pooled funding model, there would need to be provision for copayments—that is, not copayments by those who lack the capacity to pay but by those who have the financial capacity to pay.

I refer to a model that is in practice in the United States, one of the more free enterprise nations on this earth. It is called Kaiser Permanente. In that model, which is an operating model, there is a pooling of funds to cover an integrated health care system that includes health promotion programs, prevention, early diagnosis, primary care, hospital care and aged care. The virtue of Kaiser Permanente is that there is always an incentive to seek the most cost-effective solution. We know that prevention is more cost-effective than cure. Indeed, the diseases that kill most Australians are largely preventable. In the land of free enterprise a pooled funding arrangement applies. Across the Tasman pooled funding arrangements apply; the New Zealand government has introduced a pooled funding system. That now covers more than 50 per cent of New Zealand citizens. Significantly, that New Zealand system does involve copayments.

An opportunity exists for the federal government—now that it has been re-elected and does not necessarily have to attack Labor with assertions that it was supportive of the pooled funding arrangement—to overhaul federal-state relations in relation to Australia’s health system. I call on the government to take on the reform mantle that is needed there. Although our health system is one of the very best in the world, we are confronted with the challenges of the ageing of the population. In 40 years time, if current projections turn out to be broadly correct, there will be four million more Australians over the age of 65. Four million more Australians over the age of 65 means a lot more health care and a lot more age care. It is at this moment that we should be looking at reforms of our health system to ensure they are sustainable; otherwise, through avoidable problems, health expenditure, including medical indemnity insurance, will become a big challenge and an enormous drain on our resources—absorbing resources that could be used instead to ensure that every young person in Australia has the same life chances, irrespective of whether they come from disadvantaged or wealthy backgrounds.

I will conclude by saying that we will support this legislation. The statements made by those on the government side that it is a work in progress are ominous. We have had four pieces of legislation already. We await the report from Treasury on competitive neutrality and we hope and pray that the next piece of legislation that comes into this parliament on medical indemnity insurance will be the last.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to support the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005, which makes modifications to a series of medical indemnity arrangements in this country. I am compelled to comment on the contributions from the members opposite, hopefully before the member for Rankin leaves. What has been demonstrated from both contributions is a staggering vacuum in fine details and proposals for what the opposition in government would have done with the medical indemnity crisis. What we have so far from two contributions is effectively drawing the Labor wagons into a circle, holding the Tito report above their heads with everyone else pointing at it and saying, ‘That’s what we would have done to fix the problem.’

speech.para: We know they had a penchant for asking for inquiries and reports, but it is an incredibly simplistic approach. We know that an enormous amount of those dues that accumulated under UMP did so between 1983 and 1996. I also suspect that a great proportion of the profession would be thankful it was our government on the watch at the time that a solution had to be found.

Today’s bill demonstrates responsiveness and communication with the profession in an incredibly difficult piece of indemnity legislation. Many of the health workers could really only imagine at the time this was happening that a solution could be found in the short term. UMP was representing 60 per cent of doctors. We were in crisis at that time. I remember the early nineties when we were already aware of that situation evolving but there was no solution to be found.

In response to this crisis the government has rolled out a series of measures to alleviate the upward pressure on insurance premiums and the unsustainable operating environment that insurers had to work within. I did not want to cast the first political stone in this debate, but for the shadow health spokesperson to comment that we were legislating, re-legislating and legislating again—‘patching up and bailing out’—and then to propose that the alternative was to simply focus more on quality in health care is, I think, overly simplistic. Every developed economy is focusing on quality in health care. We have a National Institute of Clinical Studies that does just that. An enormous amount of resources are committed by the federal government, and we are in step with what is happening in the US and the UK.

The comment that a possible alternative for the federal government was structuring the long-term care arrangements for those who are catastrophically injured again misunderstands that this crisis was inherently driven by a combined state and federal issue. We had the capping and the controlling of tort law reform being predominantly a state issue, yet with the federal government effectively wearing the problem. So, in this federalist environment, a solution was never going to be easy. It really did have to reach a point in the crisis where all players were motivated to act. I do not take this opportunity to criticise state governments. I think they made a reasonable effort across the board, in their own ways and in their own time, to find a solution to tort law reform.

Today I will touch briefly on the four areas where minor improvements have been made. We have already alluded to the run-off cover indemnity scheme. Let me give a background on that scheme. Traditionally, doctors were using a claims based approach and not an incurred based approach. We know that in insurance, once medical indemnity came under the Insurance Act 1973, they were expected to move to a claims incurred arrangement, which meant that the insurance had to cover not just events that occurred in the period with which one was insured but for long after. In medical indemnity, it is enormously difficult to predict how you have to set your premiums for events many years, if not decades, into the future. The agreement was to fall back to a claims based approach, to allow doctors to insure in that way; and for the government to step in—in this case the Commonwealth—with a run-off cover indemnity arrangement, where the government assisted and bore some of the responsibility for that long-term cover.

A doctor now with a claims based policy can leave practice and retire safe, knowing that that arrangement is in place. A doctor who is pregnant can leave with maternity leave and take care of her child and, as long as she is not practising, know that that cover is available. Finally, someone who is permanently disabled or suffers a major injury that prevents them from practising can also have that security. The Commonwealth also reimburses the medical indemnity providers for the costs of managing that run-off scheme. But keep in mind that the cost of that scheme is around 8.5 per cent—or, in UMP’s case, 9.5 per cent—of the cost of the total amount of the premium. It is a large amount. So what is changing? The eligible run-off claim for doctors who have some but not total cover means that they are now protected. If a doctor has coverage for obstetrics but carries out a gynaecological procedure, and down the track finds that they are not covered for that procedure, the run-off cover will protect them, so long as they had some level of insurance and were practising in a prudent manner.

In schedule 1, items 17 and 18 prevent double counting of that support payment. That is important so that this run-off scheme payment is not included in the premium outcome upon which that payment is calculated. That provides enormous reassurance to those who are leaving the profession, and particularly those who are retiring.

The High Cost Claims Scheme addresses an issue that has been of enormous concern to the medical profession. The solution found by the Commonwealth was that, for all claims over $300,000, the Commonwealth would assist with 50 per cent of the cost. That reduces the cost of insurers finding reinsurance. That exerts a downward pressure on insurance coverage because many of the insurers were having difficulty matching their level of reinsurance—the degree to which they go around and obtain secondary cover—with setting the level of their premium. This scheme will help enormously. It now gives insurers a 12-month waiting period after it is entered on the Federal Register of Legislative Instruments to apply any decrease in that percentage payable for an eligible high-cost claim. It effectively makes it easier for medical insurers. All of these amendments, small as they are, are bringing more closely into alignment the work of medical insurers with community practice.

Another change is to the Exceptional Claims Scheme. As I have already said, once medical indemnity fell under the Insurance Act 1973, medical indemnity cover provided to doctors contained a cap of $20 million or $25 million on the amount of damages that may be paid under the policy. Obviously some doctors realised they would be financially exposed if an award were to be made to a patient in excess of that amount. That put them in a difficult position of potentially being personally liable for certain amounts in a claim made against them. The Commonwealth has again stepped in and assumed liability for 100 per cent of those damages that exceed the doctors’ insurance cap.

How could an alternative approach from the opposition have made any difference to these issues? I really think it is enormously simplistic, if not a little vacuous, to say, ‘We called on Fiona Tito to write a report in the final, dying days of government,’ because there was no evidence that any progress was being made while the opposition were in power. It is overly simplistic today not to present a few alternative solutions, if the opposition are in fact so uncomfortable with some of the items and the legislation that has been developed throughout 2002, 2003 and 2004.

Technical changes have also been made to the Medical Indemnity Premium Subsidy Scheme—a scheme which I too hope to be eligible for in my clinical career. Where a doctor’s gross medical indemnity costs become so high that they exceed about 7.5 per cent of gross earnings, the Commonwealth again has a scheme so that, in particular, a procedural specialist only pays 20 cents in every dollar of the insurance over and above the 7.5 per cent. That has been enthusiastically welcomed by the profession. Of course, these premium subsidies are paid directly to medical indemnity providers and doctors receive premium subsidies automatically through reduced premiums from the insurer.

It should also be noted that the bill today modifies the functioning of this scheme slightly so that it is broadened to all medical indemnity providers and not just the well-known medical defence organisations. That is relevant for doctors who are often working in the public system. They too can be covered by this scheme.

Premium subsidies also apply to procedural general practitioners. Many of those GPs in rural areas were being forced out of procedural work—general practitioners were putting down the scalpel because the insurance premiums became completely unaffordable. Once again, the solution here was to say, ‘Let’s look at a similar GP doing non-procedural work in the same location who has the same insurer and we will insure 75 per cent of the difference between the procedural and the non-procedural GPs’ insurance premiums.’ Again, 10 years ago, when I was a remote and rural general practitioner, a solution like that was unheard of. This has been a significant contribution both from the Department of Health and Ageing and from the doctors with whom they have liaised and consulted.

Small changes have also been made to the incurred but not reported protocol, which is how one handles claims that are likely to be brought before an insurer but have not yet eventuated into a claim—they have merely been reported by the doctor. There will be changes to that so that insurers will be covered for claims of incidents that are notified to them and the costs that are borne by the insurer, even if they do not progress to a formal claim from an injured patient.

There was a comment today from a leading medical practitioner in Queensland who said that we had a lot to be grateful for in this legislation and that by and large the issue of medical indemnity had been sorted out. A comment like that from the medical profession was almost inconceivable four years ago. I know from what has happened in Redlands Hospital that the issue of medical indemnity has all but disappeared from the common rooms and coffee rooms of hospitals. Morale is higher in Redlands, in particular, which is a fine hospital. Redlands is waiting for an emergency department upgrade promised by the state government, which is coming soon. What are not appearing are the nine renal chairs that allow dialysis to be done in our area. That puts an enormous burden on the nearby Princess Alexandra Hospital and obviously upon a lot of annoyed renal patients.

The topic of indemnity has almost disappeared from hospitals and from practices around the country. It was once said—I am not quite sure by whom—that, like God’s infinite mercy, professionals should never really rely on government when it comes to sorting out indemnity issues, except as a last resort. That is exactly what happened in 2002. I was flying across the Gulf of Carpentaria when it happened, I recall. At that time there were no clearly understood solutions to the problem. It almost had to reach this stage in negotiation before all of the groups involved, including the state governments, could be brought to the table to have a summit. That is exactly what this government organised. I am thankful that that happened. It happened under the watch of a government that was able, willing and keen to strike a solution for the benefit of the profession. Announcements were made in December 2003, and all of those measures have now been implemented today. Consultation with doctors, of course, remains ongoing. It will have to—there will be further finessing. Again, it is overly simplistic to say that this has been a botched job, a patch job or a bailing out, because there was really no other way, and I am yet to hear from the opposition that there was any other way of handling this issue.

I am glad that the elements of the bill today will be working as they were intended. The small changes, many of them technical, some of them quite detailed, do just that. I congratulate not just the current Minister for Health and Ageing but also his predecessor, Minister Kay Patterson—and also Minister Helen Coonan for her work as Assistant Treasurer—on the work they have done in helping medical indemnity insurers, because they know, as we do, that by helping them we help doctors, which, in turn, helps patients.

talk.start.para: —Again, it is a pleasure to rise in the House to add my comments to the debate on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. This has been a long-running and sometimes terribly volatile issue in my electorate. Some 18 months before UMP collapsed, I had visits from my obstetrician, Dr John Curry, who came to tell me that there had been calls on the profession. He felt that there was going to be a disaster with UMP and needed to raise my awareness of this issue, which he did. We travelled to Canberra on numerous occasions and addressed backbenchers and committee meetings and pulled together meetings of backbenchers. Specifically, Dr Curry highlighted the issues he felt were going to happen, certainly with UMP. He felt that there was no money in the system and that the call was significant on the profession. He said that, unless somebody stepped in and did some work on tort law reform in the states, particularly in obstetrics areas, looked at the 21-year statute of limitations and at the way in which certain cases were playing out whereby compensation was being paid in the extreme, this was going to be a major issue that we would face as a nation. We did a lot of work on this matter. Many of my specialists came on board and explained that they thought there was a problem.

speech.para: Then we had a problem because there was no indemnity cover in the state hospital system, so all my specialists in the Riverina decided not to offer their operating services. I was involved at the time in the process of trying to resolve the issue with New South Wales Minister Craig Knowles. Finally, commonsense prevailed and the state government, to their great credit—and it is not often that I give credit to the state government—decided to pick up the indemnity in the public hospital systems for medical practitioners. It was very much appreciated by me and all of my medical specialists, GPs and others, because it certainly resolved the issue of getting cover in the public system. It stopped a mass exodus from the public system to the private system whereby we would have had an enormous gap in services that could and should be provided by the state hospital system. The issue was resolved at the eleventh hour on Christmas Eve. It was pretty significant and pretty hair-raising to think that, after the new year, no specialist services, operating services and visiting medical officer—VMO—services would be available in the state hospital system in my electorate.

We then moved to the UMP crisis—and what a crisis it was! It saw, very quickly, the mass exodus of specialists who had decided to retire, or who were thinking of retiring, in three to five years. They were insecure about what was going to happen in the future and not quite sure what was going to happen in their family lives and with the assets they had built up over a long period. We put in a lot of work and a lot of effort. Various crafts assisted me in trying to resolve this issue. One of my good general surgeons, Henry Hicks, was absolutely sensational. He, along with Dr Gerard Carroll, a heart physician in Wagga Wagga, and Dr John Curry, an obstetrician, assisted me in resolving this issue, particularly in my electorate. It seemed as though this matter was just going to escalate—and it did.

Obstetricians have one private outlet in the Riverina—that is, Calvary Hospital—and they decided to remove their services from that hospital. We have about 600 or 700 deliveries per annum in the private hospital and about 700 to 800 in the Wagga Wagga Base Hospital. It was obvious that the base hospital was not set up to take all the deliveries from right across the Riverina into their sector, and we had a crisis. Two thousand members of the community—mums and dads with prams and babies—marched up the streets of Wagga Wagga to demonstrate that they needed this facility at Calvary Maternity Hospital and that we in the government desperately needed to resolve the issue. There was a significant amount of discussion and negotiation, as a former speaker has said, by ministers and the Assistant Treasurer at the time, and we ended up resolving the problem in the short term.

We then introduced a levy system and, of course, some anomalies started to develop in that system. We saw new entrants coming in. One of the surgeons in my electorate, Dr David Littlejohn, was a new entrant in the system, and it seemed that he was going to have to pick up the tail and pay for the mistakes of people before him. That, of course, needed resolving. This issue has been a moving feast for ministers, because every day there was a new and extremely significant issue that they had to deal with and try to resolve. The Australian public were beside themselves because they thought there was every chance that they were going to lose their services. It certainly did have a major impact, particularly on obstetrics. We saw many of the obstetricians in my electorate move out of obstetrics entirely and into the field of gynaecology to reduce their premiums. This left a great shortfall in obstetrics services, not just in my electorate but right across Australia.

In what I think is its absolutely best performance to date, in an effort to underpin services right across Australia, the government has had to deal with a moving feast of variable issues that were surrounding things that governments had not previously been involved in. It did not just involve obstetricians, orthopaedics or surgeons; it also involved anaesthetists. A host of different specialists had been impacted upon by the very difficult circumstances with United Medical Protection. So I congratulate the government on all the processes it undertook to ensure that everybody’s interests were served—not just those of specialists, GPs, obstetricians and surgeons, but also those of all Australians.

Some positives have grown out of this. There are some positive advantages in what has happened. After we had the march in 2000 up the streets of Wagga Wagga, we developed a new program called the rural obstetrics training network. I sat down and thought that if the UMP issue was going to cause such a crisis in my region, what were we going to do to stop people from being discouraged from entering obstetrics because of the 21-year statute of limitations? I decided to work with a group of specialists to determine how we could deliver obstetric services into the future in rural and regional areas. From that came the birth of the rural obstetrics training network and we now have a very good pilot project operating out of Wagga Wagga which is looking at how we deliver obstetric services for rural and regional people into the future. It utilises midwives and a whole host of different mechanisms that need to come into play in before and after care in obstetrics services.

I am very proud of this. Dr Ian Stewart is a practising obstetrician and gynaecologist. He has now reduced his hours to part-time gynaecology in order to take on the directorship of the rural obstetrics training network. In my opinion, nobody has more experience in the needs of rural obstetrics than Dr Ian Stewart, and he has been prepared to forgo his own monetary benefit to ensure that he can put together a valuable project that can be applied anywhere in Australia. The project will ensure that we are best utilising the service of midwives and it will encompass regional universities such as Charles Sturt University, which has a magnificent nursing and midwifery course. It will put a process together to provide a different form of delivery of service for those people who are removed from many of the major areas of delivery. At one stage, we thought we would have to airlift mums to Sydney or to a metropolitan hospital just to have simple, straightforward procedural deliveries, which would certainly not have been a good use of taxpayers’ money.

As I said, this is a long-running issue that I have been absolutely involved with, well and truly before the problems with UMP, simply because of the understanding that the specialists that work in my area had to be involved as part of the solution and not just as part of the problem. I am very fortunate to have each and every one of the specialists in my area. We have recruited specialist services due to all of these guys putting in together and utilising their own money, their own time and their own travel to get other specialist services into the Riverina. The average age of specialists in the Riverina now is between 40 and 45, which is absolutely sensational. We have one of the best medical work forces in specialty services. We are certainly lacking in some areas but the Riverina is starting to be well supplied with specialist services. The government has assisted the Riverina in many, many ways to ensure that specialists remain committed and have the incentive to move forward and to be able to continue to offer these services into the future.

In other positive news in my region, according to a recent newspaper article Cootamundra is also benefiting from an increase in professionals who are providing obstetric and maternity care. This is fantastic because, while most regions are seeing a reduction in these services, I am starting see a significant increase, mainly due to the commitment of the existing specialists there. The article in the Cootamundra Herald on 2 March 2005 states that two new midwives, and a new general practitioner with an interest in obstetrics, have moved into the town of Cootamundra. The report says: ‘We have been short of midwives for a long time and Cootamundra is very lucky. Not only do we have the two new midwives but we have a new doctor in Dr Scholz.’ Scholz is a significant name because Granny Scholz delivered Sir Donald Bradman in Cootamundra and now Dr Scholz is there providing obstetric services.

Now that I have finished making conversation in the House, I am pleased to congratulate the government on the very fine effort that they have put in and in particular I congratulate the Minister for Health and Ageing on the services that he has secured for rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to sum up the second reading debate on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 and I would like to thank all members who have taken part. I would particularly like to thank the member for Riverina for a very interesting tour de horizon of the medical services available in her electorate. I am not entirely unfamiliar with them, having visited a couple of times and also having pedalled through a large slab of her electorate in company with, amongst others, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. It is good to see the medical services of the Riverina appropriately eulogised in this place by a very hardworking local member.

speech.para: Eighteen months ago there was a genuine crisis in our health system. A large number of visiting medical officers were resigning their public hospital positions because they believed that medical indemnity premium increases were the last straw. They believed that they were being hit with unconscionable burdens as a result of changes to the tort culture, particularly in New South Wales but also in Queensland and in other states. As a result the government established the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel comprising a series of distinguished leaders of the medical profession, along with John Phillips, former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank; Nancy Milne, the insurance partner at Clayton Utz; and the then Minister for Revenue, Senator Coonan and me as co-chairs. But the key people on this review panel were Dr Bill Glasson, the President of the AMA; Dr Andrew Pesce, the insurance expert on the AMA; Dr Sue Page, President of the Rural Doctors Association of Australia, and Professor Don Sheldon, Chairman of the Council of Procedural Specialists. That committee spent a very intensive six to eight weeks looking at the problem and coming up with a series of recommendations which were ultimately accepted, almost in total, by the government just before Christmas in 2003—and which, I am pleased to say, have brought stability to this sector since.

I do not say that it is a perfect system and I do not say that it will not be in need of further work in the future, but certainly the crisis has passed. The medical specialists rescinded their resignations, our hospitals began to work normally again and the Damoclean sword hanging over them was withdrawn. This was very good news for the people of Australia but it was particularly good news for the standing and public respect of the medical profession. Every one of us in this place owes a great deal to the medical profession. None of us enjoys perfect health all the time, and invariably when ill health strikes it is the medical profession which takes the lead role in restoring us to health.

While many doctors earn large incomes, the vast majority of them carry very heavy responsibilities, work very long hours and earn comparatively modest rewards for the training, dedication and time that they bring to their jobs. It is right that we as a society do not impose unduly heavy burdens on them. Thanks to the Medical Indemnity Subsidy Scheme, finalised by the government as a result of the work of the review panel, doctors who face very high premium costs will have 80 per cent of those premium costs—above 7½ per cent of gross private medical income—met by the government. That is the essence of the scheme put in place by this government to meet the crisis, but there are other important elements: the ‘blue sky scheme’ to cover doctors who face claims in excess of $20 million; the High Cost Claims Scheme to cover doctors who faced claims in excess of $300,000; and the very important retirement Run-off Cover Scheme to cover doctors who had retired from practice but who still faced the possibility of claims as a result of the long tails on these sorts of actions.

As I said, it has not been an absolutely perfect set of arrangements. Obviously it has cost the taxpayers of Australia heavily. The package put in place after the review panel did its work cost an additional $200 million over the forward estimates period on top of about $350 million that had previously been invested by the government in medical indemnity insurance premium support. But the package has worked well and this legislation is designed to clear up technical difficulties which have arisen in the operation of the scheme. In particular, we have tried to ensure that the legislation precisely matches the intent of the government back in December 2003 and that it precisely matches the practical operation of insurance schemes of this type.

The legislation is highly complex and technical but it has been drawn up in the closest possible consultation with the insurance sector and expert members of the medical profession. I know that the legislation has the support of the medical profession and the medical indemnity insurance sector. I know that it is in the best interests of patients that we should pass this bill and I particularly thank the opposition for being as constructive as they have been on this whole issue.

Before closing, I should also thank the public servants of my department, who have toiled mightily over this issue for the last two or three years. We tend to take the Public Service for granted—and certainly the general public often talk dismissively of Canberra as if it were a paradise of overpaid and underworked public servants and people such as ourselves—but the fact is that the Public Service of Australia always get the job done. Sometimes, as our experience grows, what they do needs to be finetuned and further improved, but they always get the job done. In my experience as Minister for Health and Ageing there has been no finer illustration of the Public Service at its best than the work that the Department of Health and Ageing did to resolve this very acute, very pressing and very serious problem. So I thank and congratulate them on behalf of the government and the people of Australia. I particularly single out Charles Maskell-Knight, who is in the advisers’ box this evening and led the team which did such a good job. Thank you very much indeed.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 February, on motion by Mr Truss:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will support the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 through this parliament. The bill seeks to reinforce the structural adjustment focus of the Farm Help program by tightening the definition of ‘full-time’ farmer and by providing the ongoing monitoring of those who have accessed the re-establishment grant, to ensure that they do not go back into farming.

speech.para: In June 2004, some eight months ago, I debated legislation to extend the Farm Help program to 30 June 2008. The opposition has been broadly supportive of the thrust of this element of the Agriculture Advancing Australia package. This program forms part of the government’s Agriculture Advancing Australia package and is aimed at supporting the ongoing process of structural adjustment in the rural sector. However, if the number of farms accessing this program is supposed to be an indication of the success or otherwise of the program, then the statistics would seem to indicate that it has been a failure. Farm organisations regard this program as largely having failed to meet its objectives, and, on the government’s own stated objectives, it has failed badly. On that basis, I move:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for the failure of Farm Help and other programs to deliver appropriate structural adjustment assistance where it is needed in the farm sector”.

speech.para: Farm Help has been operating since December 1997 to facilitate adjustment by providing assistance to people on farms in severe financial difficulty. Program components include up to 12 months of income support at the newstart allowance rate, up to $5,500 in professional advice and training, the development of an activity plan customised to each farm family situation and a re-establishment grant of up to $50,000 for those who decide to exit farming. The Farm Help program was renewed in the 2004-05 budget for a further four years and will conclude on 30 June 2007.

The farm exit provisions of this program have been the centrepiece of the government’s structural adjustment efforts in the farm sector. But in most years the program has been significantly underspent. While the amendments proposed represent an improvement on the current situation, particularly in terms of accountability for assistance received, they will do little to encourage an increasing number of marginal farmers to exit farming.

The main elements of this bill are that it will amend the definition of a farmer as ‘a person who has a right or an interest in land used for the purposes of a farm enterprise’ and that it will define a ‘full-time’ farmer, for the purposes of the Farm Help provisions of the bill, as a person who, for a continuous period of at least two years immediately before they apply for entry to the Farm Help program, is a farmer, has derived more than 50 per cent of his or her gross income from the farm enterprise, has contributed more than 50 per cent of his or her capital to the farm enterprise and has spent more than 50 per cent of his or her working hours on the farm enterprise.

The bill will also provide a greater degree of flexibility in administration. For example, a person may be unable to satisfy the income test because, during the two-year period, the enterprise has experienced flood, drought, bushfire or some other natural disaster; an unforeseen extreme variation in seasonal norms; a market collapse; or serious illness or disability. Accordingly, a person is considered to be a full-time farmer if they can demonstrate that they meet these circumstances and other qualification criteria. Of course, there is another provision of the bill to enable ongoing communication with Farm Help re-establishment grant recipients. This provision basically allows for the tracking by Centrelink of people who have received assistance under these provisions.

One has to ask why these matters have not been adequately addressed by the government before this time. It is quite extraordinary that here we are some seven years after the introduction of the scheme, and the government is still grappling with the definition of a farmer and a full-time farmer. I think it demonstrates the sort of tardiness in the preparation of legislation and the administration of schemes that is typical of a government in terminal decay, as is this one.

The government introduced the scheme in December 1997. One has to ask where the minister has been since that time in tightening up the provisions of this particular legislation. At least, I suppose, some seven years down the line we are finally getting some certainty into these definitions. Of course, in doing so, the minister simply demonstrates once again his incompetence in this portfolio.

The process of structural adjustment in farming has produced mammoth changes in our agricultural sector. Of course, this is what this particular legislation is designed to address. I have, on more than one occasion in this place, referred to the impact that it has had on my own farming family, who farmed a small, mixed dairy farm in the western district of Victoria some four decades ago. That process has produced quite profound social changes in rural communities, often with great pain to families who were farming and who, in a historical sense, have farmed as a lifestyle choice as well as a means of earning a living and supporting a family.

The process of structural adjustment has been propelled by a range of factors. In Australian agriculture in recent decades, we have witnessed quite consistent growth in the annual productivity of the sector of between one and two per cent. This has been driven by massive investments in technology on the farm, land productivity improvements, huge strides in plant and animal genetics, the decisions of government to remove the regulatory framework under which industries have operated for long periods of time, an expansion of market opportunities, the upskilling of farmers, the introduction of new management and information systems, some improvements in essential infrastructure and, of course, significant gains from a concerted research and development effort in the sector. Together these have driven the creation of new opportunities and new efficiencies in Australian agriculture. They have also, however, contributed to the massive structural adjustment in the sector that has occurred in recent decades.

Other influences have contributed to the process as well. Climatic changes, such as the recent drought, have put enormous pressure on the financial viability of many farm enterprises in affected areas, with corresponding pressures on businesses and local communities. The overall issue of climate change and the potential impact it might have on the farm sector are the subject of considerable debate in the general community and in farming circles today. That certainly was not a debate that was taking place with any intensity some five years ago, but of course it is upfront and centre in the considerations of farmers and their leaders today.

I have taken the view in that debate that the sector must look to innovative opportunities and not simply wallow in the negative aspects about the extent of the sector’s contribution to the problem. The reality is that managing this problem and related problems, such as the increased incidence of pests and disease, may well be beyond the management skills of many farmers in some prone areas, forcing the pace of structural adjustment even faster.

Similarly, the changing nature of consumer preferences in how they buy and consume the output of the sector has dictated changes in the structure and will do so in the future. Consumers can be very fickle indeed in changing their preferences and having their needs and wants met, and sometimes the resources in agriculture are not flexible. Some industries, such as the stone fruit industry, require significant time frames for adjustments to occur and significant investments to meet new consumer demands, so the process of adjustment for many in the farm sector is a difficult one indeed.

Likewise, the changing nature of the domestic and the international marketplace and the dominance of huge retailers are putting significant pressures back on farm. These changes are eloquently outlined by Mick Keogh, the Executive Director of the Australian Farm Institute, in a perceptive article in the February 2005 edition of the Farm Policy Journal, entitled ‘The industrialisation of Australian farming’. He refers to the fact that this process of industrialisation appears to be rapidly developing in agriculture. I forgot to bring that article with me today to quote from it in this debate, and I regret that because it is an excellent article. It is very perceptive and very detailed, and I think it makes very important reading not only for farmers but for those in agribusiness and those who have an interest in the process of structural change in the sector.

Farm structures have adapted to accommodate these new arrangements. Keogh refers to the emergence of large-scale corporate farms. They have emerged and they are highly integrated into current food marketing systems, with direct contractual arrangements between those large corporate enterprises and large retailers that literally bypass traditional marketing systems. Keogh provides a very comprehensive analysis of the nature of these new marketing arrangements and the impact that they are having on the contractual relationships in the agricultural sector, on intellectual property rights and on patterns of trade.

In the face of these particular changes I think Australian agriculture has shown remarkable resilience, but there are even more economic changes bearing down upon the sector as we speak. We are going to see further structural adjustment in this sector as a result of the rising interest rates under the Howard government. It is now a matter for the public record that the Prime Minister and the Howard government have deceived farmers, as they deceived other Australian households and businesses before the last election, on the matter of interest rate rises in the future. The Prime Minister is in his usual pattern of doublespeak on this matter in what I consider to be a pathetic defence of his deception.

The economic framework has direct relevance to the pace of structural adjustment in the rural sector, and it is that issue of structural adjustment that is the focus of this particular piece of legislation before the House. Before the last election the Prime Minister led farmers to believe that interest rates would not rise.
