The Reserve Bank has recently increased them by 0.25 basis points, and it would appear there are more rises in the pipeline. What is the impact of this on the farm sector? I refer to a press release by the National Farmers Federation on 2 March 2005 where they have analysed the quantum of the impact that that is likely to have. Mr Charles Burke, the Farm Business and Economics Committee chair, had this to say:

quote.para: Around 10 per cent of total farm cash costs go towards servicing average debt levels of about $370,000 per farm.
This means that today’s move by the RBA will cost Australian farmers another $120 million a year and squeeze margins which are already under pressure from high exchange rates and high fuel costs.

speech.para: Here we have the triple whammy: the rise in interest rates, courtesy of the Howard government, which is adding $120 million to farm costs; a squeeze on margins which are already under pressure from a high exchange rate, which in part is due to the policies of the Howard government; and, of course, high fuel costs, which in part are a result of this government’s involvement in the Iraq conflict. So in a whole raft of economic policy areas we have a direct pressure on farm costs and on farm adjustment—which is the subject of this particular bill—as a result of the policies of the Howard government. Mr Burke went a little further. He said:

quote.para: The rate rise also comes on top of one of Australia’s worst trade performances on record. The Current Account Deficit has hit $15.2 billion or 6.5 per cent of GDP.

speech.para: I think that is perhaps a little bit on the light side. But it is the impact of our trade performance on exchange rates and on rural exporters that he goes on to analyse. He says:

quote.para: Higher interest rates will push the exchange rate higher, damaging exporters and fuelling more imports.

speech.para: He further concludes:

quote.para: We need to boost exports to address the record current account which means that ideally, our interest rates should be falling relative to our major trading partners.

speech.para: As we know, Australian interest rates are at decidedly higher levels than those of our trading partners. The high interest rate regime in Australia is fuelling the pressure on the exchange rate and this, in turn, is damaging farmers as significant exporters in this country. The foreign account relies very heavily on the input of the farm sector as far as earning national income goes in the international marketplace.

So here we have, as a result of the Howard government’s policies, a double whammy coming to farmers. Courtesy of the Howard government’s economic policies, we have a rise in interest rates which is adding to farm costs to the tune of $120 million on this occasion—and that is not taking into account the massive increase in costs that has occurred as a result of interest rate rises that had already occurred courtesy of this government. I would say that, just as a rough rule of thumb, the interest rate rises courtesy of the Howard government have added some half a billion dollars or more to farm costs, and that is not an insignificant amount. And then, of course, as this feeds into the higher exchange rate, farmers as exporters are penalised. Their income is reduced from their exports into the international marketplace. So there is a squeeze on their incomes, their costs increase and their financial viability is further threatened.

I am very interested in the interest rate debate because we know that the Prime Minister is apt to get up in this parliament and talk about high interest rates under Labor. But of course he conveniently forgets that when he was Treasurer of this country not only did he leave us with a deficit, which in current dollars would be the equivalent of $30 billion, but he presided over interest rates to businesses of 15.8 per cent. And the Prime Minister has the gall to get up in this parliament and criticise the Labor Party for high interest rates. One thing that we did do, something which really assisted farmers to cope with this issue of structural adjustment, was break the back of Liberal inflation in this country—the double-digit inflation that prevailed when the Liberal Party was in power under the Prime Minister’s stewardship as Treasurer. We broke the back of Liberal inflation. We set the basis for the low interest rate regime that this country now enjoys. So the issue of the total economic performance of the country is very important to this process of structural adjustment and it is very important to the issues we are debating here today in this legislation.

I go to the statistics that relate to the Farm Help Re-establishment Grants Scheme. We have seen that the number of exits under the legislation has not been of any substance since the year 2000. For example, in 2000-01 there were 182 re-establishment grants. In the next two financial years, 2001-02 and 2002-03, there were 161 in each of those years. It further declined in 2003-04 to 102 re-establishment grants. We can go to various industry reform packages that the government has introduced since it has been in office. If we look at the Sugar Industry Reform Program, for which funding of some $94 million was made available over the years 2004-05 to 2006-07 for re-establishment assistance, we find that, as at 4 March 2005, 82 growers had accessed re-establishment grants under that industry reform package for 2004-05. That is not a lot, given the noises that the government was making about the need to encourage many sugar farmers to exit the industry because of the economic challenges it faced.

With the Pork Producers Exit Program, the government and the minister’s estimated target was 140 producers, but only 74 have received pork producer exit grants. We see a similar situation occurring in the Dairy Exit Program where Centrelink have advised that there have been approximately 138 grants awarded under that program. So it is hardly a massive structural adjustment tool. It is no wonder that many in the farm sector have been very critical of the government for its administration of this particular piece of legislation.

If we go to the National Farmers Federation submission to the review of Agriculture Advancing Australia, we see that very little has been done by the government to address their concerns in this matter. For example, the National Farmers submission said:

quote.para: Farmhelp and similar exit programs should provide incentives for farmers considering retirement or industry exit to link with young individuals pursuing industry entry, therefore facilitating and accelerating the generational transfer of viable farm businesses;

speech.para: Nothing has been done on that particular request. The submission also said:

quote.para: The Retraining Grant and the entire Professional Support components of Farmhelp should be available to farmers prior to them making their final decision on exiting the industry (through taking the Re-establishment Grant), therefore providing additional confidence and guidance to farmers in considering their future options;

speech.para: This is one that has been done. But then, further down in the submission, National Farmers suggested that Farm Help:

quote.para: Introduce flexible measures to allow support to continue beyond the first 12-months in circumstances where farm exit maybe inadvertently delayed (ie: problems in selling property etc) or where an assessment of farm viability may take longer than this period;

speech.para: On that sensible suggestion, nothing has been done. The National Farmers also state:

quote.para: In lieu of a bank statement documenting a farmer’s credit rating, allow Rural Financial Counsellors to certify the legitimacy of an individual farmer’s Farmhelp Application.

speech.para: We know that in this provision accountants can now certify, but the request of the National Farmers Federation to extend this certification to rural financial counsellors has not been granted. There is another particular request that was made by the National Farmers Federation:

quote.para: Increase the net assets threshold for the re-establishment to $150,000 therefore enhancing the financial capacity of farm families to successfully re-establish following exit and reduce the likelihood such individuals will require ongoing welfare support following exit.

speech.para: Nothing has been done. The problem in this particular area is getting worse as asset values rise. I mention this because although we have some definitional tinkering in this piece of legislation, the substance of what farmers require from it has not been addressed by the government. We will be supporting this particular legislation through the parliament but I think it is now a matter of public record that farm organisations are very disappointed in the administration of this area of policy by this minister and by the government.

talk.start.para: (Mr Baldwin)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, of course I am opposed to the amendment, but I will speak to what has just been outlined by the member for Corio, which is the opposition’s inability to grasp the importance of this Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 as it affects farmers, particularly in the electorate of McMillan. More importantly, through the whole of a 30-minute address the member for Corio did not mention one positive statement about what the opposition would do if it were in government. In fact the member for Corio seems very comfortable in opposition. He said that the opposition is broadly supportive of the government’s programs. From the list of positives he read out about the government’s programs, I would say that the opposition is totally acquiescent to the government’s programs, particularly with regard to agriculture. Would the member for Corio, if he were the minister, do anything different from what is being done by this government? I suggest not. Throughout his address he was positive about the government’s programs. He said that the opposition supports what the government is doing and that the only massive readjustment program was Paul Keating’s interest rate regime of 17 to 22½ per cent. That is what changed the industry forever and did so much damage.

speech.para: I want to refer to the member for Corio’s address because he did mention one article. I mention another, a very positive article that I will not have time to address. On the Insiders program on Sunday morning there was a woman involved in agriculture, and particularly chemicals, who spoke to the nation through the program about interest rates and how they affect the farming community and the fact that good farmers factor in the range in which interest rates may climb or fall in a given time. Where is the difference between the government and the opposition on interest rates? The range under the Howard government has been between six and eight per cent—rises, drops. Under Labor, interest rates moved between 10 and 17 per cent. So I would not like to take the member for Corio’s figuring on his cost to agriculture to this point and then add what it would cost the farming community of Australia under Labor if we were moving between 10 and 17 per cent.

However, enough about what the member for Corio has said, because he did not outline where he had a problem with this legislation. We will be positive. This bill is of importance to the seat of McMillan because McMillan is dependent on agriculture, with the dairy industry at its heart. Reconstruction and deregulation of the industry have required greater efficiencies with fewer farmers milking more cows and producing more milk. Our dairy industry in Victoria now supplies 63 per cent of Australia’s milk production. Further efficiencies, though, are inhibited by a number of measures—and, as the member for Corio mentioned, we have just come out of a prolonged drought. We have a shortage of labour and now in many areas an increase in the cost of land affects the opportunities for neighbouring farmers to buy the land at a reasonable price for viable milk production. The bill may help free up some land by helping farmers on unviable small holdings to take the opportunity to exit the industry.

I am reminded today of the mendacity of the member for Corio as he stepped between the cow pats of the dairy herds in McMillan where he made an offer to local farmers to turn back the clock to 1950. He had a range of statements that he made only in McMillan. They did not go out of McMillan because he did not want to spread the news outside the local papers. He got tremendous coverage. He was all over the place. He really led some people to believe that he had the magic pudding in the back of his car for the dairy industry of Australia. But he was misleading the farmers and the people. We have the leaders of Fonterra and other industry leaders saying, ‘We have a great opportunity now to move forward with our dairy industry because of its efficiency and quality.’ But we will never be able to supply the markets that are available to us and we will always be looking for new people to come into the industry. How can we do that?

This legislation is particularly important to the farmers, particularly dairy farmers, in McMillan because of the dominant role that dairy plays in the total economy of my electorate. Indeed, McMillan is only one of a small number of federal electorates in which primary industry plays such a dominant role. The agricultural sector in the seat of McMillan is dominated by the dairy industry, which accounts for almost half of the total farming in the electorate and makes a significant contribution to the state and national economies. McMillan also boasts a beef cattle industry and a range of smaller agricultural and horticultural sectors, all of which are important contributors to the local economy.

The dairy industry in McMillan is emerging from several years of dry conditions which have had a serious impact on both farm production and employment—and farm families. Despite these leaner years, it continues to make a major contribution to our local economy. Over 1.2 billion litres of milk annually, almost a fifth of Victoria’s total production, comes out of the seat of McMillan. This is a sizeable contribution to the Victorian economy, with the dairy industry accounting for more than $3 billion in domestic sales and more than $2 billion in export sales. These sorts of figures can only be achieved by an industry that is continually striving for greater excellence. The dairy industry has gone through massive reconstruction over the past 30 years. Coming from a dairying community, I have lived with those changes for most of my life, with the greatest reform, outside of the high-interest years of the Hawke-Keating government, coming from deregulation five years ago.

Since the 1970s the number of dairy farms has been reduced by more than 50 per cent, while herd numbers and production have increased, so there are fewer farmers milking more cows and using greatly improved management processes. It is the desire of this House and the government that this momentum be maintained. We have to help the industry by creating an environment that makes it possible for the dairy industry to further improve all its management and ways. At the moment global demand for dairy products far outstrips production and, as the world’s fourth largest exporter, Australia appears well placed to capitalise on this demand, and the dairy farmers in the seat of McMillan will be best placed of those across the nation to capitalise on this opportunity.

In the short time I have today, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, I want to refer to some of the environmental programs that local farmers are putting in place in McMillan. Outside of those that are well known to you—the sustainable farms program, Landcare programs and other programs—56 per cent of our dairy farmers have been involved in property revegetation, 64 per cent of our dairy farmers have some remnant vegetation on their properly and 57 per cent of our dairy farmers with waterways have all or most of them fenced off from livestock. Eighty cent of our farmers have formal effluent management systems, and there is potential for a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions through reducing or using the methane gas emitted by cattle, though improved management of organic matter, fertilisers and irrigated pastures will be of importance as the industry moves forward. The opportunity to grow the dairy industry in Australia is before us now. I believe that the opposition is supportive of this bill. I believe that this is an opportunity for us—and I know that you have dairy farmers in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker—to show that these people are our future and that dairy will be a part of Australia’s future and a part of Australia’s growth and export opportunity.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 as tabled by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. This bill reinforces the structural adjustment focus of the Farm Help—Supporting Families Through Change program. Farm Help is a program that has been operating since 1997 to provide support to people on farms in severe financial difficulty. Since the program commenced, over 9,000 farmers have received income support and some 8,000 have received advice and training, while over a thousand have received assistance to re-establish themselves outside the farming sector. The government has spent over $187 million on the Farm Help program to date. It has done this because it recognises not only the monetary value of the sector to the Australian economy but also the value that our rural heritage and community bring to Australia as a nation. It also recognises that, while ‘structural adjustment’ is a nice succinct academic term, at the end of the day it is real families who are affected by the process and these people deserve our support.

speech.para: Because Australia is a net exporter of agricultural produce, which has traditionally formed a large part of Australia’s economic base, there has been investment in the sector over many years. My father, Dr Bob Fawcett, played a key role in this over his working life, developing new technologies and practices for reduced tillage and dryland farming. Increasing sophistication in farm management, meteorological forecasting, market analysis and an ongoing focus on sustainable land use have increased the potential value of the primary production sector. Despite these advances, those involved are still vulnerable due to factors which are beyond their control. Key amongst these factors are such things as export conditions—the exchange rate, markets, competition, the yields and prices and the vagaries of weather—long-term droughts and even short-term events such as cyclones or a late rain. My family has been affected by this, with some members farming north of the Goyder’s line in marginal areas where one year in five they are lucky to get a good return on their crops. Others have suffered the changes that have made their small holdings unviable and forced them to move off the land.

Farmers whom I represent in Wakefield are prime examples of some of these factors. This year they had a growing concern about the expected yield of cereal crops due to a very late break in the season. When rains did come, many became optimistic that, despite the late start, crops were looking very good. But the unseasonably dry and windy conditions on 12 and 13 October caused significant moisture loss from crops approaching harvest. This led to crop losses and to yield estimates falling by up to 30 per cent in many areas. In some areas, farmers failed to even get their seed back, which represented a significant unexpected loss to their farm businesses given the large investment in fuel, time, herbicides and fertiliser expended in anticipation of at least some return. As well the resulting poor harvest now means a downturn for local business, who were hoping for an ongoing investment in farm infrastructure and machinery maintenance or upgrades.

Farmers therefore may face not only the costs of long-term issues such as the compounding effects of land and stock degradation due to drought and the ongoing costs of living outside metropolitan areas but also these unexpected losses in income. At times like these they need support but also certainty—something that this bill will deliver. The government rightly has a focus on getting results for the people of Australia. Despite the comments of the member for Corio, the timely introduction of the Farm Help program is one example of where the government saw and responded to a need. The government also has an obligation to exercise good governance over taxpayers’ hard-earned money, which is why it maintains the Australian National Audit Office and is now responding to the mid-term evaluation report conducted by the Audit Office on this program.

The purpose of the amendments contained in this bill is to reinforce the structural adjustment focus of the program and, in doing so, to remove ambiguity about eligibility for assistance. It will do this through: defining a farmer as someone who has a right or an interest in land used for the purposes of farm enterprise; defining that a full-time farmer is one who, for a continuous period of at least two years immediately before applying for the assistance, can demonstrate that more than 50 per cent of their income, capital contributions and work time result from their role as a farmer; recognising that there may be circumstances where a genuine farmer does not in fact meet these criteria due to circumstances beyond their control, and so there is a discretion clause; and, lastly, putting in place penalty provisions to ensure the ongoing integrity of the program by enabling the departmental secretary to notify recipients of their obligation to inform Centrelink if they change their address or choose to re-enter farming within five years of being paid the grant.

My electorate of Wakefield has been blessed to not suffer some of the long-term drought issues affecting other parts of Australia, but, as a representative of an electorate with a large number of primary producers, I recognise the unique pressures faced by these enterprises and by the families who both enable and depend on them. I therefore welcome the renewing of the farm support program for four years as of the last budget and support these proposed amendments to strengthen the legislation which demonstrates this government’s commitment to this important sector of our community.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak in this very important debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005. The purpose of this bill is to bring forward amendments to the area of legislation related to the Farm Help program. This program has been running since 1997 and is widely supported by the farm organisations. When we need to make amendments to the program it is important that we do so with the support of the opposition, and I hope we receive that support.

speech.para: Due to the collapse in commodity prices or the unfair trade practices of other countries and the impact that they have on our farm sector, structural adjustment is something that goes on all of the time. As hard as we and our Minister for Trade, who tonight is on his way to China to negotiate the scoping parameters of a free trade agreement with China, fight in this place, international trade is not always fair. It certainly does not always have a level playing field. So often the impact of unfair trade in the international trading environment is felt by our farmers across Australia. But it is not only the unfair trade practices of some countries that impact on our farm sector; it is also drought. I want to touch on some of the ways extreme drought is impacting on the agricultural and pastoral sectors and on families in my electorate.

Since its inception in 1997, the Farm Help program has had tremendous support. An indication of that is the fact that some 9,000 farmers have sought support from this program since its introduction. I think that clearly demonstrates that this program is needed. Just those figures alone suggest the sort of magnitude of support that is going to farmers, and without this program there could well be 9,000 farm families put under even greater stress. Some 8,000 of those 9,000 farmers have received valuable advice and further training in business practices and some 1,000 have accessed the re-establishment grant of up to $50,000. I know from people in my own electorate that it is indeed a very painful process for so many farmers to have reached the point where they need to exit farming and receive that grant.

I want to touch on the issue of household support and how it is helping so many families. I mentioned earlier in my comments tonight that farmers are accessing this support, not just because of collapsing commodity prices but because of extreme drought. This government has been very supportive of our farm sector. I am pleased to see the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry enter the chamber. He knows only too well, as a former farmer himself and from his travels around Australia, how this exceptional drought—a once in 100 years event—is impacting on farm families.

In the west of my electorate people are now entering their fourth year of extreme drought. Only last week I was in western Queensland, in Longreach, speaking with representatives of Anglicare Central Queensland. They gave me a report of the impact that the exceptional drought is having on the families of this very vast region of central western Queensland. Their experience shows that most property owners are entering their fourth year of drought. They are down to about one-third of their viable stocking levels and their debt-to-equity levels are rising all the time. Notwithstanding that land prices have improved, the debt levels of families are rising faster than the value of their land. So, with the debt-to-equity level rising, families are finding it more difficult to continue to go to the bank and seek additional accommodation.

Anglicare pointed out their concern about the social effect that this drought is having on so many families. In their report to me they say that many women are an integral part of the property work force—if I could put it that way—because they are out there working with their husbands and their children, in some cases, just to keep the family business enterprise together. But some of these women have now gone to town to give their children access to education so that the women do not have to supervise their children’s education as they did when they were receiving lessons from the School of Distance Education. In other words, the women were being a governess as well as being that extra pair of hands on the drought-stricken property.

I was disturbed to receive this report from Anglicare. Among some of the references made to me by the drought coordinator for Anglicare Central Queensland were that many of the women in these families just simply cannot cope, as I mentioned earlier, with the role of being a mother, that extra pair of hands and teacher of their children who are being educated from home. The drought is taking a huge toll on these farm and property families and on their lives.

Anglicare in western Queensland are continuing to refer many men and women to the Royal Flying Doctor Service mental health unit and to other services—such is the stress that these families are under. The extremely high use of antidepressants is also a very worrying factor. One thing that the drought coordinator said to me was that not only women but more and more men are being referred by Anglicare to the Royal Flying Doctor Service mental health unit, which is based in Longreach.

That is why this program is so important. The Farm Help amendments before the House tonight are supporting those families who are under extreme stress. Sometimes when I stand in this House I find it rather hard to describe the mental state of these families and other people who are living in the towns. School numbers continue to fall as people move away from these towns in western Queensland. They have not only dealt with the structural adjustment in the wool industry and with it their declining fortunes but they have seen loss of employment opportunities for the shearers and their families, who have now moved away because of the decline of the wool industry.

In Quilpie alone there are now 40 houses for sale. It is a town of about 700 to 800 people. What prospects there are for the sale of those houses, I do not know, but that is the sort of roll-on effect that this exceptional drought and the decline in fortunes of the wool industry are having on these small country towns. As I said earlier, school numbers are falling in most of those western Queensland towns. It is a reflection of the impact that the structural adjustment and the exceptional drought has had on those families.

So many families are being forced off the land through no fault of their own. They have been forced off because of exceptional drought—not bad management. It is not because of bad decisions that they have made; it is because of the exceptional drought. The drought has not broken and the seasonal outlook for this year, sadly, looks as though we are heading into another El Nino effect. That, too, creates enormous stress for those families who are already stressed with trying to cope with the impact of this exceptional drought.

The amendments before the House tonight are very worthwhile. I strongly support them. I support the farm household support program because of the way in which it is helping people who need our help. We are a lucky country and we can afford to support families. That is what the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 is doing: it is supporting families in circumstances where they desperately need our help.

The other point I want to raise tonight is how the household support program will help the families of our citrus growers in the Emerald shire in Central Queensland. Those families are being affected by quarantine restrictions that have been placed on that shire because of an outbreak of citrus canker in the citrus industry last year. Those families also need our support.

I thank the minister, who is in the House tonight, for his diligence and determination to try to work with the state Minister for Primary Industries and Fisheries in Queensland, Henry Palaszczuk, who just reneged at every point in trying to negotiate a Commonwealth and state joint sharing of the financial support that we need to be giving these farmers affected by an outbreak of citrus canker—not only on their farms but in the region as well—because of the quarantine restrictions apply to these farmers and have had a financial impact it is having. In that region, of the orchardists I spoke to, already there have been 40 permanent jobs lost. Something like 1,500 workers in the horticultural industry would normally be there working the orchards right now, pruning them for the harvest later this year. They are no longer there because there is no prospect of being able to sell the product on our domestic market, should it come to fruition this year. The only option is to sell this product into overseas markets, where there are no restrictions on citrus coming from an area that is under quarantine because of the citrus canker outbreak.

This program for household support will also help those families, particularly those in my electorate in the quarantine zones. Special provisions that the minister was able to get approved by cabinet will mean farmers will be able to access invaluable household support to support their families. It will also support families from outside the quarantine zone in Queensland if they can demonstrate that they have been affected by the quarantine as it applies in Emerald shire and the impact it has had on the citrus industry in Queensland.

I am delighted to have made a contribution to this bill tonight. I say to the other side of the House: we need your support on these issues, because we are supporting families. These amendments to the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 that amend Farm Help will go a long way to alleviating some of the stress and trauma that families go through when in so many instances they find themselves in situations where they must adjust out of farming and accept the up to $50,000 to help them start a new life. I commend the bill to the House and support this bill and the actions of the government.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: —I thank all of those who have contributed to this debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 and, in particular, the member for Maranoa, who from the experiences of his own electorate has been able to give a real insight into why this bill is so important. It is, of course, true that there is a large number of Australian farmers who are going through very difficult times because of the drought, including many in your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin.

speech.para: A range of programs have been put in place to assist Australian farmers. More than 30,000 farm families have benefited from this drought assistance since it began. There has never in Australian history been a greater effort provided by a national government to assist people facing the effects of drought. The Farm Help program also provides assistance in good times to help farmers better prepare for drought, to address the various issues of concern in their industry, to help them deal with the need to improve farm skills and to provide support to those farm families that have to make the very difficult decision about whether or not there is a future for them in the industry. Ongoing programs of this nature I think have a very, very important role to play in ensuring agriculture remains strong and prosperous in our nation.

There have been a number of particularly difficult issues to confront as industries face changing world situations, problems in endeavouring to compete and alterations to their regulatory systems which place extreme pressure on some of those industries—particularly in less favoured areas. But there is nothing more heartbreaking for anyone in agriculture than to see their crops die or their animals struggling because of the impact of drought. It not just has an economic impact on communities but also depresses their will and kills the spirit of so many in rural and regional Australia. The assistance that is being provided by way of drought aid has helped many families. I am disappointed that there has been a lack of cooperation from the states in the delivery of these arrangements; nonetheless, the Commonwealth has tried to provide real and practical assistance and tens of thousands of Australian farmers have benefited.

In relation to this bill, which makes amendments to the Farm Help arrangements, it is particularly important to recognise some of the context in which the Farm Help program exists. The AAA—Agriculture Advancing Australia—program is the government’s overarching commitment to all farmers and an ongoing commitment to the development of self-reliant, competitive and sustainable rural industries. AAA began in 1997 and in seven years has provided over $1 billion towards a range of programs to help ensure the long-term prosperity of Australian agriculture and agricultural communities. Over 150,000 primary producers, representing more than half of the Australian agricultural sector, have directly benefited from the package. AAA was renewed in the 2004-05 federal budget due to its success as a trigger for positive change in rural and regional Australia and in recognition of the considerable assistance it was providing to farming families.

Perhaps I could mention on this occasion some of the recent successes of AAA. The Rural Financial Counselling Service, which is funded under the AAA program, has responded promptly after the devastating bushfires on the Eyre Peninsula. I visited that area with the honourable member for Grey just the week before last to announce some new Commonwealth government assistance to the producers in that region. As soon as the fire had been through, there was a need for some emergency assistance, and the Commonwealth is playing its role in that regard. But many families face the despair of having lost significant parts of their property—and, in some cases, family members and loved ones.

The Eastern Eyre Rural Counselling Service located at Tumby Bay, north of the disaster area and the most affected by the bushfire, is providing a focal point for general assistance with the disaster response. Through the South Australian Association of Rural Counselling Services, additional counsellors were deployed into the impacted area on a rotational basis from Kangaroo Island and several other South Australian counselling services. The Rural Financial Counselling Service has been reviewed with a view to further improving the efficiency, timeliness and sustainability of the program and its delivery. What it has been able to do to assist in the South Australian bushfire disaster is an example of how important these services are in rural communities.

Farmbis continues to be a key element of the AAA package and last year was renewed for a further four years with a government commitment of up to $66.7 million. The government has been working closely with the states on new program arrangements and has finalised agreements with Western Australia, Victoria, Queensland, Tasmania and South Australia. I am very disappointed at some of the comments being made by the New South Wales minister. We are still waiting for New South Wales to commit to the Farmbis program. Even though they announced with much fanfare funding in their last budget and in subsequent budgets, we now have Minister Macdonald endeavouring to play games and pretend that, somehow or other, he is waiting on a commitment from the Commonwealth in relation to the financial arrangements. That commitment was made ages ago. All of the other states have managed to pick up on that commitment, but New South Wales, in spite of their earlier promises of funding, are obviously looking again at where they are moving. The Northern Territory also have not yet formalised their funding commitments to the program. I hope that, as soon as possible, those remaining states and the Northern Territory will ensure that primary producers and rural land managers continue to benefit from the training opportunities in business and natural resource management skills that are provided by the Farmbis program.

The AAA Industry Partnerships program is encouraging industries to be proactive in responding to challenges and opportunities. It is working in partnership with Australia’s agricultural, fisheries and forestry industries to assist them to improve their resilience and self-reliance. A key part of the Industry Partnerships program is the successful Young People in Rural Industries program. Since 2001, the government has provided over $2 million in funding to further the skills, knowledge and participation of young people in rural industries. I have to say that that is an element of the AAA package that gives me a great deal of satisfaction. To see the talents and the skills of many of the young people who have the potential to make such a significant contribution to Australian agriculture certainly gives me heart and the will to ensure that we provide the kind of environment that can properly reward their enthusiasm and commitment to their industries.

A further AAA success has been the Farm Help program. It continues to provide assistance for farmers working towards adjustment. Farm Help has a long record of achievement. Since the program commenced on 1 December 1997, over 9,000 farmers have received Farm Help income support, almost 8,000 farmers have taken up advice and training sessions and over 1,000 farmers have received re-establishment assistance. In that regard, the criticism from the honourable member for Corio of the failure of farmers to take up the exit package is obviously hollow. The member for Corio can surely not have been believing his own words when he criticised the fact that around a thousand farmers have taken up this exit package. He also made reference to the take-up of exit packages specifically provided in particular industries. Is he not aware that 82 farmers so far have already taken up the sugar package re-establishment grants, that 74 took up the Pork Producer Exit Program and well over 140 took up the Dairy Exit Program?

There has been a response by farmers unable to continue in the industry to take advantage of these exit programs which help to smooth their passage to an alternative lifestyle. It is not easy for farmers who choose to leave the career that has perhaps supported them throughout their lives and may have supported their families for generations. There is a sense of failure in many instances and an uncertainty about their capacity to deal with what a new life might hold in the cities or some other places. This re-establishment grant helps farmers to adjust to those circumstances. It gives them an opportunity to undertake some new training and to equip themselves effectively for a new life.

The purpose of the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 is to reinforce the structural adjustment focus of the Farm Help program. It seeks to do this by clarifying the qualification provisions for entry to the Farm Help program and by enabling ongoing communication with Farm Help re-establishment grant recipients regarding their undertakings not to re-enter farming and to notify a change of address. These provisions aim to improve the effectiveness of administration of the Farm Help program by allowing for follow-up to determine whether the program has assisted farmers to re-establish successfully out of farming. They are also to ensure that they comply with their agreement not to return to farming within five years of receiving the re-establishment grant. The opposition has indicated support for the bill but has moved a second reading amendment criticising the government for the failure of people to take up the various exit packages, to which I think I have already provided a response. Clearly the opposition amendment is without substance.

But I must also refer to the major point of the comments on the bill of the member for Corio where he spent a great deal of time criticising the government about interest rates. I am amazed that any member of the Labor Party could come into this parliament and criticise this government on the question of interest rates. Farmers well remember that when Labor was last in government they were paying interest rates of around 23 per cent on their loans. Can anyone imagine in this day and age, when interest rates have been around five, six and seven per cent for an extended period of time, the burden on their mortgage if they were paying the sorts of interest rates that farmers were paying when Labor was last in government—figures like 20 to 23 per cent? No business can sustain that kind of interest rate bill. For the opposition to come into this parliament and criticise a government that has adopted and delivered a low interest rate policy is clearly the height of hypocrisy. On those grounds alone I think the contribution of the member for Corio should be dismissed out of hand.

Nonetheless, I am grateful for the fact that, in spite of his spurious criticisms and inaccurate comments about the purpose and relevance of elements of the legislation, the opposition have indicated their willingness to support it. I thank all of those who have made a contribution to the debate on this bill. The AAA program continues to be founded on the success of its key components, which are the catalysts for prosperity and growth in Australian agriculture and for the sustainability of rural communities. I commend the legislation to the House.

To this the honourable member for Corio has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That’ be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

Original question agreed to.
