debateinfo.title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES AND VETERANS’ AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER 2004 ELECTION COMMITMENTS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Ms Ley:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

item.para: failing to pay families the full $300 annual increase in the maximum rate of FTB Part B starting from 1 July 2005, which is what it promised in its election policy Extra assistance for families;

hypocritically claiming that the payment of up to $150 that families will now receive from 1 July 2005 is a ‘bonus’, when in fact it is only half of what was promised in Extra assistance for families;
taking away from eligible families the choice of receiving the additional FTB Part B money fortnightly, and instead paying it as a lump sum as part of eligible families’ ‘tax returns; and
failing to address the ongoing work disincentives caused by FTB Part B that penalise second income earners and harm labour force participation”.

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the motion.

—Labor will be supporting the Family and Community Services and Veterans’ Affairs Legislation Amendment (Further 2004 Election Commitments and Other Measures) Bill 2005. However, I would like to take the opportunity presented by this debate to highlight the government’s continued neglect of our social welfare system and the implications for struggling Australian families. As is the case with most of the government’s agenda in this area, Labor supports the bill not because the measures within it are strong or the best approach to dealing with the issues we face as a nation but because they go some way to alleviating the hardships created by the government over the last nine years.

speech.para: Many Australians continue to suffer because of the government’s mismanagement of our social security system, and Labor has no intention of standing in the way of any relief they can get. Disappointingly, however, this bill makes no attempt to address the underlying structural problems in our social security system. This is particularly evident with the government’s consistent failure to address the flaws in the family tax benefit system. We continue to see hundreds of thousands of families hit with large family tax debts year after year, and we have learned that some of Australia’s wealthiest families, with earnings of over $1 million each year, are still being paid obligation-free payments of up to $3,000 a year in the form of FTB part B. Yet the bill makes no attempt to address these obvious inconsistencies. Instead it introduces another quick fix, demonstrating yet again the government’s bandaid approach to social security. So I want to take the opportunity to point out the failings of this bill and show how these are symptomatic of the government’s continued mishandling of our social security system. I have also moved a detailed amendment that deals with these problems.

In summary, the bill proposes to amend the following legislation: A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999 and A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999 to introduce a new family tax benefit part B supplement from 1 January 2005; A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999 to replace the existing formula to the child income cut-out amount for the family tax benefit with a specified index cut-out amount; and the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans’ Entitlements Act 1986 to exempt aged care accommodation bonds from the operation of the assets test. I will deal with each of these measures in turn.

As part of its election policy ‘Extra assistance for families’, the government promised to increase the maximum rate of FTB part B by $300, starting from 1 July 2005. The government subsequently announced that it would backdate the new payment to 1 January 2005 and that it would now be paid as a lump sum on income reconciliation after the end of the relevant income year. It is claimed that schedule 1 of the bill gives legislative effect to this commitment through the introduction of a new FTB part B supplement. The annual amount of the new supplement will initially be set at $302.95 for the 2004-05 financial year. This amounts to a daily figure of 83c. As the FTB part B supplement commences from 1 January 2005, and there are 181 days in the period 1 January to 30 June 2005, the maximum FTB part B supplement for that period would be $150.23. The FTB part B supplement will be subject to a one-off six-month indexation arrangement on 1 July 2005, which reflects its 1 January 2005 commencement, and then will be indexed on 1 July 2006 and each following 1 July according to annual movements in the CPI. Of course the creation of another FTB supplement was not what the government promised at the election—and I will return to that point later.

Schedule 2 deals with the child income cut-out amount. An individual cannot be an FTB child if, among other things, the individual has adjusted taxable income, for the relevant income year, that equals or exceeds the cut-out amount. The relevant eligibility rules and definition of ‘cut-out amount’ are in sections 22A and 35 of the Family Assistance Act. Under the bill the current definition of ‘child income cut-out amount’ will be replaced with the amount of $11,233 from 1 July 2005. This amount will be subject to annual CPI indexation to maintain its value in real terms. The new amount is apparently higher than the cut-out amount of $11,218 that would have been applicable from 1 July 2005 under the existing formula in family assistance legislation.

Schedule 3 deals with accommodation bonds. As part of its election policy, the government promised that accommodation bonds paid to an aged care facility would be exempt from the Social Security Act and veterans’ entitlements assets tests. Currently where a customer pays an accommodation bond to an aged care facility the refundable balance of the bond is held as an asset of the customer for means testing purposes. This may result in a reduction in the pension the customer receives and may in some cases mean that a pension is no longer payable. These amendments therefore mean that many older Australians will be able to receive a higher rate of payment or obtain a payment they would not otherwise have had.

These amendments will also allow customers to pay their accommodation bonds by periodic payments and to rent out their former home without the rental payments affecting their rate of payment. Customers in this situation will also be able to retain the asset test exemption for their former home during any period in which they rent it out. This change mirrors existing concessions available to residents in high-level aged care who pay accommodation charges. There will also be provision for customers, who will now be eligible for either a social security or veterans’ affairs payment because of these changes, to have their payments backdated to 1 July 2005. The backdating will be available where customers apply to Centrelink or the Department of Veterans’ Affairs for a payment prior to 30 December 2005 or, if they have special circumstances, prior to 30 June 2006.

I now want to deal with the government’s broken promise to increase family tax benefit part B. As I indicated earlier, the proposed changes to family tax benefit part B included in this bill are not what families were promised during the election campaign. Indeed, eligible families will now only receive half of what they were promised during the financial year. As part of its election policy—Extra assistance for families—the government promised to increase the maximum rate of FTB part B by $300, starting from 1 July 2005. Families had every right to assume that the $300 annual increase would be made available to families through their regular fortnightly family tax benefit payments and that this money would start to become available after 1 July this year, but this has not occurred.

Under the arrangements included in this bill, families will not receive the promised $300, which will now be paid as a lump sum, until after 1 July 2006. Instead, the Minister for Family and Community Services announced on 9 February 2005 that eligible families would be paid a $150 bonus, a bogus bonus, at the time they lodged their tax returns for the current financial year—that is, after 1 July 2005. This so-called bonus is only half of what eligible families were promised at the election. So we have seen the government swing into full mean and tricky mode by fudging the accounting and then having the audacity to dress up the revised measure as somehow being a bonus for struggling families. In a breathtaking display of hypocrisy—and this is pretty incredible for that minister—the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, continues to have the hide to claim that this consolation payment of up to $150 is somehow a bonus for families. Senator Patterson clearly, as usual, does not understand her own election promise, which was that families would get the full $300—not $150—starting from 1 July this year. It is either that, or the minister is plainly being deceptive. The delayed payment of the full $300 was confirmed by officials from the Department of Family and Community Services at the Senate estimates on 16 February 2005. It is also clear that families no longer have the choice of receiving the additional money through their fortnightly payments. The removal of any choice is contrary to the government’s rhetoric that families should have the choice of receiving regular fortnightly payments or a lump sum through the tax system.

In the last week we have seen even more damning evidence that the government’s family tax benefit system is not working. New figures have revealed that Australia’s wealthiest families continue to be big winners from family tax benefit part B. Nearly 30,000 families with annual incomes of over $100,000 received family tax benefit B payments worth up to $3,000 a year during the 2002-03 year. At the same time poorer families continue to be confronted with a mounting FTB debt load year after year. Imagine how these families felt when they saw the reports last week that wealthy families, earning hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, were able to get family payments. While wealthy families are pocketing thousands of dollars in payments, other families are being saddled with family tax benefit debts every year. Where is the fairness and equity in all of that? The fact that wealthy families are being rewarded with up to $3,000 a year in obligation-free family payments shows the failure of the government to provide assistance to those families who need it most. If the government were really serious about welfare reform then fixing this glaring inequity would be a good starting point.

The largesse for Australia’s wealthiest families contrasts with the government’s harsh plans to take away payments from people with a disability, and sole parents. While the government is happy to pay wealthy families thousands of dollars each year it wants to force single parents back to work as soon as their children start primary school. This demonstrates why Labor remains committed to introducing a single family payment with a consistent income test for all Australian families. This is the best way to ensure that our system of family payments is fair, consistent and targeted to those families that need the help most. Struggling families have every right to demand an explanation from the Howard government about why its policies continue to reward wealthy people at the expense of people who have a genuine need for assistance.

The government is also setting out clearly to target single parent families. The broken promise to increase family benefits to single parent families is one of the three major hits on these families since the election. And it is the same story with the promised child-care rebate. Shortly before Christmas last year, the Howard government broke its promise to introduce an uncapped 30 per cent child-care rebate this year. The rebate will now be capped, and families will not be able to claim one cent until after 1 July 2006, a full year later than the government promised at the election. The rebate would have provided much-needed relief to single parent families struggling under the weight of high child-care fees. Now we learn that the government wants to force single parents back into the work force as soon as their children start primary school. These three hits on single parents demonstrate that the Howard government is more interested in cost cutting than in looking after the needs of families or giving them the capacity to participate fully in the work force. Single parent families are right to be anxious about what will happen next time they appear in the Howard government’s firing line.

We have also seen the government continue to leak information about its plans for so-called welfare reform. The government basically wants to make it harder to access payments so that it can save money but not necessarily assist people to fulfil their capacity. The government does not seem to understand that real welfare reform is about making the social security system simpler, fairer and more accessible for the six million Australians who access income support payments each year. There has to be a system which invests in their capacity and provides incentives. Real welfare reform is about unlocking the welfare trap that this government has created in both the tax system and the family payment system and investing in the capacity of individuals to participate in the work force. Neither of these things is happening. Successful welfare reform should develop opportunities for the full work force participation of those who are receiving payments.

As always with the Howard government, its plans are simplistic and narrow. The narrow cost-cutting focus of John Howard’s agenda is best summed up in his failed attempts to limit access to the disability support pension. By recycling these plans, the government has again shown that it cannot tell the difference between cost-cutting and reform. Labor recognises that encouraging people to move from welfare to work is a policy objective in its own right, and one of the most important we can have. We want fewer people on welfare and more people in work. By helping people make the transition from welfare to work, we can deliver social and economic benefits for individuals, their families, their communities and the nation as a whole. Welfare reform should deliver increased work force participation, which has been recognised as an economic priority for a very long time. But, as the Reserve Bank and others have noted, skills shortages and stagnant work force participation are big threats to Australia’s continuing economic prosperity.

After almost a decade in government, John Howard still has not made any progress on welfare reform. As always, the government is long on rhetoric but very short on action. That sums up the story of the Howard government: nine years of failure to invest in people and real welfare reform. It has a tax system which punishes people trying to move from welfare to work, whereby some of the people on the lowest incomes in our community lose more than a dollar for every additional dollar they earn. Rewards should be there for working harder—for people trying to move from welfare to work and for people working overtime. People should not be financially punished for becoming active in the work force, but that is currently the situation we have in the intersection between the family payment system and our income tax system.

Labor took up this challenge seriously at the last election. Labor’s policy was not perfect, but it did seek to fundamentally address the punishing effective marginal tax rates that are holding our economy back. It had the overriding objective of boosting participation, particularly amongst jobless families. Income splitting was allowed, enabling a tax-free threshold of up to $12,000 for one parent. Combined with the new working tax bonus, the incentives for jobless parents to move off benefits and into work were dramatically improved, slashing effective marginal tax rates by almost 20 per cent. Family tax benefits were combined into a single payment, ensuring that multiple benefits could not be withdrawn at the same time. The income threshold before payments were withdrawn was lifted substantially from just over $30,000 per year to $50,000 per year, massively improving the rewards for work for middle-income families.

The Melbourne Institute assessed the impact of Labor’s package on participation and concluded that up to 71,000 extra people would be drawn into the labour market, including 49,000 jobless parents, with the potential for savings in social security outlays and extra tax revenue rising to more than $1 billion per year. That is welfare reform. We do not have welfare reform from this government. What we really have is a welfare trap which the government remains unwilling to unlock because it will not deal effectively with the problem of high effective marginal tax rates. Nor will it come to grips with the need to invest in the capacity of people, particularly those who are denied access to rehabilitation—disability support pensioners who could do some activity in the labour market if they had real access to support when it comes to rehabilitation.

In comparison to Labor’s scheme, the Howard government’s family benefit changes announced in the 2004 budget were estimated by the Melbourne Institute to result in 22,000 individuals leaving the work force. So Labor has been leading the way in constructing a participation agenda—the agenda which the government claims to have, but which it does not practise. The government has put in place a welfare trap by not putting the necessary resources forward to invest in the capacity of individuals and by not reforming the intersection between the tax system and the payments system, which punishes so many Australians who want the opportunity to move from welfare to work.

It is with these remarks in mind that we have moved our constructive amendments to point out that this government has reneged on two key election promises. When it comes to the 30 per cent rebate for child care, the government has fiddled the system. Essentially, people cannot access any of that rebate for something like 18 months. What sort of payment or initiative is it when this government thinks it is assisting families by telling them it is going to give them a 30 per cent rebate for child care and then makes them wait 18 months before they see a dollar? It is just incredible. I do not think I have seen anything from this government that is more out of touch than this proposal. The government tells families to keep receipts for child care, which many of them cannot afford, for 18 months and then it might give them a quid—and does not bother to tell anyone how it intends to do it.

Similarly, the fiddle that they have done with family tax benefit B is a shocker. These measures combine to essentially rip $550 million out of their original election commitments. Why don’t the government own up and say, ‘We promised too much; we’re ripping $550 million out and putting down an affordable scheme’? You would have more respect for them if they said that. But we get these sneaky cutbacks hidden underneath which we had to tease out from them in estimates committees. Their reneging on the child-care promise was announced two days before Christmas by Treasurer Costello, hoping no-one would notice.

So $550 million has been ripped out of the commitments and taken away from families in yet another broken election promise. When you look at all these things combined, what this country desperately needs is some real welfare reform which invests in people and provides incentive and the backup to give people the capacity to stand on their own two feet. They have not been getting that for nine years and there is nothing in this bill to deliver it.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Labor Party will support the Family and Community Services and Veterans’ Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004 before the parliament. It is interesting that there has been discussion about ‘sneaky cutbacks’, the government fiddling with the system, ‘bogus’ bonuses, payments not being real and in ‘mean and tricky mode’. I do not think the Australian people believe the Australian Labor Party when they hear that kind of rhetoric. They know what is proposed in the bill this evening is certainly of benefit to all Australians.

speech.para: I am also moved to defend the current Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Kay Patterson. There could not be a more decent and caring person in that particular portfolio. Senator Patterson knows the portfolio backwards. She knows what Australian families face and she argues fiercely for them in the cabinet. She is a great advocate for those who need income support or other benefits, for Australian families and for older Australians. This bill tonight is the result of her advocacy. Senator Kay Patterson is indeed a fine minister in this portfolio, and I would not have any other.

Another thing that concerns me is the continuing attacks from the Australian Labor Party on the agency that delivers the benefits that are in this bill this evening—Centrelink. Centrelink is the model of a welfare delivery and income support system that the entire world could take note of. Centrelink is a marvellous organisation. Centrelink deals with such a huge volume of inquiries every day, does it extraordinarily efficiently, yet cops extraordinary criticism when once or twice something might go wrong. Mistakes will happen no matter what. There are always mistakes. They are never wilful, but they happen. When they happen once or twice in millions of transactions every day, I get pretty cranky that such criticism is directed against the good people in Centrelink right across this country. I pay tribute to Peter Doutre, who looks after the northern region from Gladstone and Cape York to the border. Peter Doutre and his people are just fantastic and a model of what happens right across the country. I certainly respect and compliment the people of Centrelink and the great work that they do for all Australians on behalf of the Australian government.

I have also heard criticism tonight that welfare reform is about the government saving money. It is not. Some of the welfare reform that occurs—and some is in the bill tonight—actually costs the government fairly significant amounts of money. I want Australians to understand that just cutting costs is not the agenda of the Howard government; it is delivering services and support to Australians who need it at the time that they need it.

I heard criticism in the debate tonight about the government wanting to limit access to the disability support pension. Right now there is a fellow in my electorate who is on the DSP and he runs a concreting business. How can that be? How can he be getting a disability support pension and at the same time be the principal working in a concreting business? That is wrong. Yet the Australian Labor Party say to the government: ‘We’re not going to help you fix that. This is a cost-cutting measure.’ No, it is not; it is a measure to look after people who actually need looking after and to not look after people who do not need support. All Australians would support that—all Australians, apparently, except the members of the Australian Labor Party.

We have heard criticism tonight that there has been no progress on welfare reform in nine years. Goodness gracious me! The Australian Labor Party ought to ask Australian families how they feel about that. They ought to ask Australian families about the payments that the Labor Party claimed were not real. They might find that Australians are very satisfied with the progress and the reform that has occurred under the Howard government in the last nine years.

talk.start.para: —Ask them about interest rates.

—Yes, we might ask them about interest rates. You know what they will say? They will say, ‘We remember what they were under the Australian Labor Party; we remember the range that they were and when they were 17 per cent.’ We are happy to ask about interest rates.

speech.para: In relation to progress on welfare reform, of course the government have not been able to implement all the reforms we wanted to. And why not? Because the Australian Labor Party stood in the way of sensible reforms. I do not think you could point to a single reform by the Howard government—all the difficult things we have done over the last nine years—that has not been proved to be right. We have fought tooth and nail to get them through the Australian Senate, and when they have been implemented the government have been vindicated in what we wanted to do. The reforms have been very effective for Australia. We will continue to do that and Australians will be better off because of it.

I am particularly pleased to see the changes to the accommodation bonds in the bill before us tonight—a very sensible measure indeed and one that will be welcomed by older Australians who currently are not exempt from lump sum accommodation bonds being taken into account in relation to their social security benefits. This not only applies to social security recipients; it also applies to recipients of veterans’ affairs pensions, and so it should. It should be consistent. The government has ensured that the relevant acts will be amended, when this legislation passes, to have consistency across benefit delivery to all Australians. In exempting this particular accommodation bond from the assets test, the government has also been mindful to exempt situations where residents might not sell their home but instead rent it. The government has very sensibly exempted the rental payments to avoid those payments affecting the person’s pension. This is an example of the Howard government’s caring attitude towards Australians in these sorts of circumstances.

We have heard about the other two parts of this bill, the FTB part B supplement and the child income cut-out amount. All of these measures in the bill are good news for Australians. They are good news for older Australians and they are good news for Australian families. My allotted time has now expired so I commend the changes in the bill. The whip says I can only speak for 10 minutes—

talk.start.para: —What a tragedy!

—I have to say to the member for Lowe that I would not dare challenge the whip. I commend the bill to the House and I ask the Australian Labor Party to cut out the words they have been using in relation to our welfare reforms and work with the government in the interest of all Australians.

—Before I turn to the contribution I intend to make in this debate, I have to pick up on some of the comments made by the previous speaker. We on this side of the House know that when they on that side of the House mention ‘welfare reform’ and ‘welfare to work’, they are not talking about caring for the person or getting the best outcome for the person, they are talking about cost cutting. Cost cutting is what this government is about. It is not about getting the optimal outcome for the person who may be in receipt of the welfare. When I heard the previous speaker pull up a person from his electorate who may be running a concreting business and use that as an example of why there should be a reform to the disability support pension, it made me sick. As somebody who worked for 13 years with people with disabilities, constructively trying to get them into the work force, giving them the skills and confidence to go in there and try to get a job, I have to say that to hear that member on that side of the House denigrating people and trying to scapegoat them, stereotype them and make out that anyone getting the disability support pension or benefiting from the current system is in some way trying to rort the system is absolutely disgraceful. The member should hang his head in shame. To say that the Howard government is noted for its caring attitude, for its caring nature, for being caring towards all those people who are on welfare is an absolute joke. He must take the members of this House for idiots if he thinks that is what the people of Australia think of the Howard government. Members of this House sit in their electorate offices with constituent after constituent coming in to see them to complain about actions taken by the Howard government, so I would have to say that the member is deluding himself.

speech.para: I will turn to the substance of what I wish to say in this debate. I and members on this side of the House support the Family and Community Services and Veterans’ Affairs Legislation Amendment (Further 2004 Election Commitments and Other Measures) Bill 2005, but our support is somewhat tempered by the government’s failure to fully deliver on an election promise it made to the Australian people. I suppose you could say that we should not be surprised by that, but the Australian people voted for this government and believed what it had to say. Unfortunately, they have put their trust in a government that has made a name for itself for not delivering or not quite telling the truth about matters that it puts to the Australian people. Unfortunately, part of this legislation falls into that category, and I will touch on that in a moment. But, overall, I think that the bill does deliver some meaningful gains to the Australian people.

The bill seeks to implement the introduction of a family tax benefit part B supplement, and I will concentrate on that a little later. There are changes to the formula for calculating the child income cut-off amount for family tax benefit and exempting aged care accommodation bonds from the Social Security Act and the Veterans’ Entitlements Act. When this legislation is enacted it will introduce a new family tax benefit part B supplement and that will be effective from January 2005. It will replace the existing formula for the child income cut-off amount for family tax benefit with a specific cut-off amount of $11,233 and there is a new formula for annual indexation of this amount. It exempts aged care accommodation bonds from the operation of the social security and veterans’ affairs assets test.

I will concentrate on that last part first. I like to be positive. I was a little bit negative at the start of my contribution to this debate but I will be positive now. I think that it is a very good move to exempt aged care accommodation bonds from the Social Security Act and the veterans’ affairs assets test. This is one of those matters that I have had constituents come and talk to me about. It is a matter that has created great angst for elderly people and for their families. It is something that I have made representation to the government about and that I have tried to support for a long time. It is very commendable that finally the government has embraced this matter. By doing so, it is assisting those elderly people who find they have to move into low-care accommodation and making it a lot easier for them to make the transition.

I mean ‘easier’ not from a financial point of view but from a psychosocial point of view. It is very hard for an older person to make the decision to leave their home. They are very attached to it. The ownership of that home, the memories that go with it and everything else that is associated with it are very important to them. When they do sell the home and then find out that it can affect their social security or veterans’ benefit, that further exacerbates the anxiety that is caused because in many cases they feel that they are losing the security that the money they had for their home gave them. This legislation puts them in a similar position to those people who are currently in receipt of social security and veterans’ payments. So I see that as a very positive move by the government and a very positive part of this legislation. I am sure the members on the other side of the House will recognise that I do not give compliments lightly, but I think this is positive and that it should have happened a long time ago. On that point this legislation gets a big tick but, unfortunately, there are other parts of the legislation that I am not quite so happy with.

I support the second reading amendment. The first part of that amendment is about the failure of the government to pay families the $300 increase in the maximum rate of the FTB part B starting from 1 July 2005 which is what was promised in its election policy—extra assistance for families. But, once again, the government has walked away from a promise it made to the Australian people. It thinks it can shuffle sideways and it thinks that it can trick the Australian people. It does not understand that Australian people actually rely on the government and they believe the government. Every time the government changes its position, every time it does not deliver properly, it not only undermines itself, it undermines all members of parliament. It creates a belief in the community that you cannot trust members of parliament because they do not deliver on what they say.

The government says one thing before an election and does another thing after the election. I find that particularly obnoxious because as a member of parliament I always try to be very honest with the people that I represent in this parliament and I place great importance on the fact that, as members of this House, we have an obligation to the people we represent and to all Australians to tell the truth. By not fully delivering on that promise of $300, the government stands condemned. But I know I should not be surprised. I know people on this side of the House share my feelings. I think that it is very disappointing.

The next part of the amendment is to condemn the government for hypocritically claiming that the payment of up to $150 that families will now receive from 1 July is a ‘bonus’ when in fact it is only half of what was promised in extra assistance. That goes back to what I was saying a moment ago, because a bonus is not getting half of what the Australian people believed that they would be getting by voting for this government. What they are getting is trickery and deceit and the government stands condemned for that.

The next part of the amendment criticises the government for not giving families choice in receiving the additional family tax benefit part B money fortnightly or having it paid in a lump sum as part of eligible families’ tax returns. Families find that quite disturbing. It is important that people have choice about how they receive their payments. I suppose if you look at the daily amount it is rather small, but if you are on a tight budget and you need that money on a fortnightly basis, you need it then; you do not need it at the end of the financial year. The government just does not understand how hard it is for families. It does not understand that people actually struggle on a day-to-day basis to make ends meet. It does not understand the difficulties that families experience. And to remove that choice, in itself, can create hardship for people. I know that many people of the other side of this parliament have extreme wealth and do not understand just how important it can be to have that money on a fortnightly basis.

The final part of our amendment, which is pretty self-explanatory, is the failure of the government to address the work disincentives caused by the family tax benefit B. It is all driven by their ideology, by their philosophical bent. They are not looking at the real issues, at how their decisions, their actions, affect Australian families.

This is a government that gives on one hand and takes on the other. It throws money at Australian people before the election and then it takes it back afterwards—in this case, it takes half of it back. It is a government that talks about keeping interest rates low—and what happens after the election? Interest rates are on the way up. That in itself creates enormous hardships for families. I have already had families contacting my office, talking about the hardship that this will create. This is a deceitful government. Its failure to fully deliver on its election promises in this legislation demonstrates its deceit. The Australian people recognise this deceit and if the government continues in this way they will send it a very strong message at the next election.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Family and Community Services and Veterans’ Affairs Legislation Amendment (Further 2004 Election Commitments and Other Measures) Bill 2005. Before the member for Shortland leaves, I note that it is terrific to see that she recognises the things that the government is doing even though, along with the rest of her party, she seeks to mislead the Australian people time and again by listening only to the parts she wants to and by spreading misinformation in this place as well as in the media about the things the government has done. The good news is that the people of Australia are far smarter than the ALP and the member for Shortland realise, hence the result of 9 October last year.

speech.para: This bill is about the government’s ongoing commitment to listening to and acting in support of three of the most significant parts of our community: families, seniors and veterans. On the first occasion I was privileged to speak in this place I highlighted my belief that families are a key part of our society. Part of the reason I chose to stand for election to represent the people of Wakefield here was a commitment to families. I welcome any move toward supporting stronger relationships and functional, loving families. This commitment to raise the amount of family tax benefit part B through a supplement is a welcome addition to the other practical outcomes this government has delivered to the people of Wakefield. I am happy to say—and I am sure that this will disappoint the member for Shortland—that these outcomes do not go unnoticed.

While I was doorknocking the many young families living in new housing developments such as Blakeview, Hillbank, Hewett and Andrews Farm, many spoke of their relief that the Howard government has kept interest rates in a low band of around six to eight per cent compared to the 10 to 17 per cent of the previous, Labor government. This means that families can enjoy the security of their own home. Parents I have spoken to have welcomed the facts regarding immunisation. The member for Shortland has said that this government is about money and that it does not care about people. She is partly right. This government is about money, because of the outcomes that it brings for people. While the last Labor government spent just $13 million on vaccines keeping our children healthy, in the next financial year the Howard government will spend $286 million on vaccines—a 22-fold increase on the 1996 figure. This means that childhood immunisation rates, which were at just 50 per cent in the early 1990s under Labor, are now amongst the best in the world at above 90 per cent.

Furthermore, groups such as the Clare and Gilbert Valley Council in the north of Wakefield have gone from telling me about the shortages of child care in their area to now telling me that because of the policies of the Howard government they have a number of providers vying to provide long day care in Clare. The residents of Kapunda and surrounding districts have told me of their excitement about the $519,000 incentive funding made available recently by the Howard government to enable the establishment of a child-care centre and the opportunities this will open up for families in their district.

While this family tax benefit supplement will assist families, I note in the legislation the measures needed to take account of the single parent situations and situations where custody is shared. Wakefield has a large number of families whom this will apply to, and often the children involved require additional support and help, particularly with early learning. I have begun discussions with local church, community and education groups to examine the best ways this government can provide targeted support to these communities of children in need. I am passionate about this not only so that these young people can have a better childhood but so that they have the opportunity to achieve their full potential as they grow into young adults—the future of our society.

These same clauses in the legislation highlight to me once again the enormous financial and emotional cost of relationship breakdown and the dysfunction that so frequently follows in our community. An article on the front page of the Australian of 10 February this year highlighted the fact that, while not all marriages work, successful relationships are possible, that they are about choices and support and that, importantly, the benefits of successful marriages flow not only to the couple involved but to their children as well as the broader circle of people touched by the family. With this government, I will continue to work with the people of Wakefield and Australia to identify and promote ways to better value and support healthy, viable marriages.

This bill is also about the Howard government delivering outcomes for pensioners and veterans. Whether it was in Davoren Park, Elizabeth Grove, Salisbury North, Mallala or Riverton, talking with pensioners and self-funded retirees highlighted to me their concerns about the viability of their lifestyle now and at the point when they move into care of some kind. These people welcomed the Howard government’s provision of a utilities supplement which will help them meet practical needs; the $148 million package for elderly carers, which will provide more financial help and respite; as well as the increasing rebate for private health insurance for older Australians.

Another real concern, however, was the potential impact of the costs of aged care. They saw that the inclusion of the accommodation bond in assessing their social security payment and the retention of the family home, which in the eyes of many is an inheritance, would affect their disposable income through both asset and income testing. This bill will not only resolve this issue, by exempting the balance of the bond from the assets test, but also it will provide certainty as to the status of their former family home. If the property is rented out and the income is used to pay periodic bond payments, the rental will be excluded from the social security income test and the home itself will remain exempt from the means test. Importantly, these amendments also apply to veterans. They will enjoy the same benefits and have more certainty about their future once these amendments to the social security law, the family assistance law and the Veterans’ Entitlements Act are passed.

Unlike the member for Shortland, the Australian people recognise that these amendments—this follow-through of the commitments made during the election—are just the latest instalment from a government which over the last nine years has consistently listened to, and delivered results and real benefits to, the families, pensioners and veterans in Australia’s community. I am therefore happy to support the bill.

talk.start.para: —I am certainly pleased to speak this evening on the Family and Community Services and Veterans’ Affairs Legislation Amendment (Further 2004 Election Commitments and Other Measures) Bill 2005. The bill sees the Howard government following through on a commitment that we made during the election campaign to ensure that we provide in a very full way for those people in our community that rely on family tax benefit part B, as well as providing increased certainty for veterans under the veterans affairs assets test when it comes to dealing with social security. As well, the bill replaces the existing formula for the child income cut-out amount for family tax benefit part B with a set amount of $11,233. I am also pleased to speak to this bill because it addresses the primary concerns of two communities in my electorate of Moncrieff, particularly those people on the Gold Coast. They are of course the veterans community on the Gold Coast and those many Gold Coasters with young families that rely on the support that the Howard government provides them through family tax benefit part B.

speech.para: Before I get to the detail of the bill, I would like to make some comments on family tax benefit part B, particularly the fact that the government took the decision to pay the increased amount of $300 from 1 July onwards as a lump sum payment. This is an important component of the government’s legislation and goes to the core of the fact that the Howard government recognises that Australian families benefit from lump sum payments. Despite the many concerns that the opposition raises, I would contend that those concerns are false and hollow and that the rhetoric that the Australian Labor Party engages in, especially when it comes to lump sum payments made by the Howard government to support hard-working Australian families, is done for no reason other than cheap political point scoring.

I am pleased to associate myself very closely with the Multiple Birth Association, one of the many very active community groups in the Gold Coast community. The Multiple Birth Association have a very active membership. I am a big supporter of theirs and I am very proud of the work that they do as advocates for those people that have had twins or triplets and the like. I am also very proud of the role that they play in keeping informed those people that are encountering a lot of the burdens and challenges that go with having multiple children from the one birth, by taking them through the process and teaching them about mechanisms that they can use and also about assistance that is available, so that the experience of young children is one that is ultimately not too stressful for the parents concerned. I think we would all recognise that perhaps having twins or triplets in one birth would present a series of unique challenges for many families, so the role that the Multiple Birth Association play is an important one, and that is why I am pleased to assist them.

Recently, during the campaign, I had the opportunity to have the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator the Hon. Kay Patterson, visit my electorate for a short while. While the minister was there, I made sure that she had the opportunity to meet with representatives of the Multiple Birth Association. We made sure that we took the opportunity, while we were discussing the challenges that they face, to discuss the ways in which family tax benefits have been of assistance to them. I would highlight the message that came through very loudly and clearly from the large number of mothers that were there on that particular day to meet with the minister. They indicated their overwhelming support for these types of payments being made as lump sums. The reality is that, contrary to what the ALP says, it is not a case of families going out and squandering the money on all sorts of inappropriate purchases or activities. The vast majority of families use this money very effectively to ensure that they make available to their young children the very best that they can. This might include, for example, using the lump sum to purchase seats for their vehicle, new bunk beds or other equipment that is crucial to ensuring that the children that are born into these families have the very best possible start in life. That is why I am particularly pleased to support this bill.

In particular, the announcement during the 2004 election campaign that the government would increase the rate of family tax benefit part B by $300 per annum from 1 July 2005 was one that I had no difficulty at all in highlighting to my electorate and explaining the benefits that would flow from it. I am certainly pleased about it and I know from the mothers I have spoken with at the Multiple Birth Association as well as other people who have approached me at the listening posts that I hold in the community that parents like lump sum payments and they like the fact that they provide them an opportunity, as I said, to purchase a new set of bunk beds or the kind of equipment that they need for their children.

Likewise I am pleased that now the federal government has been able to ensure that aged care accommodation bonds are exempt assets when it comes to social security and the veterans entitlements assets test. This has been an issue that a number of veterans have raised with me. On the Gold Coast there is a very large and significant veteran population. The Gold Coast has the fourth largest veteran population in Australia and I am very pleased that the government has been able to move in this way thanks to its economic responsibility. Thanks to the good economic management of the government we are in a position where we can exempt aged care accommodation bonds from the social security and veterans entitlements assets test.

The reality is that many veterans rely on this exemption to ensure that they are able to obtain the greatest entitlement that they can. It is an entitlement that I know veterans appreciate. On the Gold Coast my relationship with a number of veterans groups—in particular the Nerang RSL, the Surfers Paradise RSL and the Southport RSL—has shown me that this issue was important to them, and I am pleased the government has been able to respond in this way. The third aim of the bill is to replace the existing formula for the child income cut-out for family tax benefit with the new set amount of $11,233. This is an important amendment. Whilst I will not go into detail, I know that it will be most welcome. In summary, this is an important bill. I know that all areas of the community will benefit from it. I am pleased to support it.

talk.start.para: —It is a great pleasure to conclude remarks on the Family and Community Services and Veterans’ Affairs Legislation Amendment (Further 2004 Election Commitments and Other Measures) Bill 2005. This very important measure is further evidence of all the things that the Howard government has been able to achieve through its sound management of the economy and particularly helping those sections of the community most in need. I commend the member for Moncrieff for his remarks. I particularly relate to the comments he made regarding the exemption of the aged care bonds from the means test.

speech.para: Two important commitments made by the government during the 2004 election campaign will be put into effect through the social security, family assistance and veterans entitlements amendments made by this bill. They are aimed at Australian families with children and older Australians—arguably those Australians most in need. Under the first of these commitments, families will benefit from the introduction of a new family tax benefit part B supplement. The new supplement will be paid on top of the standard rate of FTB part B as a lump sum on income reconciliation after the end of the income year. This mirrors the payment arrangements for the FTB part A supplement introduced last year.

The initial annual amount of the new supplement for 2004-05 will be $302.95. On a daily basis, this comes to 83c. The first payment of the FTB part B supplement will be made at the daily rate for the remaining portion of the income year after commencement of the measure on 1 January 2005. Therefore, the maximum FTB part B supplement for this financial year would be 181 days at 83c per day, or $150.23. The FTB part B supplement will be indexed annually on 1 July according to the annual movements in the consumer price index. However, the first indexation, on 1 July 2005, will be a one-off six-month indexation arrangement to reflect the supplement’s commencement on 1 January 2005.

The bill will make a further amendment to FTB to repeal the existing formula set down for the FTB child income cut-out amount. A child whose income equals or exceeds the cut-out amount cannot attract payment of FTB. The formula is being replaced with a specified amount of $11,233, which represents annual indexation of the existing amount for 2004-05 of $10,948. This new cut-out amount, which will apply from 1 July 2005, will be CPI indexed on 1 July in each following year. The new amount is higher than the amount of $11,218 that would have been applicable from 1 July 2005 under the existing formula.

The second of the election commitments addressed by this bill has been made by the government to give older Australians peace of mind and greater capacity to manage their transition to aged care. The measure is to exempt aged care accommodation bonds from the social security and veterans entitlements means test. If a customer pays an accommodation bond to an aged care facility, the refundable balance of the bond is currently assessed as an asset of the customer under the means test. This may reduce the customer’s payment or rule out payment altogether. These arrangements will significantly improve that situation so that many older Australians will receive more or will receive a payment that was previously unavailable.

Furthermore, customers who pay their accommodation bonds by periodic payment will now be able to rent out their former home without the rental payments affecting their rate of payment. They will also keep the assets test exemption for their former home while ever it is rented out. This advance is in line with the current concessions available to residents in high-level aged care who pay accommodation charges. Customers who will now be eligible for either a social security or veterans entitlements payment because of these changes may be able to have their payment backdated to 1 July 2005. All that will be necessary is for these customers to claim payment from Centrelink or the Department of Veterans’ Affairs before 30 September 2005 or, if they have special circumstances, 30 June 2006. I commend the bill to the House.
