debateinfo.title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (2005 MEASURES NO. 1) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Measures No. 1) Bill 2005 is the fourth bill we have dealt with that tidies up a host of bungles that have now been discovered in the Higher Education Support Act. This is in addition to the hundreds of government amendments moved when the act was originally passed back in December 2003—all this for an act that has only been in force for about nine weeks. When the original legislation was introduced in September 2003, the Minister for Education, Science and Training tried to convince us that we had to pass it without amendment as a matter of urgency. This is the sort of arrogant and sloppy legislation that unfortunately we can expect to see a lot more of once the government has absolute control over the parliament from July this year.

speech.para: The bill before us has four main elements: firstly, to meet funding commitments made in the lead-up to and during the election; secondly, to provide the fourth round of technical amendments associated with the implementation of the Higher Education Support Act passed in December 2003; thirdly, to alter the composition of the governing council of the Australian Maritime College so that it complies with the national governance protocols; and, finally, to give access to table B providers to the capital development pool.

I will go through the first part of the legislation. The bill includes $48.7 million over four years for the following initiatives: 100 new student places in radiation therapy, 40 new aged care nursing places, 12 new medical places for James Cook University, infrastructure funds for James Cook University, infrastructure funds for the new Australian Maritime College campus at Point Nepean, infrastructure funding for IT for Charles Darwin University, and national institute funding for the Australian National University.

The Australian Labor Party support all of these worthwhile initiatives, but we note that many of the commitments are to be delivered to universities in highly marginal coalition held seats. This is an issue I will return to later, but I must say I feel a bit sorry for the universities that do not happen to be located in marginal electorates, and it does call into question the way in which this government allocates funds to our universities.

As I indicated, this is the fourth bill to tidy up the mess that the minister presented to this parliament in 2003, and from the look of the program we have even more to come. Every time we look, we are faced with another tidy-up bill to paper over a few more of cracks in what appeared at the time to the minister to be a faultless bill.

The technical amendments before us today deal with the following issues. Firstly, they make clear that compliance with the tuition assurance requirements for higher education providers is ongoing, not only at the point of approval. Secondly, they alter the minister’s powers to exempt higher education providers from the tuition assurance scheme to allow conditions to be placed on the exemption. Thirdly, they clarify the conditions under which the Howard government’s seven-year learning limit must be recredited and the HECS-HELP loan recredited should a provider be unable to offer a unit in which a student is enrolled. Labor will support all of those amendments.

The most significant policy issue in the bill is the proposal to give table B providers access to the $43 million a year capital development pool for university infrastructure. Since general capital allocations were rolled into operating grants for universities more than a decade ago, this is now the only capital funding to universities over which the Commonwealth has discretion. The current impact of this section of the bill would be to give Bond University, the University of Notre Dame and Melbourne College of Divinity the ability to apply for grants under the capital development pool. However, this list could grow as additional providers are added to table B in the future.

While we will not be opposing this provision, the opposition do have a number of concerns about the lack of transparency and about the way in which this proposal has been introduced. It is important to note at this stage that extending the number of institutions that will be eligible to access the fund without an increase in the size of the fund amounts to a real cut in funding for what is already pretty dilapidated university infrastructure.

Like many of my colleagues, I am aware that our universities have countless examples of need for capital development to either expand or replace existing infrastructure. The government in this legislation is cutting the finite pie into a larger number of pieces. Of course, the size of each piece will inevitably get smaller. If the government is serious about providing support where it has not previously done so, it would be good if the government decided to make available increased money as it increases the number of institutions that can apply.

It is also worth noting that there was absolutely no prior warning and no public discussion of this initiative prior to the bill’s introduction to the House just three weeks ago. There was certainly no mention of it before the election and there has been almost no explanation of the rationale for the change, just a pretty bland statement of the outcome. There has been no explanation of where this proposal might sit within the government’s broader ideas being floated by the minister at the moment about which higher education institutions are going to be eligible for public subsidies. These are very significant changes that the minister is floating and, as I say, it would be useful to know where this change fits within his thinking.

There has been absolutely no discussion about whether this proposal will be used as a precedent to extend funding under more significant programs. There has been no comment on whether the government has similar plans to extend access to other funds to the much more numerous higher education providers outside table B. So we are certainly very keen to hear the government’s response to these issues and get a much more detailed rationale from the government to inform consideration by the parliament. I look forward to the minister’s response to our concerns when he sums up and to further exploration of his response when the bill reaches the Senate, but in the end we will not be standing in the way of the change.

As I said, there was no mention of this proposal to expand the number of institutions eligible for the capital development pool before the election—absolutely no mention at all. You might ask how the minister could have told us about it during the election campaign because he did not actually release a higher education policy. Of all the things we have heard about from the minister, all the kites that have been flown, not one of them was talked about before the election. Maybe it was something that was out of the minister’s control. We certainly had the impression that the government wanted to talk about anything but the changes that it has now foisted upon our universities and, more particularly, foisted upon students and their families. Students and families are by no means impressed with the government’s continuing attempts to expand the number of full fee paying places at our universities. Students and parents do not support the increases in HECS that have now impacted on so many students around the country.

Maybe it is no surprise that we had a government that was not prepared to talk about higher education before the election, but it is pretty extraordinary that immediately after the election we have a minister who, out in the media, is floating ideas all the time but who made no effort to discuss those with the Australian people before the election. Even if the government had decided to release a policy before the election, you would have to wonder whether anyone would have believed what it said, because the government when it comes to higher education promises before elections certainly has a bit of a track record of giving up on those promises pretty soon after.

I remember the now Leader in the Senate promising before the 1996 election that a Howard government would not introduce full fees for Australian undergraduates. One had only to wait until August, following the election in March, for that promise to be ignored—it did not take long at all. The government, of course, decided they would introduce full fees for Australian undergraduates, and now we have fees of up to $210,000 at one university. Students can now buy their way into university, ahead of students with better marks, but of course only if you have these massive sums of money—$100,000, $150,000, $200,000—outrageous sums of money, whereby students are jumping the queue and buying a place at university.

The government, as I said, have got form. Once again, in 2001, they went to the electorate and promised they would not increase the proportion of full fee paying students. That promise was not worth much. By 2003, the same minister that we have now was announcing his intention to lift the number of full fee payers by increasing the proportion of courses that can be taken up by full fee payers to 50 per cent. This was pulled back somewhat in the Senate to 35 per cent, but we will have to see how long that lasts once the government has absolute control over the parliament from July this year.

We also should not forget that the minister told us in the parliament that the deregulation he was pushing through when he introduced the last round of changes to higher education would not mean huge HECS hikes. He actually had the audacity to say to the parliament:

quote.para: What that means in real terms is that the HECS charge for most courses in most universities will not change at all.

speech.para: Nothing could be further from the truth, as I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker. It did not last. Within a year, the vast majority of universities had put their fees up for all possible courses, and most of them by the maximum allowed under the legislation. You would have to say, when it comes to higher education, the government’s track record of saying one thing before an election and then doing something completely different is pretty strong. They did not say anything about this clause in the bill before the election; they have just dreamt it up since the election. They did not bother talking to the public about it, and here we have it in a piece of legislation.

The other serious concerns that we have about the impact of the government’s changes on higher education particularly go to what is happening to the number of places in our universities. Last year, under this government, the number of HECS students actually fell by more than 8,000 while the number of full fee paying places increased by 2,500. What an extraordinary record for a government. The government is very fond of claiming that full fee paying students do not displace a single HECS student.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! It being 9 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to acknowledge the women in my electorate and around the country who every day break down barriers and overcome obstacles to build full lives for themselves and their families, women who rise through the ranks, women who break into new career paths for women, women who find ways to mix family with career and women who choose to stay at home and cope with the financial penalties that arise from that choice—the ordinary and extraordinary women who, at a time of changing roles for men and women, work every day to find ways to fashion lives of their own choosing.

speech.para: International Women’s Day, 8 March, is just over 30 years old, but the fight by women for women is much, much older than that. Mary Wollstonecraft, who wrote A Vindication of the Rights of Women in 1792, said:

quote.para: I do not wish women to have power over men; but over themselves.

speech.para: She was years, perhaps centuries, ahead of her time, but today her words are absolutely appropriate. Women all around the country and women that I meet every day want and expect power over their own lives, yet we find on a daily basis that there are barriers for women seeking to exercise that power—barriers that governments have the capacity to overcome.

A couple of months ago I met a woman in Rydalmere who had an eight-month-old child. She had put her child on the waiting list at the local child-care centre when she was still pregnant. She did not have a car; she needed to use the local centre. When the child was eight months old, she planned on going back to work, so she started looking for work. She found work that would start two months after that. A month before she was due to start work, the local child-care centre phoned and offered her a place for her child. At that stage, because she had not started work, she could not afford the fees, so she said, ‘Can I delay it for a month?’ The child-care centre said, ‘No, we have to give the place away.’ A month later, when she tried to start work, she could not find child care for her child. When she had child care she could not afford it; when she could afford it she did not have child care. So this is a woman who remained out of the work force and is still out of the work force while she tries to find a child-care place and a job which appears in the same week.

I met another woman raising three children on her own who was desperate to go back to work and had the skills to go back to work, but because of the way the family payments and the tax system are structured the day she went back to work she was worse off. If she could have afforded to have been worse off, she would have gone back to work, but she simply could not afford it. So there was a woman with the skill and the will to work who was trapped by her circumstances.

When I meet with businesswomen I am astonished at how often a group of quite senior businesswomen will sit around talking about the difficulties they have with child care. Even given the opportunity to talk about business, when meeting with senior business figures their main priority is how difficult they find it to balance their careers with child care. When I go to a child-care centre expecting to talk about child care, I am amazed at how often I find myself talking to women about how difficult they find it to find work. So it does not matter whether you are talking to women without work or women with work, the issue remains the same: it is about ways to find a balance between children and career.

It also is apparent that women are the first to suffer from any downturn in conditions—a downturn in the economy or in working conditions. When the labour force is increasingly casualised, it is women who are the first into the ranks of casual labour. It is women who first suffer that lack of security and income. When we do not provide appropriately for the aged, it is women who drop out of the work force to care for their parents first. It is women who bear the burden of downturns. But, as I said earlier, Mary Wollstonecraft, well ahead of her time, got it absolutely right. I know from my conversations with many women that they expect us to get it right. They expect us in this House to make it possible for them to do what they know they need to do with their lives, which is to build lives that suit them. Whether they choose to stay home or go back to work, whether they choose to go back full time or part time, whether they choose a casual work lifestyle or a part-time work lifestyle, they expect us to take the barriers down so that they can actually make their own choices and build their own lives.

talk.start.para: —I rise in the House today to congratulate the Right Reverend David Chislett SSC, the Rector of All Saints Anglican Church, Brisbane, on his consecration as a bishop in the Church of God on 16 February 2005 at the Parish Church of the Good Shepherd, Rosemont, Philadelphia, in the United States of America. I know Bishop Chislett very well. I have attended All Saints Wickham Terrace for years, first when I was a student at secondary school. I am a former altar server, parish councillor and synodsperson.

speech.para: Bishop Chislett was consecrated to serve the traditional Anglicans in this country and Forward in Faith Australia who are dismayed at the heterodox views of many of the Anglican bishops in this country. Bishop Chislett will work with the Traditional Anglican Communion to bring orthodox Anglicanism to a new future. The chief consecrator was Archbishop John Hepworth, the Australian Primate of the Traditional Anglican Communion, and there were a number of co-consecrators, including the Anglican Bishop of the Murray, the Right Reverend Ross Davies, and the Anglican Bishop of Ruvuma in Tanzania, Bishop Kapinga. It is important to recognise that the Anglican Church over the years has always claimed to be part of the One Holy Catholic and Apostolic Church, and in fact the threefold order of ministry is the same as in the great communions of the West and the East—that is, the Roman Catholic Church and the Churches of Eastern Orthodoxy.

I am indebted to the Bishop of the Murray, who participated in the consecration, for some of the remarks I am about to make. I was always taught that the Anglican Church is the Catholic Church of England but, regrettably, in 1992 the Church of England broke with Catholic order when it legislated to allow for women to be ordained to the apostolic ministry of the priesthood. In the same year the Anglican Church of Australia enacted similar legislation. Traditional Anglicans would consider this to be a breach of Catholic tradition and Catholic order, and in fact it does present a situation in the Anglican Communion today in which we have impaired communion and where many bishops and people feel unable to be totally in communion with all in the Canterbury Anglican Communion. In England when this occurred in 1992 there was a provision made for provincial episcopal visitors, and a number of ‘flying bishops’ were appointed to minister to those congregations that were not able to accept the ministry of their bishop who had ordained women, thereby leaving the Catholic faith.

In the Australian spirit of a fair go it is not unreasonable that the Anglican Church in Australia should have made a similar provision for those Anglicans who, in all conscientiousness, were unable to accept the departure from Catholic order. I have observed the ministry of Bishop Chislett at All Saints Wickham Terrace. I have seen him build a congregation which was quite small into one that every Sunday now has more communicants at high mass than St Johns Anglican Cathedral in Brisbane. He has pastoral gifts, principles, integrity and is someone who should be held up as a role model for all Anglican clergy. Bishop Chislett will continue as the Rector of All Saints Wickham Terrace while carrying out his new episcopal ministry on behalf of traditional Anglicans in this country and Forward in Faith Australia. He will also work as part of the Traditional Anglican Communion and the Anglican Catholic Church in Australia.

I commend Bishop Ross Davies for his courage in participating in this consecration, along with the other bishops. Bishop Chislett is an example to all of us. He is an outstanding pastor and for 10 years has served conscientiously as the Rector of All Saints Wickham Terrace and he is a person who will enhance the future of Anglicanism in this country. Bishop Chislett understands the Anglican Church is the English expression of the Catholic faith. He is quite uncompromising and highly principled. He is a person I want to salute in the federal parliament as a person who should enjoy the admiration of all of us.

talk.start.para: —I am very proud to rise and speak on behalf of the women of Richmond to mark International Women’s Day. In talking to many women across my electorate I find that opportunity is a common theme of our discussions. Women want the opportunity to further their education, to balance work and family commitments and to access decent health care when they need it and when their families need it. Of course, all of this is made a lot easier when women live in a safe and secure environment. Late last year I met with the women who run the Tweed Shire Women’s Service. They provide support, counselling and a safe haven for women who have been the victims of domestic violence. When I was a police officer, the sad truth was that I spent a great deal of my time attending domestic violence situations. In my experience, when women live in a safe and supportive environment it is only then that they can find real opportunities.

speech.para: Let me turn to another issue that, because of this government’s complacency, is limiting opportunities for women. Across my electorate there is a shortage of child-care places. We are the second fastest growing region in the country, and I speak to families every week that are waiting to get their children into child care. For too long child care has been underfunded and, on top of this, it is becoming increasingly unaffordable for working families. In another broken promise to families in my electorate, the Howard government has reneged on its pledge to pay a 30 per cent tax rebate on child care this year. Now, families will be forced to wait until July 2006. The Prime Minister is so out of touch with ordinary working families that he has failed to deliver this much-needed relief. This government has indeed become so complacent that it no longer believes it should keep its promises to Australian families.

Parents are battling to get their babies and toddlers into long day care and family day care, and when those kids go on to school there is a shortage of available vacation and after school care. I recently visited a local child-care facility that provides after school care and vacation care. The manager of the centre told me she was literally overrun with parents wanting to put their children into vacation care. She simply could not cater to them and had to turn so many of them away. This often means that working families have to find alternatives that simply do not exist. One solution is to provide more funding and therefore more child-care places. Child care has been neglected; it is as simple as that.

As a mother of two young children, Alexandra, who is 6, and Joe, who is 5, I know that the reality is that a lack of child care limits opportunities for women. In 2005 women should not have to choose between continuing their career or education and having a family. If they choose to stay at home with their families, they should be able to do so without feeling financial pressure to go back to work straightaway. But the government’s broken promise has only added to that pressure.

These are not just women’s issues; they are also community issues. Women make up more than half the population. It stands to reason that issues affecting us affect the entire community. It is unfortunate that women are paying the price for this government’s complacency. I also often speak to many elderly women who have so much difficulty in accessing health care, decent dental care and home care, and they have difficulty in finding places in aged care centres as well. There is a whole range of issues in relation to women that are so important, and I have been very proud to stand here today and speak on behalf of the women of Richmond.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak about the effects of truck traffic on residents of the Bonner electorate. In particular, I wish to draw attention to a notorious section of the national freight route known as the Brisbane urban corridor, the BUC. To residents of my electorate the BUC is more commonly known as the Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road. This is not a new issue. It first surfaced in the early 1990s and it has continued to be of great concern to the local residents ever since.

speech.para: It is no coincidence that I have chosen this to be the first matter that I have raised in the House. This issue is as important to me as it is to my constituents. The Brisbane urban corridor cuts across Brisbane’s southern suburbs and links the Ipswich Motorway to the Gateway Motorway. This 11-kilometre corridor includes Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road, Kessels Road, Riawena Road and Granard Road. It is a road corridor that was clearly not designed to carry the traffic it now carries. Each day up to 50,000 vehicles travel on this route. Although there are many different users of the BUC, there is no doubt that truck traffic has the greatest impact on the surrounding suburbs.

In the Bonner electorate, residents of suburbs like Wishart, Upper Mount Gravatt, Mansfield and Eight Mile Plains have to live with the effects of this traffic every day. It has a major impact on their quality of life. This is a fact that nobody disputes. Elected representatives from all levels of government and from both major political parties are united in their recognition that truck traffic on the BUC is a serious problem. In particular, I wish to acknowledge the efforts of my colleagues the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Gary Hardgrave, and the councillor for Wishart, Mr Graham Quirk, who have fought tirelessly for around a decade to highlight the need for action on this issue.

In 2002 the Howard government demonstrated their commitment to local residents by funding a major study aimed at finding solutions to the problems on the BUC. This study received feedback from close to 2,000 people, and more than 20 separate community meetings were held during the process. The results of this study confirmed what residents already knew: truck traffic was a problem that impacted on their daily lives in a major way. One local family who participated in the study commented, ‘Traffic, pollution and trucks make our life miserable.’ Although this is the comment of just a single family, I know that it reflects the feelings of thousands of people living along the BUC.

The outcome of this planning study was a series of recommendations aimed at improving traffic conditions and reducing the amount of heavy vehicle traffic on the BUC. I am pleased to report that two of the most important recommendations to come out of the study are being implemented as I speak. Starting on 28 February, a 12-month trial commenced to allow trucks to travel toll free at night on the Gateway Motorway extension and the Logan Motorway. These toll roads are the major alternative routes to the BUC. The study found that many truckies were using the BUC to avoid the motorway tolls. This trial is aimed at getting non-local and non-essential truck traffic off the BUC when residents are trying to sleep.

In addition to this trial, new number plate recognition cameras have been installed on Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road to monitor traffic. These cameras will help us to identify overloaded trucks, oversized trucks, speeding trucks, noisy trucks and polluting trucks. The cameras will also help us to determine the effectiveness of the toll-free trial. In the short time since the trial started I have already received some very encouraging feedback. One Upper Mount Gravatt resident told me that even after just four nights he had noticed a dramatic reduction in traffic noise and truck traffic. I have had similar feedback from other residents. While we still have a long way to go, I am delighted that we have now taken the first crucial steps towards achieving better outcomes for residents living along the BUC. I look forward to working with local residents and my federal and state colleagues to ensure that we continue to make progress over the coming months and years.

talk.start.para: —Today, 8 March 2005, women in this place, in our home towns, across this nation and throughout the world celebrate International Women’s Day. I pay tribute and my respects to Indigenous women around the country who are still struggling for equality and justice in the areas of health, education and employment. I also pay tribute to the members of the Newcastle branch of the Union of Australian Women.

speech.para: All of us have older women in our electorates who were in the midst of the major struggles to try to achieve justice and equity for themselves and their generation but more particularly for their daughters and their granddaughters. These are the women of the Save Our Sons campaign, who protested against Australia’s involvement in the Vietnam War, and they are still actively protesting against violence in all forms including Australia’s involvement in Iraq. Their grandmothers fought for the right to vote for women; they fought against discrimination against women and for free and accessible education and equal wages for women. Unfortunately, today women still lag far behind men in wages, are still under represented in our parliaments and do not sit in equal numbers as CEOs or executive officers of our major companies. Women still carry the greater responsibility for child rearing, housework and caring for elderly parents—to name but a few.

Another major struggle of our grandmothers and mothers was, and is, that relating to women’s reproductive rights and women’s rights to control their own fertility. Unfortunately, the Australian public has been once again assailed with the abortion debate. Who raised and who is leading the current debate about reproductive rights in this country? Some conservatives and some church leaders, led by none other than Australia’s self-appointed morals crusader, the Minister for Health and Ageing. Be afraid; be very afraid. We have here a minister for health in a conservative government who is vehemently opposed to women having control of their own fertility and reproductive rights.

Women’s access to safe, legal abortion is a major public health issue. Mortality from abortions has declined since 1971, when many states changed their legislation to provide some protection for abortion providers. Prior to 1971, abortion was a major cause of death related to pregnancy, with an average of 25 per cent of maternal deaths being attributed to abortion. Since 1971 deaths associated with abortion are rare. The World Health Organisation estimates that globally 19 million unsafe abortions take place each year and that 68,000 women die as a consequence of this. The majority of unsafe abortions occur in developing countries where unsafe abortions are characterised by unskilled or undertrained practitioners, unsanitary facilities, a lack of post-abortion care and hazardous techniques. The WHO characterises unsafe abortion as one of the neglected public health problems in developing countries.

Unwanted and unplanned pregnancy is linked to a range of social, cultural, economic and psychological factors. Of course, we know there are no simple solutions that will reduce the rate of abortions—and taking Medicare funding from the procedure is not the very least of them. This so-called solution, promoted by anti-abortionists, would only serve to deny access to abortions for poor and rural women, therefore allowing only wealthy women to terminate unplanned or unwanted pregnancies.

There is evidence which indicates that comprehensive sex education and access to contraception are effective in lowering the rates of pregnancy, particularly amongst young women. Comprehensive sex education does provide young people with more support and guidance to delay their first sexual intercourse and develop a healthy attitude towards sex and sexuality. There is no evidence that abstinence-only programs successfully delay the onset of sexual intercourse. In fact, abstinence-only programs undermine the use of contraceptives once young people become sexually active.

Abortion is the only widely practiced medical procedure that is criminalised in this country. The termination of pregnancy is contained under the Criminal Law in every state and territory except the ACT. Recent data from the Australian Survey of Social Attitudes show that 81.2 per cent of Australians, regardless of gender or religion, agree that women should have the right to choose an abortion. Some 42.4 per cent of Australians strongly agree and 38.8 per cent agree that women should have the right to choose an abortion. Only nine per cent of Australians either disagree or strongly disagree that women should have the right to choose an abortion.
I conclude by reminding the House of Labor’s platform concerning reproductive rights. It reads:

quote.para: As women are the major users of health and community services, Labor will:
support the rights of women to determine their own reproductive lives, particularly the right to choose appropriate fertility control and abortion—

talk.start.para: —During the recent election campaign and in my first speech in this House, I indicated that I would act without fear or favour on behalf of the residents of Hasluck. There is considerable concern amongst constituents and residents in my electorate about the proposal to build a brickworks on Commonwealth land which is currently leased by the Westralia Airports Corporation and is immediately adjacent to the Perth airport. I understand that a couple of weeks ago a notice, effective from 14 February, was served on the West Aviat Golf Club on Kalamunda Road, South Guildford, by the Westralia Airports Corporation Pty Ltd. It gave the West Aviat Golf Club only 30 days—just one month—to vacate the property, with all that that entails. This is allegedly so that the land can be used to build a brickworks. I find it rather amazing that a group of people can be treated so harshly by any organisation. These constituents and residents have lived in the area for a long time and have leased the golf course area since 1984 for that particular purpose. They have put their own blood, sweat and tears into creating this golf course at their own expense and through their own efforts. They have created an excellent recreational area for use by residents.

speech.para: I have had representations on these issues from councillors of the City of Swan, from Kalamunda Shire and from representatives of local community associations from High Wycombe, Hazelmere and Rose Hill expressing concerns about health, safety and the environment, and the impacts that these potential arrangements will have on their amenity.

I have received many emails and have spoken with many residents about their concerns. Their concerns about the proposed development of the brickworks on the site include the lack of a consultative planning process; the potential environmental impacts on adjacent residential areas, lakes and wetlands; and the safety to aircraft from the heat emitted from the chimney stacks of the proposed brickworks and from the nearby asphalt plant. Importantly, they are concerned about their health and the air quality resulting from the emissions. In addition, on land adjacent to this area there is a waste material dump site, previously used as a building waste recycling operation. It is alleged that asbestos is contained in this waste dump, and they are concerned about the potential threat and hazard of that.
I would like to read from some of the emails I have received:

quote.para: We appeal to you, as a representative of the federal government, to block the moves being made at present to build another brickworks in the Midland environs, of which Hazelmere forms a part, on the West Aviat Golf Club, which club members have constructed with their own hands and, out of their own toil and labour, have maintained a beautiful landscaped area, incorporating two man-made lakes, which are visited by birds of many varieties.

Please give this appeal your urgent consideration and try to get your colleague the Hon. John Anderson to rethink the matter and get WAC to leave us on the land which we have invested so much in by way of money, blood, sweat and frustration only to have it taken away from us in just four weeks.

According to the honour book, over 6,000 members of the public used the course last year. In 1984 the land was leased to Transport Australia institute, the parent body of the West Aviat Golf Club, which was built and maintained by the members on a purely voluntary basis and still is.

The site is marked on the airport master plan as precinct 3 and was previously zoned as recreation and sport. It was vested by the federal government of the day back in the 1940s and is used as a camp for country people to send their kids to today.

speech.para: I assure the residents and my constituents in Hasluck that I will work as hard as I possibly can to achieve the best possible outcome for our community in this matter. I have made representations to the appropriate minister and will pursue those issues on their behalf. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is my great pleasure to be here to make some comments about some issues relating to my electorate, as the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and related bills allows me to do. I would like to speak about several organisations in my electorate which deal with children and which I have had some experience with over the years. One is a school which deals with kids who have severe behavioural and other difficulties and are between years 7 and 10 in secondary college. Another is a school which deals with primary-age kids with real problems as part of an overall network called the Child and Family Care Network.

speech.para: First I will talk about a school in my electorate called Berengarra. Berengarra School is part of the local community and does an incredible job with kids in years 7 to 10 who have real problems. About four years ago, I was very pleased to go to the 25th anniversary of Berengarra. I was recently down there again talking to the principal and others about potential relocation plans that they are looking at, and talking about some of the work that they have done. As I mentioned earlier, it is a school which deals with kids who have real problems. I have some details about that which go back to information provided by the school, which I would like to inform the House of. It reads:

quote.para: Increasingly employers, parents and many teachers are expressing concern about the nature and outcomes of our schooling system. This concern is not just about academic outcomes; it is also about the increasing number of kids attending mainstream schools whose behaviour is outwardly disruptive or quietly self detrimental.

Mainstream teachers are not trained to deal with kids that have severe behavioural problems and the stress of trying to has often meant that these students are excluded from school. On the other hand the many anxious or depressed students who do not attract attention, suffer silently until attempts at self-harm bring them to notice.

There is one school, which, due to a lack of funding, is generally unknown even amongst mainstream schools. The schools who do know about Berengarra often have the wrong view about how it functions and what types of children it accepts.
There is one general perception, however, that is absolutely correct, and that is, that Berengarra provides an effective place for training kids who are in an immense amount of pain.

Against all odds, the teachers at Berengarra have developed a unique and cutting edge environment in which they tackle the problems of truancy or school refusal, early leavers, behavioural dysfunction and academic failure.

This School is a model of best practice, which mostly goes unheralded, except by the many students and families whose lives have been turned around by their association with the talented group of teachers that make up Berengarra.

Berengarra is a small independent school, which has been working with some of the most difficult kids in this state for the last 25 years. The kids who are angry, depressed and anxious and have no chance at succeeding in regular schools.
How do they do it?

It has nothing to do with high fees or expensive resources. In fact, Berengarra struggles financially while it maintains a strong commitment to keeping fees at a minimum, assisting low income families who are often the most in need.
A major focus is on developing self knowledge and self management strategies.

The objective of developing academic skills is always predicated on the acquisition of socially acceptable behaviours and responses. What Berengarra does differently is to set realistic achievable goals for each student, on the understanding that overcoming the accumulated negative attitudes towards teachers and learning, requires time, patience and courage from the students, along with extraordinary attributes from the teachers.

Berengarra staff work with students in classes of 10 or 11 boys and girls. Inevitably the boys outnumber the girls 10 to 1. What may work well with one student may have the reverse effect on another and of course what works well with boys rarely works with the girls.

Statistics show that 90% of students are inclined to regularly seek attention inappropriately, even in a small group situation and 86% cannot cope with any task and become extremely frustrated and no matter how much they need it, 28% refuse help when offered.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: The key to Berengarra’s success is its guiding philosophy which determines staff selection and the development of curriculum that involves the basics, such as English, Maths, and, practical and creative subjects which include a range of electives such as farm work and rock climbing.

One example of this is the breeding program of hens and roosters that are exhibited each year at the Royal Melbourne Show. In maths the livestock is weighed and measured and the students are encouraged to handle the animals with care.
Science often involves flight, such as building and launching rockets which allows for a great release of energy, in a positive way. As well as being fun.

The students are challenged and engaged while dealing with their specific areas of dysfunction through cognitive behavioural strategies. All students receive individualised attention, which, is the prime ingredient in developing generic and specific skills.

Everyone at Berengarra believes in the worth of the students, they understand and respect students who often covert desire to achieve. Through experience, staff know that even the most resistant kids will revel in small successes and respond positively to teachers who give them a chance to feel good through achieving what is meaningful to them.

speech.para: Often we do not understand the nature of the problems that some of these kids have and the sorts of issues that are therefore faced by them, their families and their teachers. We in the community often dismiss them as being troublesome kids that you wish were not in the same class as your kid. That is quite understandable. It is a feeling I have had with my own children.
I have some statistics which relate to the sorts of students Berengarra has been seeing. The statistics state:

quote.para: All Berengarra students have seen or are seeing a psychiatrist or psychologist, 59% are receiving more intensive guidance.
26% of students come from single parent families.
17% are in-care with foster parents or carers.
41% have a history of child abuse.
30% have been in trouble with the police at some time.

speech.para: The list goes on:

quote.para: 37% of Berengarra students are hyperactive or have been diagnosed with ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder).
54% have notable learning disabilities and or difficulties, many kids require specially prepared work and one-to-one assistance.
74% of students have problems with work presentation and 87% can’t meet deadlines and therefore fail to cope at mainstream schools.
90% of students are inclined to regularly seek attention inappropriately, even in a small group situation.
86% cannot cope with any task and become extremely frustrated and no matter how much they need it, 28% refuse help when offered.
28% also indulge in chronic absenteeism and 63% have been expelled or suspended from one or more previous school.
65% of students provoke teachers and other students verbally and 38% take it a stage further by resorting to physical violence.
50% cannot accept criticism and 74% accept no responsibility for their behaviour.
46% tell lies and are unco-operative.
63% use excessive bad language which is time consuming when getting to the bottom of an incident that may have occurred.
65% of students have low self esteem.

speech.para: The statistics further state:

quote.para: These are the typical characteristics of any given group, Berengarra class sizes consists of 10 to 11 students. The most common behaviour that becomes unacceptable in mainstream schools being the constant excessive bad language.
The programs offered at Berengarra are specifically designed to address these needs and are continually under review.
The progress of Berengarras body of students is monitored daily and individuals are usually reviewed once a week, although at times daily, even hourly progress reviews are required.

The review system allows teachers to exercise a tailored approach to each student’s developmental needs, accommodating the many changes students make as they work towards returning to regular schools or TAFE.

speech.para: That is what it is all about. It is about getting them back into the mainstream system.

Students generally spend one to two years at Berengarra and are assessed on an ongoing basis to find out the appropriate direction for them when they move on. The intention is to basically re-establish self-esteem, try to give them the social skills to be able to handle themselves in a normal school environment and a normal community environment and the confidence to better understand what they are doing. The academic program is designed to minimise disruption caused to students from being taken out of mainstream schools and gives them the best possible opportunity to go further outside that environment.

Berengarra takes a very tough section of the student community and gives them an opportunity to get back into a situation where they can be solid students and solid members of the community. It is work that is done on a daily basis, and I would like to congratulate everyone at the school for the work they have done. It was good to catch up with Mark Heuston, the principal, and to talk to him about the issues that are being faced. I would certainly like to mention Ian Watson, who was the principal there for some years. He was the principal when I visited the school some time ago for its 25th anniversary. He has since retired, I understand, but is still involved with the school on a more voluntary basis. I wish him all the best.

Berengarra is located on the site of the Child and Family Care Network, which I mentioned earlier. The Child and Family Care Network is an excellent organisation that services the Monash area. Since I became the member for Bruce I have had dealings with that organisation on a range of issues and programs. It does work right across age groups. I can remember at earlier times attending programs funded by government for the training of young adults, and a range of other courses over various years, where I have gone along to present awards and otherwise take part in the activities at the school. In fact, I think that Kim Beazley attended as opposition leader at the Child and Family Care Network during the 1998 election campaign, when we launched our youth policy there. It is a non-political organisation. Its whole basic reason for being is to deal with the needs of young people and provide them with opportunities. It has done a great job over a long time now. It descended from the Burwood Boys Home. I understand that it now has a history of around 100 years of caring for children and families.

The Child and Family Care Network take a holistic approach. They see that you cannot look at these things in isolation and they work to try to ensure that they are providing services that fit the needs of the people they are seeking to serve. One particular aspect of what they do at the Child and Family Care Network involves the Cheshire Education Centre, a school that deals with primary school aged kids who have problems. Beyond that they are doing a bit of a restructure at the moment and are developing, establishing and funding a kids centre, which will be providing a range of services at a purpose built facility. I was happy to have a look at some of the construction work just the other day. I think that is going to be providing an innovative and successful service, particularly for kids in the zero to six age group, a time that more people have become aware of as being crucial to the development of the adults that they later become. I wish them all the very best with the kids centre. It sounds like a very interesting and exciting project. I may talk about that later if I have a bit more time.

I would like to talk a bit more about the Cheshire school, which I mentioned a bit earlier. The Cheshire school is a program of the Victorian based Child and Family Care Network, which provides a 12-month intervention program for primary age students with social, emotional and/or learning difficulties who are unable to be maintained within a mainstream school. So it is a younger age group than we were talking about with Berengarra. They have found that the cycle of failure experienced by many of Cheshire’s students leads to significant behavioural, social and emotional difficulties at home and at school. School life is a daily battle for their students, and they quickly learn to ‘act out’ or withdraw to shift the attention away from their underlying difficulties.

Students at Cheshire are provided with a unique 12-month time out from mainstream schools to develop their self-esteem, resiliency and confidence in a safe and supportive environment. At the end of their time at Cheshire the students are successfully transitioned into a mainstream setting. Cheshire currently caters for 16 students on a full-time basis, with a new intake of students each term. In line with the Child and Family Care Network’s focus on early intervention, the Cheshire school is in its final stages of building a classroom to cater for eight more students who have been deemed not ready for school at kindergarten prep level. With the generous support of the Brockoff Foundation and Rotary, this new classroom has been designed to cater for younger children. In fact, they have now completed that. I inspected it the other day, and it certainly was an impressive facility. A lot of work was being done with some very difficult kids. While I was there I did a flag presentation and the kids came out and helped me. It was great to see them. It clearly showed that the work that the teachers were doing with them was having an impact. The nature of the problems that these kids have are heart wrenching and terrible, but I also have some testimonies from some of the students about why they came to the school. I think they are quite touching and give you a bit of an idea of the way that they see the world. They are unattributed, so I can use them—I checked that with the school. I will read a couple to give you a bit of an idea of the sorts of situations these kids come from:

quote.para: I came to Cheshire because I was bullying people. I used to kick big kids because I wanted to and they were not allowed to kick me back. I came to learn how to make friends and be nice to people. I have to learn how to do my school work. Sometimes I’m nice to people. I still kick sometimes at home but not at school anymore. I’m concentrating and I do my work better. My numbers are better. My spelling is better and I’m getting good at reading. I get to do the fun things because I’m good here. Sometimes I miss out if I’m not good. When I go to my new school I have to be good and work hard.

speech.para: That is from a grade 1 girl aged 6.

quote.para: At kinder I hurt kids. I pushed them and I kicked them. One kid at kinder was my friend. I didn’t hurt him I just played with him. At Cheshire I be friends with people. I don’t hurt people. Sometimes I throw sand and I get into trouble. I can draw kittens and cats and dogs and people. I can dance and sing beautiful. I can skip with a red skipping rope. When I am a good boy at school I get to do something special. When I go to my other school I will still be good but I was naughty at Kinder.

speech.para: That is from a prep boy aged 6.

quote.para: I came here because I needed some help being friendly to other people and getting rid of my tantrums. I enjoy art, cooking, spelling and reading. I have even improved in reading, spelling and being good. I think I can improve even more before I go to my new school.

speech.para: That is from a grade 4 boy.

quote.para: I came to Cheshire because I was having problems making friends and I was bossy. I was sad a lot and people didn’t want to play with me. I was scared of making new friends and felt very lonely. I have new friends now and they like me.

speech.para: That is from a grade 5 girl.

quote.para: I was real bad. I would swear, throw things, stand on tables and I’d punch the teacher, run up and down the corridor, go up onto the roof and yell real hard so it would go through to the other classrooms. The teachers would give me a suspension or would take me somewhere to calm down. The last time I went on the roof and jumped down the school kicked me out. I had to stay home for 9 months. Some people got the idea for me to come to Cheshire. Mum said I had to be good or I couldn’t go I went to Cheshire for a look around and I reckoned it was quite nice, I liked the small classroom because I could get help for my work. People had time for me. I changed my reading, my times tables and all my work things. My behaviour has change. Now people help me, I am nice, I don’t swear, I don’t be mean or hurt people. I feel happy now, I’ve even got friends. I like how I am now.

speech.para: That is from a grade 5 girl.

quote.para: I came to Cheshire because I hit people and threw sticks and dust bombs at people. I threw sand and kicked people. Now I have changed and I don’t hit people, kick people, throw sand, sticks or dust bombs. If you do the wrong thing you have to sit off the yard or in the foyer. If it’s really bad you miss excursions. I sit on the chair nicely and I do my work. I like writing stories best and learning about bugs. It is better being good so you get to do the good things.

speech.para: That is from a grade 2 boy aged 8.

This booklet is full of testimonies from kids facing different situations but basically, at the end of the day, trying to grow up, which is always a difficult thing. What you see when you read through these stories is quite touching. It goes to the essence of what sorts of kids sometimes come out of our school systems and what sorts of kids sometimes are produced within family environments, and why it is important not to just take a view that they are not retrievable. The fact is that schools like Cheshire, for kids that age, and schools like Berengarra, for kids at a later age, do a lot of incredibly important work trying to deal with the problems that these kids have created and have had created for them.

When you look to the future of a country it has often been said that we measure the level of civilisation by how we treat our elderly, on the one hand, and how we treat our children, on the other. When you look to the future and to what can be done, the point has also been made, and it is an important economic point, that the sort of money that gets spent on dealing with early childhood development issues is an investment in the country’s future, not only because of the individuals’ lives that it can save and the circumstances of the families and communities that it can improve but also because of what it does for the future of the country. The savings that can be made in the future by investments at early ages to deal with those problems can be phenomenal. Those savings come by dealing with early identification of problems and illnesses, by—hopefully—preventing criminality at a later age, by reducing incarceration and prison time and by reducing policing costs.

There is a lot that can be saved if governments look to the future by dealing with the issues that we face with our young people. Schools and organisations like the Child and Family Care Network in Berengarra do a lot of important work. They do not get recognised enough. I am very pleased to be here today as their local member to say a little about what they have done. To all those involved with those organisations I would like to say congratulations on a job very well done.

talker.name: Nairn, Gary, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr NAIRN

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to support the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and cognate bills, which are an example of the ongoing excellent economic management of the Howard government. They are important bills to go through this parliament so that government, the Public Service and other instrumentalities can continue to do good work on behalf of the people of Australia. That strong economic management by the Howard government has certainly been reflected in the electorate of Eden-Monaro over the last few years, where we have seen quite strong growth in most parts of the electorate.

speech.para: Eden-Monaro has seen growth through additional people moving into the area. We have very strongly growing towns. Often it is an easy throwaway line these days to say that numbers in rural Australia are reducing. Sure, there are towns that unfortunately are reducing. But there is also very strong growth in many of the regional towns and not so big towns, which is certainly occurring across the electorate of Eden-Monaro.

There is growth not only in population but also in economic activity. As a consequence, there is growth in numbers of people in work and therefore a reduction in the number of people out of work. In fact, last year in Eden-Monaro the unemployment rate dropped to below five per cent. It is an unemployment rate less than the national average, which was an incredible achievement. You do not have to go back too many years to find unemployment substantially higher. In parts of the electorate it was not only in double figures but up around 20 per cent. Now all parts of the electorate are well below that double figure mark and across the electorate it fell below five per cent, which is extremely encouraging.

As we have heard in some of the debate that has gone on in recent days, that good work produces another problem: a shortage of labour and a shortage of certain trades and other skills. It certainly was not a problem 10 to 15 years ago, when so many of those people were unfortunately unemployed. But, because unemployment has plummeted, all those people are in work and that puts pressure on the labour market. It is a problem, I think, we would rather have than the reverse, which was there particularly in the early nineties.

Quite a number of things are happening to meet those challenges. One of the things that was announced in the election campaign last year was the establishment of the Australian technical colleges. One of those will be established in Queanbeyan. It has been very encouraging to see the community within Queanbeyan, and people from the ACT, as well, looking at this technical college and wanting to be involved in its establishment. We have had a number of meetings involving the chamber of commerce from the ACT and our Business Enterprise Centre in Queanbeyan. The newly formed Queanbeyan Business Council has certainly got it as a top priority. Everybody is working together to come up with a model to put forward once the opportunity to tender for this technical college comes about in the next couple of months, to ensure that it is a real global solution. When established in Queanbeyan it will tap into people within the ACT. As now ACT schools take students from Queanbeyan, so it will be with the technical college.

It is also great that people are acknowledging that it does not have to be just in one town—that, in fact, it can tap into other parts of the region. The discussion so far is about how we can tap into the coast and the mountains as well and perhaps have students from those regions do some of their core subjects in their schools down the coast—at Batemans Bay, Narooma et cetera—but also be part of the Australian technical college that is to be established in Queanbeyan. So these are exciting times, and they are the things that will start to address some of the issues relating to skills.

While in the electorate of Eden-Monaro we have all this growth, we also face some threats. Unfortunately, one of the threats that we face is in fact from our neighbour, the ACT. Queanbeyan is trying to grow but is currently being prevented from growing because of access to water. Although a fair bit of the water is stored in New South Wales over at Googong Dam, it is controlled by the ACT government. The ACT government is trying to keep most of the development in this region within its boundaries and, I think, has been extremely slow to work with the New South Wales government and the Queanbeyan council to provide the sort of water that is needed for the growth that there could potentially be around Queanbeyan.

We have to get over the problem of the border and we have to think more about being a region, rather than a ‘them and us’ situation. I am pleased that recently the Mayor of Queanbeyan, Frank Pangallo, met with Jon Stanhope to try to progress this, but I think it needs a bit of impetus from the New South Wales government as well. It requires that cross-border agreement, and I do not think the New South Wales government quite understands the urgency of it. I hope that progresses so that we can see some reasonable development occurring, because everybody benefits. Many of the people who might live over in my electorate in Queanbeyan in new developments will work in the ACT, and they will certainly at times shop in the ACT. People who live in the ACT work in Queanbeyan and often shop in Queanbeyan. We have all of that cross-border stuff, so growing the whole region helps everybody and nobody should try to keep that growth to one side of the border.

The other aspect of cross-border cooperation that I would like to talk about briefly today relates to the jail that the ACT government says it is going to build at Hume, which is right on the border. The nearest population to that jail is, in fact, in New South Wales; it is not in the ACT. After pressure from ACT residents and voters, the ACT government decided to stick it on the doorstep of Jerrabomberra and Letchworth, where the people who will most likely be affected do not get a vote in the ACT. We have had an ongoing battle about this. Even though the land for the original preferred site for an ACT jail in the Majura Valley has been made available by the Commonwealth, the Chief Minister refuses to take up that offer and still wants to pursue this jail at Hume.

From a planning point of view, I have to question this. Taking the politics out of it, purely from a planning point of view I have to question the location. Anybody who comes into Canberra from either Jerrabomberra or Queanbeyan via the Monaro Highway or from Tuggeranong every morning would know the type and extent of traffic there. What the Chief Minister is proposing will put another set of lights smack bang in the middle of the Monaro Highway to give access to this jail, which would be an absolute disaster. It would also become the thing you would see as you left Canberra to head towards the mountains or the first thing you would see coming into Canberra from the mountains. I do not think it is the sort of thing that you want on a gateway, particularly when there are far better sites available. But the Chief Minister is determined to pursue this because it is in a location where he will get no flak from his voters or residents as none of them are nearby. The only neighbours are across the border. He is being a really bad neighbour over this, particularly given that there have been other options.

The most frustrating thing from my point of view is that I have constantly written to the Chief Minister about this issue since it started, but he has refused to reply to me. I wrote to him on 11 February 2004, after he made the announcement, when I received masses of leaflets from residents of Jerrabomberra and Letchworth opposing what he was doing. To this day, I still have not received an answer to that letter. On 20 February, the state member for Monaro, Steve Whan—a member of the Labor Party—and I, the federal member, wrote an unprecedented joint letter to the Chief Minister. We got a letter from Katy Gallagher, acting Attorney-General, thanking us for a letter to the Attorney-General. Yes, Jon Stanhope is the Attorney-General, but we did not write to Jon Stanhope as the Attorney-General; we wrote to him as the Chief Minister. We still have not had an answer from Jon Stanhope.

We went through other matters that had gone on for months with respect to the availability of the land in Majura. Consequently I held a rally at the end of August, and hundreds of people turned up on the Monaro Highway. I have never seen so many people turn up to something like that. I wrote to Jon Stanhope and told him about it in case he had missed it on the news. That letter was dated 7 September, and I still have not received an answer to it. I do not know what is wrong with me that he cannot write me a letter and defend his position, but he just will not write to me.

My constituents keep asking me what is going on with the jail, and I tell them that I keep writing to the Chief Minister but he will not answer me. Then, all of a sudden, I got a letter from the Chief Minister, which was written just before Christmas. He wrote to me asking for copies of documents under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. Although he had not responded to any of my correspondence, he wanted all documents that I might have in my possession on the decision by the Commonwealth to provide the land for his jail at Majura Valley, and he told me I should respond within so many days. He demanded a response from me immediately, but he still has not responded to my letter of 11 February, to the joint letter of 20 February 2004 or to the letter of 7 September. I wrote back to him in January and said that I would get some advice. He then wrote to me on 2 March and said: ‘You didn’t respond to me quickly enough. If you don’t give me these documents within 14 days, I’ll commence proceedings in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.’ The arrogance of the man! He has not even responded to my first letter, which I personally delivered to his office along with a big box containing well over 1,000 leaflets that had been returned by residents of Jerrabomberra and Letchworth opposing the location of this jail at Hume. And this is the sort of carry-on that we get.

I do not think that a jail in the ACT is necessary. We read in the paper just the other day that the ACT is in a bit of strife and looking at a tough budget. That is because the current ACT government have not created anything since they came to government. Their money, including record GST, has gone into all sorts of programs but they have never put it into any wealth creation for the region. They are going to spend $110 million on a jail, which I say they do not need. They currently send their prisoners to the various jails in New South Wales, and New South Wales is very happy to have them. Perhaps the ACT government think crime will be a growing thing and that this will be an economic activity for the ACT. It will not create anything in that respect, and it will continue to cost them more money. They would be far better off putting the $110 million into the hospital that they badly need—and I know the ACT Liberal Party proposed that before the ACT election. That would have been a much more sensible use of the money in a social sense.

The other option would have been to put that $110 million into a decent convention centre for the ACT, which would create some economic activity. Apparently the ACT government are going to spend about $40 million doing up the current Convention Centre, which all the experts say will be a bandaid measure. The ACT government ought to be creating some real wealth for the future, for example growing an industry rather than a jail. That is the sorry saga of what is happening at Hume.

I know that Defence adjoin this block at Hume, and I think they are not real fussed about having a jail next door to the fairly strong and important facility of HMAS Harman because it has certain telecommunications et cetera. I will say no more, but I do not think that they really want to have the jail next door. I do not think the jail is needed at all but it would be really nice if I could at least get answers to some of my correspondence on behalf of the residents I represent in this matter, who are certainly not pleased with the jail.

I notice that in parliament last night the member for Fraser, speaking in the debate on the appropriation bills, talked about planning issues in the ACT. Normally I might have some sympathy for some of the things that he said about this problem with the NCA, local planning et cetera, but when you see a local government acting in this quite irresponsible way from a planning point of view, I think in some respects it is just as well that we have the NCA to keep an eye on things.

I would have thought the NCA—and I have written to them—would have had a view about the entrances and exits to our nation’s capital. I agree with the member for Fraser inasmuch as the most important parts for the NCA are around the parliamentary triangle and those aspects, but I would think that the NCA quite rightly should have a very strong view about the entrances and exits to Canberra. To have a jail stuck on one of the major entrances and exits to Canberra is not good planning; it will be very poor planning if it creates incredible traffic problems—which it will. So they are some of the challenges in this area.

In the couple of minutes left, I will finish on a happier note for my electorate and that was the announcement that was made on the weekend in relation to age care places. We certainly have an ageing population, and in my electorate, particularly on the coast, we have a higher proportion of the aged population than in many other parts of Australia. We have seen a growth in numbers in aged care facilities and, fortunately, we have had some terrific growth in the number of facilities that we have and each year more and more places are provided by the federal government. We have had a terrific expansion over the last nine years.

That expansion has continued with the most recent announcement of a number of grants and additional places. I am particularly pleased with a number of them. In Cooma, the Sir William Hudson Memorial Centre, which is a high-care facility for seniors, was successful and received a grant of $1 million towards a quite large expansion which is really needed in the mountains. They were just ecstatic when I contacted them on Friday afternoon to let them know that that grant had come through, because it means that a very large expansion can occur. It is a community based organisation and the local community have put together substantial sums of money themselves. This grant means that that project can now go ahead. Also in Cooma, Yallambee Lodge, which is a low-care facility, was successful and received $850,000 to assist its further expansion. It was also given eight low-care places in this announcement. Once again, it is a community based organisation and it does a fantastic job there.

In Bombala, one of the smaller towns in my electorate, there are a lot of people who want to stay in their town when they get to the point of needing to go into an age care facility. They do not want to have to move to Canberra or to Sydney or elsewhere. They have a wonderful facility there, Currawarna Home for the Aged, and it was also successful and received $1 million in grants to enable expansion of that facility and 10 low-care places. Once again, the local community do a fabulous job in looking after that facility. In addition, Nullica Lodge down in Eden received $768,000. They got a grant of $1.3 million a couple of years ago, and they have had the most amazing muck around, mainly because of state government regulations with bushfires and other things. What they have had to go through has been just incredible.

As a consequence, the costs of expansion should have cost less than $2 million but they are probably now closer to $3 million. The additional $768,000 will help Nullica Lodge to get that facility going. We also had some additional places in Queanbeyan for Kawaree Lodge—seven additional low care places—and a new service down at Batehaven, Batemans Bay, which is really growing quite substantially. We have a number of great aged care facilities there, but there will be a new service: Glen Residential Care Centre. Twenty-four high care places and 38 low care places have been provided for that particular service at Batehaven. These are excellent additional facilities for the aged in Eden Monaro. We are really looking after the people who have been great pioneers for our region and allowing them to stay in our region as they get on in years. I thank the Minister for Ageing for those particular grants.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and cognate bills to speak on the threats to human communities and their economies from climate change brought on by global warming and the measures that need to be put in place to address this truly paramount issue. I speak at a significant moment when the international treaty framework that has been developed to address global warming, the Kyoto protocol, has come into force around the world. Despite being a party to the treaty negotiations—and, in fact, gaining a considerable advantage through the so-named ‘Australia clause’ which saw Australia rewarded with a particularly achievable target; namely, 108 per cent of 1990 levels—the Howard government has subsequently walked away from the treaty. We are informed by the government that it is not looking at entering into global negotiations on climate change until 2012. Additionally, a number of government members have risen in the House and questioned the existence of the greenhouse effect and global warming.

speech.para: To someone who has recently entered the parliament and has heard the debate and seen the extensive amount of information about global warming that is available to anyone who takes an interest in this issue—and who, like many members of the public, has an awareness of the general consensus that has emerged backing the validity of likely climate change as a consequence of a warming planet—these views are alarming. It is true that there is a vociferous collection of sceptics and those supported by the fossil fuel industry who gainsay climate change, but the facts speak otherwise. The greenhouse effect as a theory was first mooted in the 19th century. It was first mentioned in Australia in the Australian Conservation Foundation’s publication Habitat in the 1970s. If one takes a step back and considers that the life-giving properties of the planet are maintained through our atmosphere, and that we inhabit a closed, delicately balanced system, that allows life to flourish and that has evolved over millions of years, then the case for global warming through a greenhouse effect whereby increases in gases emanating into the atmosphere resulting in less reflection of the sun’s heat off the earth with a concomitant rise in temperature within the atmosphere is well-made. Even more so are the facts—significantly the parts per million of carbon dioxide have increased from around 200 to 380 parts per million over the past 100 years.

The huge increase in human population and corresponding production of pollution and assorted greenhouse gases by motor cars, power stations and so on makes such a phenomenon very likely. To argue against its existence is akin to arguing that a lack of rain does not cause drought. Still some on the other side fulminate against science and available evidence, and the government itself has maintained the position that to bring the treaty into law would harm the national interest. Doubtless one reason for this harks back to the original consideration by the Howard government of an ABARE report from around 1997 on the economic impacts of containing climate change. That report claimed that the economic damage to Australia would be great. Members of the House may not be aware that participation on the steering committee that provided the economic models which informed this report was possible only for those organisations who were invited and paid for the privilege at a cost of some $50,000. The consequence was a report which was one-sided, dominated by the views of the fossil fuel industry. Alternative views, including those of non-government organisations, were blocked. If you could not pay, you could not say anything about this issue. The then Commonwealth Ombudsman found that ABARE had breached Australian public sector standards and recommended guidelines be drawn up to cover the use of private money by public agencies. Times have moved on since then, but the position of the government is unchanged and there remains much confusion amongst members of the government on this issue.
Mr Greg Hunt, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, said on 7 December 2004:

quote.para: This is an agreement which is not equitable, which does not address the needs of the environment and which threatens Australian jobs.

speech.para: But the Prime Minister had said earlier ‘we achieved a win for the environment and a win for Australian jobs’. On the day the treaty came into force, energy Minister Macfarlane was quoted as saying:

quote.para: Whether or not these emissions are causing climate change or not, I don’t know. If you go back across history millions of years, carbon dioxide levels go up and down and global warming comes and goes ...

speech.para: But Senator Ian Campbell, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, to provide some clarity, said:

quote.para: ... it is important that we understand that climate change is not something that can be left open to debate.

speech.para: The minister for the environment at least had that part right. The Sunday Telegraph calls 2004 ‘the Year of the greenhouse’. As temperatures continue to rise, with 1998, 2002, 2003 and 2004 the hottest years since measurements began, NASA climatologist James Hansen says simply:

quote.para: There has been a strong warming trend over the past thirty years.
