speech.para: But more than that is the fact that global warming affects all the constituent parts of the ecological fabric of the planet: rivers; oceans, which are warming; atmosphere; habitat; glaciers; and coral reefs. Professor Sir David King, Chief Scientific Adviser to the United Kingdom government, put it thus:

quote.para: There is no bigger problem than climate change. The threat is quite simple, it’s a threat to our civilization ...

speech.para: We are witnessing an enlarging, ominous pattern that will consume us unless we act resolutely. As I said in my maiden speech, whilst the Howard government fiddles, we in Australia burn.

Critically, our continent, with its greater climate variability—the land of droughts and flooding plains we love and know well—is comparatively more exposed to global warming. The predictions by the CSIRO that some regions, like south-western Western Australia, will be more prone to drought, are coming true. This region can fairly be called one of the world’s first climate change regions. Rainfall there has dropped by 20 per cent over the past three decades.

The impacts of climate change are many and manifold. They include threats to supplies of drinking water for many in the poorest nations, as well as the citizens of Western Australia. Coral reef collapse and rising sea levels are a problem already in the minds of our low-lying Pacific neighbours. I will come back to that later. Positive feedback loops develop that exacerbate the global warming trend and, of course, the likelihood of an increasing tempo of species extinction. Still the Howard government ignores the significance of increasing data and predictions on this issue, despite the fact that we have a great deal to lose with the advent of a hothouse world.

The essential argument is still made by the government that Kyoto, a modest platform for international greenhouse gas reductions, will destroy our economy. It is an argument without merit and exposes the government to the charge that it is incapable of appreciating the true threat to the national interest—and the international interest—that lies in stalling on global warming. The Kyoto Protocol Ratification Advisory Group considered this question. The committee included Peter Duncan, former Chief Executive Officer of Shell, and former Liberal leader John Hewson. Its findings were simple: there would be no adverse impact to our economy if Kyoto were to be ratified. Indeed, if we had access to the trading mechanisms under the Kyoto protocol, the costs of compliance would be significantly less.

Criticism of Kyoto tends to focus on its effectiveness, the likelihood of its realising its ambitions and the flaws, imagined or otherwise, in its processes. Some of these criticisms have legitimacy, but they miss the central point: an international framework is a preliminary but essential step in addressing global warming, and there will be of necessity a suite of policies and practices, additional to simply signing on to the modest reductions under Kyoto, which countries will need to adopt. Kyoto is not the endgame, but it is surely the beginning. The modest reach of Kyoto will need to be greatly expanded in time, but the platform for future action will be based on the world’s economies operating in the framework of the Kyoto protocol—something this government has simply ruled out.

What about the likely economic impacts of global warming over time? The Financial Initiative report of the United Nations Environment Programme, UNEP, recently calculated that the economic costs of global warming are doubling every decade. Using historical data from reinsurance giant Munich Re and assuming that current trends continue, by 2065 the economic costs of natural disasters and an increasingly volatile climate will exceed that total world output. It has been estimated that a two degree centigrade to 3.5 degree centigrade increase in temperature in a country like India would result in a decline in farm revenues of nine per cent to 25 per cent. Clearly, for those in the farming communities in south-western and south-eastern Australia, the effect of likely drought as a result of climate change, and its impact upon stock in particular, will impose a great cost.

Meteorologists believe that variations in extreme weather typically associated with the El Nino cycle are also likely to become more common and more intense with increased global warming. The last strong cycle, in mid-1997, continuing through 1998, had a major global impact. Estimates of global loss range from $US32 billion upwards. That is very costly. UNEP reports that the number of people affected by global environment disasters driven or exacerbated by global warming has increased to over two billion in the last decade, with economic losses in the 1990s amounting to $629 billion from this issue alone.

The World Health Organisation, UNEP and the world meteorological program report that at least 150,000 people die unnecessarily each year as a direct result of global warming. The AMA has repeatedly warned of the impacts on air quality, particularly in the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne, and the consequent increases in respiratory diseases people will suffer in these regions. Malaria, which is already the second leading cause of death in the world for five-year-olds to 14-year-olds, is also expected to reach higher levels because of climate change.

In our region of the South Pacific we have seen a significant increase in the number of people affected by disasters in the last 30 years. For example, Fiji receives around $US30 million in aid annually, but about 25 per cent of donor projects are in sectors which are potentially affected by climate change. Previously in the House, I read some of the words that introduce the Otin Taai declaration, produced by the Pacific Churches Consultation on Climate Change. People met in the small island state of Kiribati during March 2004. I know that members opposite have a keen interest in the health of church communities, so I will read from the Otin Taai statement:

quote.para: Here on the small island atoll of Kiribati, the impacts of human-induced climate change are already visible. The sea level is rising. People’s homes are vulnerable to the increasingly high tides and storm surges.

speech.para: But in recent meetings of the South Pacific Forum, when member states sought to raise this issue and the prospects for their citizens, the Australian government shut down debate. Shame!

At a basic level, it is clear that global warming is of a size that threatens to reverse human progress—in the case of our responsibility to the human community, making unattainable the international targets on halving global poverty by 2015, known as the Millennium Development Goals. The future under the Howard government is grim. As land clearing emissions stabilise at a low level over the next few years, Australia will be responsible for a rapid increase in energy related emissions, leading to a total rise in greenhouse emissions. We will clearly exceed the parameters of Kyoto down the track unless urgent action is taken. According to the Australian Greenhouse Office, greenhouse gas emissions will actually increase by 23 per cent by 2020.

What should the government be doing? It should implement a national target and plan to reduce greenhouse emissions by at least 60 per cent of 1990 levels by 2050, with a 20 per cent target by 2020 to show real progress. We already have the likelihood of a one per cent increase in global temperature, but to avoid an increase in temperature of two per cent—which climate scientists call the ‘tipping point’—industrialised countries need to reduce their emissions by 60 to 80 per cent by 2050. That is the current state of play. In 2003, Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged that the UK government would cut its emissions of CO, the main greenhouse gas, by 60 per cent by 2050. A commitment to set a national target in Australia would help to avoid the worst impacts of climate change and allow this country to innovate and to begin to develop a low emissions economy.

We need short- and long-term targets that provide an overall framework which allows industry and the economy as a whole, including the skills and job space, to adjust within a reasonable time frame. This means that industry can plan with certainty, in the course of normal capital replacement cycles, and it allows for the encouragement of new technologies, new industries and innovators to come forward to meet the challenges we face as a nation experiencing global warming. What is stopping action by this government? For example, the Clean energy future for Australia report concluded:

quote.para: The barrier to … [a 50% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions from the stationary energy sector by 2040] is not that the clean technologies cannot produce enough energy at relatively affordable prices, nor is it that the cleaner fuels are not available. The barrier is a lack of achievable policies and strategies for facilitating the transition to new fuels and commitment by decision-makers.

speech.para: Proposals advanced by progressive business and conservation organisations with a mandate and an interest in this issue have demonstrated that a 20 per cent cut below 1990 targets by 2020 requires emissions to be cut by approximately 108 million tonnes. As an example, the following initiatives will achieve over 90 million tonnes of savings: reductions from the land use change and forestry sector, which in 2002 contributed 29.2 million tonnes; in the stationary energy sector, 40 million tonnes can be saved by replacing coal fired power stations of 40 years of age or older with a mix of combined cycle gas plants and wind power; four million tonnes can be saved by the uptake of cogeneration by large industrial users of thermal energy; four million tonnes can be saved by approximately 50 per cent of residential dwellings using solar hot water. Energy performance codes currently in place are expected to save seven million tonnes by 2010—this saving could be increased substantially with stronger mandated standards for the period 2010-20.

Of course, national leadership is required. The current lack of a national framework to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is creating business uncertainty and leading to a proliferation of disparate policies and measures at state and federal levels. As the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce said in 2003:

quote.para: To deliver substantial, least cost greenhouse gas abatement it is essential that a national approach be applied. The effect of piecemeal measures is that certain industries, dependent upon location and output, will bear a disproportionate cost burden placing pressure on their domestic and international competitiveness.

speech.para: In order to remove uncertainty, national leadership must be provided by the federal government to establish a price on the pollution of carbon dioxide. By putting a price on greenhouse pollution, we can ensure those responsible for causing greenhouse pollution will pay for the environmental damage that it causes. Revenue from a carbon levy, for example, can be used to fund tax cuts or to increase spending in non-polluting practices. Numerous industrialised countries have now introduced a carbon levy or are about to do so, including Denmark, France, Norway, Sweden, the UK and Germany. Alternatively, an emissions trading scheme with a cap on carbon dioxide emissions could create an economic incentive and reward for companies to reduce greenhouse levels. Providing the necessary stimulus would necessitate legislating a stringent greenhouse gas trigger in the Environment Protection Biodiversity Conservation Act. That, of course, is Labor policy.

Setting targets of the order needed to rein in global warming will require a large increase in the share of electricity coming from renewable energy such as wind, sustainable biomass, solar-thermal, geothermal and other renewable sources. One study estimates that wind and biomass energy could supply around 50 per cent of Australia’s electricity needs by 2040. A strong mandatory target for renewable energy will ensure these technologies achieve a commercial critical mass to grow and expand beyond 2020. We estimate that an MRET target of 10 per cent by 2010 would be a job creator. Additionally, measures to increase Australia’s energy efficiency by setting a mandatory national target to reduce stationary energy use would be important.

Improving energy efficiency is recognised as an important and especially cost-effective way to reduce greenhouse pollution. The new solar power tower project near Mildura will cost less than a regular power station. It will require no fuel, will produce no pollution and will provide electricity 24/7 for a quarter of a million people in a city equivalent to the size of the city of Geelong, in Victoria. Indeed, a paper for the Ministerial Council on Energy concluded that energy efficiency savings could deliver a $1.8 billion benefit to GDP, creating around 9,000 jobs and reducing emissions from the stationary energy sector by nine per cent over 12 years.

There is a strong environmental, social and economic case for the federal government to play an important role by setting national directions and reducing greenhouse pollution from our cities and towns. The policies that I have mentioned today, identified by any number of organisations and entities and well supported by the public, would help put Australia on the path to delivering the significant reductions in greenhouse emissions that scientists say are necessary to prevent the worst impacts of climate change. We owe nothing less to the generations that follow.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and the associated legislation because I believe the Howard government has done more for the people of the Gold Coast and the people of Australia than any previous Australian national government. In particular, I am pleased to say that, thanks to the economic responsibility and the good economic management of the Howard government, all Australians have benefited as a consequence of record low unemployment, record low interest rates and the fact that under this government we have now had nearly 14 years of continued economic growth. In summary, the Howard government has provided in a very meaningful and real way for all Australians—for those Australians who are trying to pay off their mortgage, for those Australians who are trying to get an education and for those Australians who are trying to get a job. In every one of these key respects, the Howard government has ensured that all Australians are materially better off today than they were when this government was first elected in 1996.

speech.para: I would like to focus on some of the benefits that have flowed to the people of my electorate of Moncrieff and more broadly to the people of the Gold Coast. Under the Howard government, there have been a number of key areas in which the people of the Gold Coast have significantly benefited, thanks to a number of policy initiatives that the government has taken. These are policy initiatives that are only possible thanks to the strong budget surplus this government has run since 1996 and thanks to the economic responsibility which has delivered record economic growth now for, as I said, nearly 14 years.

I will focus on some key aspects of federal government policies. Of particular concern to the people on the Gold Coast is our principal industry, the tourism industry. The tourism industry is the lifeblood of the Gold Coast, accounting for some 37 per cent of our local economy when one considers both direct and indirect inputs flowing from tourism. The tourism industry suffered significantly for a large while as a consequence of what I call the three horses of the apocalypse for the tourism industry: the collapse of Ansett, the SARS epidemic and, most disturbingly, the attacks on September 11. These three issues, in particular, were of great harm to the tourism industry across Australia and were felt very strongly by the people of the Gold Coast. We also saw the slow decline of Japan over the past decade, which has seen a record fall in the number of Japanese tourists—who were traditionally amongst the most prosperous and influential tourists coming to Australia, thanks to their generally longer periods of stay and higher levels of average daily spending while they were in Australia.

In every respect, the future of tourism on the Gold Coast is looking a lot brighter. We now have a resurgence of Japanese tourism which has been funded, in part, by virtue of the fact that the Howard government has provided record additional funding to the tourism industry. We have also seen the restructure of Tourism Australia. We have seen, for example, the incorporation of the Bureau of Tourism Research and See Australia. They are all now under the umbrella of Tourism Australia. This restructure at a national level means that people on the Gold Coast can take great stock in the fact that the Howard government has, under its white paper, a 10-year plan for tourism—a long-term plan that is delivering real results and record numbers of new tourists to the Gold Coast, including a greater number of domestic tourists to the Gold Coast. Each time an international tourist or a domestic tourist comes and visits our fair city it means more money in the pockets of ordinary Gold Coasters, and this is a great shot in the arm for our local economy.

Of course, it does also present some challenges. In this regard, the Gold Coast faces a number of unique challenges that are not felt in other parts of Australia. Principal among them is the fact that the Gold Coast is the fastest growing region in Australia. As a consequence of this rapid population growth, we as a city face a number of challenges, not least of which is investment in infrastructure. On this point I would like to draw some stark contrasts between infrastructure investment under the Howard government and the absolute lack of investment in infrastructure by the state Labor Beattie government. When it comes to investment in infrastructure, as I said, because the Gold Coast does have such a rapidly growing population, there is a need to continually update and invest in infrastructure.

One of the key areas—and it was in fact an issue that I raised in my first speech—was the need in Gold Coast City for there to be more university places. When taken on average against the rest of the country, the Gold Coast faced a significant shortage of tertiary education spots. On average, it was calculated to be about 3,000 places short of the national average. After making continued and strong representations in this regard to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Dr Brendan Nelson, and arguing very passionately and strongly, together with my federal colleagues, that the Gold Coast needed a significant allocation of new university places, I was very pleased that we saw in last year’s announcement by Dr Nelson a record allocation of new university places to the Gold Coast. This allocation of new university places saw the Gold Coast campus of Griffith University receive the highest single allocation of new university places in the country. It is something that was certainly argued for and passionately believed in, but I am very pleased that the minister listened and, more appropriately, that the minister responded in such a true and meaningful way. It now means that we on the Gold Coast have a better chance than ever for our rapidly growing population and, in particular, for young people to be able to secure a job and be likely to stay on the Gold Coast.

Another key piece of investment in infrastructure on the Gold Coast by the Howard government was the allocation of a new medical school. This again has been an issue that our city has been fighting for for nearly two decades now. I was very pleased, having been a strong advocate for the need for our city to have a new medical school, to see the Hon. Kay Patterson allocate funded student places at that medical school. As I drive from my electorate office in Short Street in Southport, I am delighted to see, a mere 500 metres up the road, the now almost completed Griffith University medical school—seven storeys high—which will most certainly be an iconic institution in the health and medical precinct of Southport on the Gold Coast. This significantly represents a very substantial investment in infrastructure which, once again, provides unsurpassed opportunities for local students to secure a place to study medicine on the Gold Coast and, more than likely, to remain on the Gold Coast. A double injection of benefit flows from that: not only do local kids have a greater opportunity to study medicine locally but also, once they graduate, we are going to retain a higher number of doctors on the Gold Coast. That means that Gold Coasters will have increased access to doctors, which of course is always a great and positive thing.

In those two respects, these are some of the most significant investments that we have seen by the Howard government. But there has been more than that. When it comes to road and transport infrastructure, I am pleased that the Howard government has invested over $140 million in improving local roads, plus a one-off grant of $120 million to ensure that the Tugan bypass will be completed. Some people might ask: why is it a necessity for the federal government to invest $120 million of taxpayers’ money into a project that should be funded by the Queensland state Labor government? My response to that is that it is necessary because the Queensland state Labor government continually chooses to ignore the needs of the Gold Coast and to shirk its responsibilities with respect to investment, in particular, in road and transport infrastructure. A case in point would be the absolutely woeful state of affairs when it comes to public transport infrastructure on the Gold Coast. Compare and contrast the needs of the Gold Coast with those of Brisbane. The Gold Coast is now a city of some 500,000 people. Thanks to a subsidy from the state government, it has a public transport bus service. The size of the subsidy is a mere $6 million per annum. That is the contribution that the Queensland state Labor government makes towards public transport infrastructure on the Gold Coast, and I might add that it is a very lousy $6 million.

Let us contrast that to Brisbane—a city that is twice the size of the Gold Coast, granted—which receives hundreds of millions of dollars of subsidies from the state Labor government. I am at a loss to understand why Premier Peter Beattie would think it is appropriate to provide hundreds of millions of dollars of public transport subsidies to Brisbane—to fund the Queensland city rail network, to ensure that there is a ferry service and a bus service, and to invest hundreds of millions of dollars into new road transport projects in Brisbane—but not to put money towards the equally important needs of the people of the Gold Coast. I know that the people of the Gold Coast are waking up to the fact that the Beattie state Labor government is short-changing them. It goes further than that.

I have heard ALP members opposite raise concerns about changes the Howard government made to tertiary education policy. This is an interesting case in point. I often hear members opposite complain about the fact that we have given some tertiary institutions the opportunity to increase the HECS fees charged to students by 25 per cent. They wail and complain about how this is a disincentive to so many students who would like to go to university but refuse to be laboured with a debt and an increase in that debt of some 25 per cent as a consequence of Howard government changes to tertiary education. Yet the most expensive university course is still cheaper than it is for students to undertake vocational education at TAFE on the Gold Coast—and TAFE fees have to be paid up-front.

Despite all the rhetoric from the state Labor government and from the federal opposition here in Canberra that there is in some way a great injustice when it comes to tertiary education, they do nothing to support those students who would like to undertake vocational education on the Gold Coast. They ignore the fact that on the Gold Coast students have to pay some $5,500 per annum up-front with no assistance from HECS, whilst at the same time there is a small group of privileged students who go to university and are subsidised by taxpayers to the tune of approximately 75 per cent of the cost of their course of study. If that is not an injustice, I do not know what is. I do know one thing, and that is that students on the Gold Coast will continue to move away from the TAFE system and vocational education as a consequence of the policies of the state Labor government.

I would like to focus on a number of other areas in which the Howard government is providing support to local Gold Coast families. I note the time, so I will touch on these issues as rapidly as I can. One of the most important policy initiatives that I know receives widespread community support is the Work for the Dole program. The Howard government has provided over $7 million to fund the Work for the Dole program. This has allowed nearly 3,300 local young people to gain work skills, and to give something back to our community. Over the past four years I have been to many Work for the Dole projects. I can say with great sincerity that, at every single one of those projects, participants rave about the value they get out of undertaking those projects. They speak in glowing terms about how much they enjoy the projects and about the fact that they believe they are gaining real skills and a true insight into what it means to work and to develop work habits. They feel a sense of pride at their accomplishments in the local community. More often than not, they can drive past those projects in subsequent months and know that they have been involved in creating something for the residents of the Gold Coast, and more broadly for the people of Australia, through their involvement in Work for the Dole.

There has also been an investment of more than $11 million in local environmental projects, including the restoration of the Federation Walk at the Spit—a project that I have been closely involved with. This is a very important project, as it is one of the last remaining areas of sand dune vegetation on the Gold Coast. I am very pleased that the people of the Gold Coast can now, through an investment of some $11 million, enjoy Federation Walk, as well as other key environmental areas on the Gold Coast. Once again in this vein, may I say that I am disappointed that, after all this money and after the investment of hours of hard work by local communities on the Gold Coast, the Spit should be under threat by the Beattie state Labor government, who intend to put a cruise ship terminal at the end of it. At a time when the federal government is providing funding to ensure that there are opportunities for the people of the Gold Coast to enjoy one of the last sand dune vegetation remnants on the Gold Coast, an area that is generally regarded as having very high levels of development, the Queensland Labor government is threatening that by proposing to put a cruise ship terminal in the actual area that we are trying to protect. A terminal would have thousands of tourists passing through that area, with a need for greatly enhanced infrastructure—in particular, a wider road, with higher levels of traffic, through an area that is considered so environmentally sensitive that the federal government has been putting millions of dollars into trying to protect it, through direct funding as well as through Work for the Dole projects and dune revegetation projects.

More broadly the Howard government, through its private health insurance rebate, has facilitated access to private medical insurance for one in two local residents. This has eased significantly the pressure on the Gold Coast Hospital and has ensured that people have easier access to the public hospital system. Again, it stands in stark contrast to the efforts of the Queensland Labor government. At a time when the federal government is doing what it can to take some of the pressure off the public health system by having those who can afford to use the private system take up places in that system, the Beattie government is doing what it can to try to blow out the waiting lists at the Gold Coast Hospital by not making sure that there are sufficient services to meet the growing levels of demand on the Gold Coast.

In addition to the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate, the Howard government has also introduced an additional $7.50 payment to bulk-billing doctors, a payment which will apply to people on the Gold Coast. This means that people who have children or who have Commonwealth concession cards will now have increased opportunities to utilise the services of bulk-billing doctors. Again, this is something that I know is very well supported on the Gold Coast.

With respect to local apprenticeships, on the Gold Coast we have seen the investment of some $53 million to provide real jobs to over 6,750 Gold Coast residents of all ages. It is in contrast to the Labor Party’s previous efforts; it represents a 156 per cent increase in apprenticeships when compared to the legacy of the Labor government that was in power prior to the election of the Howard government.

The Howard government has a very proud record when it comes to assisting veterans and war widows. The Gold Coast has a significant veteran and war widow population—the fourth largest in Australia. I am very pleased to be part of a government that takes seriously its responsibility to thank and to continue to provide for those who were prepared to put their lives on the line so that we as Australians can enjoy the great democratic freedoms and responsibilities that we do enjoy, living in a nation such as Australia. In this respect, I am very pleased that 14,867 Gold Coast veterans and war widows share in around $293 million in pensions and benefits each year. In fact, our local veterans are now receiving an average 55 per cent more funding than they were under the Australian Labor Party. So there is an extra 55 per cent of funds going to local war widows and veterans. I know how important that money is to them and I know how important it is to them, and how much they recognise, that the Howard government understands the contribution that they have made in the past and is prepared to stand by them at a time when the Australian Labor Party would callously turn its back on them.

In addition to that, I am pleased that the Howard government has been able to put record amounts of funding into the cadet service. I was formerly an Air Force cadet, and I was very pleased with the exposure I gained as one. It instilled in me a sense of discipline, and I know that that is something that many parents are seeking for their children. In this regard, I am very pleased that $14 million is flowing through Defence spending to our local community, including some $424,000 towards cadet activities for Gold Coast youth.

When it comes to the elderly on the Gold Coast, I am very pleased that the Howard government has been able to deliver some $46 million for community aged care packages, as well as boosting residential aged care funding by a third. The Howard government has provided some $296 million to local aged care facilities, including increasing the funding by some $3,500 per resident.

In every one of these respects, it is clear that the Howard government has delivered in spades to the people of the Gold Coast. I am certainly pleased to be a strong advocate and ambassador for our city, the fastest growing city in Australia. People recognise the great benefits that flow from living on the Gold Coast, and they want to continue to enjoy the lifestyle benefits and the economic benefits. It is my responsibility, and I am in fact duty bound, to ensure they continue to enjoy those benefits by making sure this government continues with its strong and proud record of delivering locally for residents of the Gold Coast. Thanks to the Howard government, I can honestly say the people of the Gold Coast are much better off. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —When we speak of national security policy in 21st century Australia we think of a range of different challenges. There are the familiar challenges: the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction; the problem of territorial disputes across our region, as in the Korean peninsula, the Taiwan Straits and Kashmir; and the emerging challenge of Islamist terrorism in South-East Asia. Then there are the other, less familiar national security challenges: large-scale trafficking in narcotics, international organised crime and unlawful international people movements. And then there are the new challenges, principal among which is the challenge of internationally communicable diseases.

speech.para: Australia’s long-term national security depends on our government allocating appropriate resources to each of these challenges in order to provide for the safety and security of our people. My purpose today is to sound a warning in relation to the newest of our national security challenges, and that is the prospective impact of HPAI, highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, on the security of our wider region and therefore Australia. My purpose is also to begin to examine the extent to which the region is prepared for this contingency and how Australia in assisting in building regional capabilities, in addition to auditing our own, can help. My purpose is not to be alarmist but rather to be constructive about what has been done and what needs to be done.

What is avian flu? According to the US centre for disease control, avian influenza viruses are infectious diseases circulating among birds worldwide which are caused by various strains of the type A influenza virus, one of the three types of flu viruses, A, B and C. Type A viruses occur in a variety of animals. As wild birds, particularly waterfowl, are the main hosts for all subtypes of A viruses, they are believed to be the source of the type A flu viruses in other animals. Usually the wild birds that are the host to the virus do not get sick, but they can spread influenza to other birds. Infection with certain avian influenza A viruses, such as some H5 and H7 strains, can cause widespread disease and death among some species of domesticated birds. Low pathogenic forms of avian influenza viruses are responsible for most avian influenza outbreaks in poultry. Such outbreaks usually result in either no illness or mild illness—for example, chickens producing fewer or no eggs—or low levels of mortality. But when higher pathogenic avian influenza viruses cause outbreaks, between 90 and 100 per cent of poultry can die from infection.

In early 2004 a strain of highly pathogenic avian influenza, known as H5N1, swept across much of Asia, leading to the culling of 120 million birds. Influenza A viruses are normally seen in one species but sometimes can cross over and cause illnesses in other species. According to the World Health Organisation, the first documented infection of humans with an avian influenza virus occurred in Hong Kong in 1997, when the H5N1 strain caused severe respiratory disease in 18 humans, of whom six died. The infection of humans coincided with an epidemic of highly pathogenic avian influenza in Hong Kong’s poultry population, caused by the same strain. Extensive investigation of the Hong Kong outbreak determined that close contact with live infected poultry was the source of human infection. Studies at the genetic level further determined that the virus had jumped directly from birds to humans. Rapid destruction within three days of Hong Kong’s entire poultry population—estimated at around 1½ million birds—reduced opportunities for further direct transmission to humans. Most influenza experts agree that the prompt culling of Hong Kong’s poultry population probably averted a pandemic.

The total number of confirmed human cases of avian flu since the most recent outbreak in Thailand and Vietnam on 28 January 2004 is 55. Forty-two of those cases were fatal. There are indications that avian flu could be passed between humans, but it has so far not been proven conclusively. In one case in Thailand a girl and her mother both died, which indicated that the probable transmission of the virus was of that type. The girl’s aunt, who was also infected, survived the virus. UK virology expert Professor John Oxford has said that these cases indicated that the basic virus could be passed between humans and predicted that similar small clusters of cases would be seen again. It is not the only instance where it has been thought bird flu has been passed between humans. In 2004, two sisters died in Vietnam after possibly contracting bird flu from their brother who had died from an unidentified respiratory illness. In a similar case in Hong Kong in 1997, a doctor possibly caught the disease from a patient with the H5N1 virus, but this was never conclusively proven.

What is the risk of a pandemic? In a recent article in the New Yorker magazine, Michael Specter described a pandemic as the viral equivalent of a perfect storm. He said that there are three essential conditions for a pandemic which rarely converge and which are impossible to predict. First, a new virus must emerge from the animal reservoirs that have always produced and harboured such viruses—one that has never infected human beings and therefore one for which no person would have antibodies. Second, the virus has to actually make humans sick. Finally, the virus must be able to spread efficiently, through coughing, sneezing or a handshake. For H5N1, the strain of avian flu found in Thailand and Vietnam last year, the first two conditions have been met. It is new and it is deadly.

Pandemics are not new to the 20th century. The great influenza pandemic of 1918-19 known as the Spanish flu caused an estimated 40 million to 50 million deaths worldwide and infected hundreds of millions of other people. In the US it took more lives than all combat operations in the 20th century. In Australia it led to 11,500 deaths. And remember that this was in the days before international travel on the scale we see today. According to the WHO, the world generally experiences three or four pandemics a century. Most scientific experts agree that another influenza pandemic is inevitable and possibly imminent.
On 12 November 2004, Michael T. Osterholm, director of the University of Minnesota Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy, warned:

quote.para: There are disquieting signs that the H5N1 virus circulating in Asian poultry flocks could do as much damage to humanity as the ‘Spanish flu’ virus of 1918 ...

speech.para: Dr Osterholm has warned that the avian flu virus could trigger a pandemic ‘if it acquired the ability to spread easily from person to person’. In particular, he warned:

quote.para: At minimum, assume we will not have a vaccine in the first 6 to 8 months of a pandemic.

speech.para: Dr Osterholm estimates that a 1918-like virus arising today could cause as many as 177 million deaths around the world. On 21 February this year, Dr Julie Gerberding, head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said that the avian flu was the world’s number one health threat. She stated:

quote.para: This is a very ominous situation for the globe ... We are seeing a highly pathogenic strain of influenza virus emerge to an extraordinary proportion ... The reason this is so ominous is because of the evolution of flu ... You may see the emergence of a new strain to which the human population has no immunity.

speech.para: Dr Gerberding has also said:

quote.para: I think we can all recognise that a similar pattern probably occurred prior to 1918.

speech.para: Shigeru Omi, Regional Director for the West Pacific Region of WHO, at a WHO conference in Thailand on 26 November, said:

quote.para: I believe we are closer now to a pandemic than at any time in recent years. There are a number of reasons for this, but the three basic ones are as follows: First, the extent of the current outbreak in poultry is historically unprecedented in terms of its geographical spread and impact. So far, more than 120 million poultry have died or been destroyed. Despite the intensified efforts of affected countries, there are indications that the disease may remain entrenched in this part of the world. The second reason for concern is that history has taught us that influenza pandemics occur on a regular cycle, with one appearing every 20 to 30 years. On this basis, the next one is overdue.

speech.para: Finally, on his resignation as US Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services on 3 December 2004, Tommy Thompson warned of the possibility of a global flu outbreak. He lamented there was still not a vaccine for the avian flu and criticised Congress for not approving more money to tackle the disease. He said:

quote.para: This is really a huge bomb out there that could adversely impact on the health care of the world.

speech.para: What are the international responses to date? The three relevant organisations are the World Health Organisation, the WHO; the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation, the FAO; and the World Organisation for Animal Health, the OIE. The WHO has been playing a key role, providing impartial guidance to countries at risk on scientific research and development and national and global action for influenza control, coordinating virological and epidemiological influence control and surveillance, and in assisting affected countries implement identified priorities in preparation for the next influenza pandemic—including through the development of vaccines and the vaccination of those who have had close contact with poultry. The FAO has also been active in assisting countries to build their own surveillance and early warning systems, establishing contingency plans, and building a global information system for disease monitoring. The FAO also plays a role in promoting research on disease control and eradication methods.

In April, the OIE is planning to launch a new worldwide Avian Influenza Network, which will facilitate collaboration with the WHO on issues related to the animal-human interface, develop and harmonise research projects on avian flu in different parts of the world and offer veterinary expertise and new skills to affected countries to assist in the control and eradication of avian flu.

In the US, the Center for Disease Control and Prevention has developed an International Emerging Infections Program to deal with the emergence of precisely the kind of threat posed by avian influenza. The program, based in Thailand, has been described as a kind of radar defence system for microbes. It was created in response to the emergence of unexpected viral infections, particularly animal illnesses that infect humans and make them sick. Because these types of viruses inevitably emerge in Third World countries, the program was based in Thailand. Mark Simmerman, from the CDC, described the rationale behind the program as follows:

quote.para: ... the feeling was that maybe if we were out there with our ear to the ground, listening and watching, we might be able to catch something before it’s too late.

speech.para: What are the implications for Australia? A total of five outbreaks of avian flu have occurred in Australia so far, with the last occurring in New South Wales in 1997. Each outbreak was quickly eradicated, but in every case there was evidence of contact between farmed poultry and water fowl. Migratory water fowl are thought to be one of the main means of spreading bird flu viruses between continents. AQIS has conducted surveys of wild birds which have confirmed that various strains of avian flu do circulate among wild birds in Australia.

The Australian government’s efforts to combat avian flu have included, firstly, efforts by AQIS in relation to the disease surveillance program, including baggage screening for passengers arriving from Asia, and the seizure of all poultry products such as meat, eggs and feathers. International mail is also being screened and poultry from ships’ stores confiscated. Secondly, there are farm biosecurity measures designed to prevent contact between commercial poultry and wild birds by protecting feed and water supplies, limiting entry to farms and physically isolating the poultry. Thirdly, there has been the development of an Australian veterinary emergency plan to deal with a variety of animal health crises, in line with OIE guidelines. The plan includes a proposed response for an outbreak of avian flu in Australian birds.

The bureaucratic mechanisms which have been established across the country for dealing with infectious disease outbreaks include: the Office of the Commonwealth Medical Officer; the Australian Health Disaster Management Policy Committee; Communicable Diseases Australia, a branch of the Department of Health and Ageing; Emergency Management Australia; Communicable Diseases Network Australia; and the National Influenza Pandemic Action Committee, a committee formed in 2003 to plan for pandemics and monitor avian flu.

Some avian flu specific measures were announced in the 2004 federal budget, including the stockpiling of antiviral medications, the expansion of the National Emergency Medicines Stockpile and the strengthening of detection measures at international borders. The challenge for Australia’s institutional arrangements in dealing with infectious diseases, influenza pandemic is one of effective national coordination. This, in turn, affects our capacity to enhance capabilities across the region. As the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Health and Ageing said to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade:

quote.para: Coordination is the key. You can plan for certain incidents but, generally speaking, surge is something that requires a national solution.

speech.para: According to the government’s framework for an Australian influenza pandemic, if Australia were struck by a flu pandemic today like the Spanish flu, it could expect at least 42,000 deaths per year, representing a 30 per cent increase in overall mortality rates. A significant outbreak in Australia would threaten our agricultural industry, trade, tourism, transport, business and economic growth generally.

On 28 January 2004 the Treasurer, Mr Costello, expressed concern that an outbreak of avian flu could have an impact on Australia’s tourism industry like the SARS virus did in 2003. The Asian Development Bank has also warned that the avian flu has the potential to cause overall losses of tens of billions of dollars in Asia and to have significant implications for the Australian economy. Treasurer Costello’s concerns about the potential economic impact of an outbreak of avian flu in January 2004 appear not to have been shared entirely by his colleague the foreign minister. Later that same month, when asked about the risk posed to Australia by avian flu, Mr Downer told radio 3AW’s Neil Mitchell:

quote.para: ... I’m not a scientist but, I suppose it’s conceivable it could come to Australia but I think that’s, frankly, a little unlikely and I haven’t been advised that there’s a real threat that it will come to Australia.

speech.para: Regrettably, I regard that as a statement of complacency. The government has announced that it will provide up to $1 million through AusAID to meet the immediate needs of regional organisations to deal with the recent outbreak of avian influenza virus in Asia. Up to $500,000 is being provided to the WHO to use Australian expertise in epidemiology, laboratory techniques, animal health, virology and public health in the affected countries. Funds will also be used to purchase equipment and laboratory supplies. Guidelines and training materials will be produced and translated into local languages.

But $1 million provided through AusAID, while better than nothing, does not represent a comprehensive strategy to deal with the potentially devastating effects of an outbreak of avian flu in our own region, our neighbourhood, our own backyard. Let us be clear about Australia’s interests in the event of an avian flu pandemic in Asia. Such a pandemic poses more than simply the devastating economic impact on Australian agricultural, tourism and transport industries that has been foreshadowed by the ADB and others. A pandemic of the proportions contemplated by experts would not only have serious economic ramifications for our regional neighbours but would also result in a massive loss of human life. If Dr Osterholm’s predictions are accurate, the death toll could reach 177 million worldwide. A human tragedy on this scale would make the aftermath of the tsunami look small indeed.

Despite Australia’s relative geographic isolation as an island state and the stringent border protection and quarantine regime Australia already has in place, the reality is that with up to 3.8 million people movements between Australia and Asia each year the risks of virus transmission represent a significant challenge for our national authorities. And, of course, the greater the extent of any pandemic in Asia, the greater the risk that the pandemic could spread to Australia. The government’s response to the threat posed by avian flu has been focused on preparing Australia’s response to an outbreak of the disease within our own borders. It is an open question whether the government’s domestic efforts to prepare for a possible outbreak of avian flu—including its biosecurity measures, quarantine controls and disaster management contingency planning—will prove to be adequate to combat an outbreak of avian flu in Australia. These are questions to be answered by the relevant domestic policy ministers, and in particular the health minister. It is also an open question whether the preparations within the region are adequate to deal with a future pandemic. This is a question of foreign policy as well.

I note that, in the wake of the SARS virus, APEC has established an ad hoc health task force to address health related threats to economies, trade and security. This is to be welcomed. The region needs, however, a comprehensive regional strategy to deal with the threat posed by avian flu. The strategy would include as a priority an urgent audit of the capacity of our neighbours in the region to detect, investigate, diagnose and report the virus. The strategy should demonstrate a detailed approach on how to manage and control any outbreak once detected. The countries at risk in the region need to do more to prevent an outbreak by improving biosecurity at poultry farms. This should include controlling the movement of personnel and the movement of birds that may contain the virus. Given the potential harm to Australia’s health and economic security, the government must demonstrate leadership within the region. A comprehensive regional strategy on avian flu would help Australia identify the gaps in regional capacity to deal with a future pandemic in our own region and enable us to target appropriate assistance through AusAID’s annual budget of $1.8 billion.

For example, there are fears that avian flu could spread through Indonesia reaching Papua province and then Papua New Guinea, bringing it much closer to Australian shores. In this context, Australia has a clear interest in doing more to ensure the preparedness of our closest neighbours—Indonesia, East Timor and Papua New Guinea—for an outbreak of the virus. Robert Webster, who holds a chair in virology at St Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis, was quoted in a recent New Yorker article. He has been studying avian influenza of the decades. Nobody knows more about the origins of the virus, how it changes or what those changes might mean. He is regarded as an international expert. He said, and I will conclude with his quote:

quote.para: “This is the worst flu virus I have ever seen or worked with or read about. We have to prepare as if we are going to war—and the public needs to understand that clearly. This virus is playing its role as a natural bioterrorist. The politicians are going to say Chicken Little is at it again. And, if I’m wrong, then thank God. But if it does happen, and I fully expect that it will, there will be no place for any of us to hide. Not in the United States or in Europe or in a bunker somewhere. The virus is a very promiscuous and efficient killer. That much we have known since 1997.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to debate Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 2004-2005, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2004-2005. In addition to the usual funding allocation for parliamentary departments, these bills are needed to begin paying for some of the reckless spending undertaken by the government to secure their fourth term. I would like to use my time here today to highlight some of the areas where I believe the government have misallocated their funds and set wrong priorities. I would like to begin by adding my name to the growing list of people who are concerned about the effect some of the government’s more flamboyant spending will have. I am particularly concerned about the effects on families in my electorate. A brief look at the budget of a family in the electorate of Canberra will reveal a familiar pattern of expenses: mortgage repayments, car repayments, child-care costs and private health insurance are all common features. Taxpayers have been given the nickname of ‘Howard’s battlers’. The Prime Minister can be especially proud of that nom de plume right now because, thanks to him and his government, battling is exactly what many of them are now doing.

speech.para: During the last election campaign the Prime Minister and the coalition parties campaigned on one central issue and one central promise or undertaking—that a Liberal government would keep interest rates low. The Prime Minister toured the country with the words ‘keeping interest rates low’ etched into his plastic podium. Negative attack adds cluttered our airwaves with half truths and accusations designed to scare people paying off large mortgages. Throughout the campaign the Prime Minister’s spin doctors were always ready with statistics quoting the amount of extra money families would supposedly pay each month if a Labor government were elected. Voters everywhere were led to believe that a re-elected Howard government would not put upward pressure on interest rates. This was despite Labor election promises being dwarfed by the coalition’s $66 billion spending spree. Now that the election is behind us and the dust has cleared, the podium has been packed away—perhaps in the same place as that famous debt truck, wherever that has been packed away. What about the Prime Minister’s promise? How does the government plan to keep interest rates down? Simply put: maybe it cannot.

Now we are faced with another tap-dancing act from the Prime Minister as he tries desperately to make the Australian people forget that once again he promised something which he probably cannot deliver. Now he blames the Reserve Bank, he blames the world economy and he tries to explain away the key promise of that election. This behaviour has become standard procedure for the Prime Minister. After four terms in office his pattern has become as predictable as the tide: say and do whatever it takes to win the election and then when called to account for his behaviour back-pedal, obfuscate and do whatever it takes to confuse the issue until it blows over. The Australian Prime Minister has shown no remorse, indeed he has stuck to his story on the airwaves, on television and here in this place, hoping against hope that the opposition and the Australian people will not remember that plastic podium and his latest non-core undertaking.

Australians paying off their mortgages are right to be afraid of a rise in interest rates. Personal debt has exploded over recent years under this government and even the slightest rise in interest rates will have a devastating effect on many families. The average size of a home loan taken out in December 2004 in the ACT was $234,600. Assuming a 20-year term and an interest rate of 7.05 per cent, the monthly repayment would be $1,826. At an interest rate of 7.30 per cent the monthly repayment rises to $1,861, which is a $35 increase. This is just the average. A quick glance at any real estate agent’s window in Canberra will tell you that it would very difficult to get a house for $234,000 here. For a young family paying off a house in Tuggeranong, in my electorate, the interest rate increase will have a real impact on their weekly finances. The price of the government’s re-election has to be paid for by someone. Unfortunately, it appears that the cost will be borne by those who are probably least able to afford it.

I now turn to the issue of private health insurance, which sadly balances very well against the issue of interest rates. Private health funds recently received the green light from the federal minister for health to increase their fees, adding to the list of increased costs faced by families in my electorate and around the country. This increase is the highest since the Howard government introduced the private health insurance rebate and is the fourth consecutive annual rise. Canberra families will be forced to choose between paying almost eight per cent more for their private health insurance, choosing a lower level of cover or possibly dropping out of the private system altogether.

Along with the cost of insurance, the out-of-pocket costs that are not covered by the gap are increasing. The government can run as many publicly funded advertisements with pretty umbrellas—I remember them well—as they want, but the fact of the matter is that private medical insurance is becoming more expensive in Australia. The private health funds state publicly that an increase in premiums is needed to cover the rising cost of claims, hardly an unbelievable assertion considering the logic behind the government’s plan to get more and more people into the private system. They expected younger people who are healthy to take up private health insurance and, because they are healthy and rarely need to claim, the insurance company would have an increased profit because it would not have as many claims to pay. Then the company would take the profit from those younger folk who do not claim and use it to subsidise those members who claim more often or who claim for more expensive treatments. The problem is that when you hit them with interest rate rises, drive up personal debt and threaten their job security, these people are going to look for ways to cut costs from their budget. When faced with the choice between paying for school books and paying for health insurance, paying for health insurance is less likely to stay in the budget.

As the cost of private health insurance climbs, it will get harder for people to pay their premiums. As more and more people are forced, once again, back into the public hospital system, the pressure on our hospitals and GP clinics will increase and the gap between public and private treatment quality will continue to widen. I ask two questions: where does the health minister think the system is going and how far is he willing to let it go? The health insurance rebate came with promises from government that costs would be held down, that health services would improve. But what do I see? In my community, I see ever-increasing private health insurance costs and elderly public patients waiting months, if not years, for a hip replacement while their counterparts, who can afford insurance, are being treated sooner. It is a really serious issue: a two-tier system becoming a system of those who can afford treatment and those who have to wait. I call it a very unhealthy health system. It is something that I believe we all need to be very concerned about.

Another issue of concern which was talked about earlier today is child care. Child-care workers in Australia earn less than people in most other occupations. In November last year the ABS advised that child-care workers had an average full-time weekly wage of $424.10, which equals just over $22,000 a year. In January this year, after two years of hearings, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission finally approved an increase of $64.50 per week for qualified workers and $82.20 per week for diploma certified child-care workers. While the increased pay is obviously very welcome—and I applaud the AIRC on its long overdue decision—child-care workers’ wages are still amongst the lowest in the country.

Child-care providers in Australia are extremely dedicated to their work. They have to be. When you know that Woolworths will give you more money to pack shelves than the wage you receive for looking after children, you really do need to be committed to stay in the profession. Unfortunately, the turnover rate of staff of 27.5 per cent highlights the simple truth that commitment alone will not pay their bills. Members on my side of the House will continue to fight for better conditions for child-care workers in Australia, and I hope that the government will recognise the need for greater funding and start providing the level of support these people deserve.

As if the situation faced by healthy children in child care was not bad enough, I understand also that the Minister for Family and Community Services is planning to review the in-home care program which, amongst other things, provides care for profoundly disabled children who cannot be cared for by a mainstream service or facility. How on earth are these children supposed to receive the level of care they need if the government stops funding their carers? The answer is that families will be expected to pick up the extra burden. Parents that are already full-time carers and exist on the small amount of funding they currently receive will be stretched even further. At what point will this government recognise that being in power means you have a responsibility to all Australians and that the funds the government cuts affect people who deserve better?

Hard decisions have to be made in government—we all know that—but I would have thought that threatening to cut funding that benefits the families of disabled children was beyond the pale, even for the current executive. I would have thought that providing for our children was more important than dredging a creek to shore up numbers. I will reflect on that a bit further. In recent months, in the latter part of last year, I had the absolute privilege of visiting a small number of families that have a profoundly disabled young child. The pressure on those families—the costs involved and the way that the whole family ends up being involved in the care of that one little person—is enormous. What those families need is a government that will come in underneath them, support them and offer whatever it can, not a government that, for some ridiculous reason, puts pressure on them and threatens the funding that supports those families. I plead with the government to think very carefully before it goes down that road. It is a very dangerous trip to take. It is entirely unacceptable, and I would suggest unfair and un-Australian, to the families concerned.

In my reply to the Governor-General’s speech last month I spoke about the unfortunate comments of the Minister for Workforce Participation regarding coercing disability support pension recipients off the pension and into work. His comments were based on a pilot study that provided intensive assistance to DSP recipients that wanted to find work. The pilot study report is publicly available and has received coverage in the mainstream press. I will point out just a few problems with the minister’s argument. Almost half of the DSP recipients initially interviewed were excluded before they could participate in the program. Less than half of the pilot participants were placed in work or education. Of those lucky enough to be placed, only 22 per cent found full-time work, with 31 per cent being placed in part-time work, 39 per cent in casual employment and eight per cent beginning some sort of education program. While these figures may look promising at first glance, consider this: initially 1,130 people were met by the providers involved in the study. Of those 1,130, 239 had been placed in either work or education when the pilot study report was published on the department’s web site in December 2004.

The minister expects us to believe that, because 239 out of approximately 1,000 DSP recipients who wanted to find work and were enthusiastic enough to volunteer for the pilot, and believed they could do it were placed in some sort of work or education, all DSP recipients should be put under greater pressure. We have all heard of the carrot-and-stick analogy for motivation: reward those people who try to find work and punish those who try to play the system. Of course people with a disability would prefer to work. Of course they would prefer a life different from the one they have. Of course they wish to participate fully in our community, and many do despite their disability. Of course they should be supported in their endeavours. However, when I hear the Minister for Workforce Participation talk about using coercion to move people off the disability pension, it is difficult to see the future in a positive light. What is the real agenda here? Is it cost saving? Will it save money? Is it just deciding to wedge a particular group in our society for political purposes, to get on the back of people with a disability, or is there a real, honest, genuine reform agenda? I need the government, as do many people, to state its true claims in this regard.

The ACT is often described as a public service town. While it is true that many government departments are based here, Canberra residents hold a wide range of jobs and our economy is sustained by many industries. We have cooks, plumbers and lawyers; we have teachers, waiters and electricians. Canberra residents fill the same jobs found in any other inland city and will prosper or suffer along with the rest of the country after 1 July. Attacks on unions, job security, workers rights and the Industrial Relations Commission have already started and can be expected to increase soon after the Senate changeover. When the current government gains control of the upper house, I fear that residents of my electorate will find themselves in the firing line, along with many other Australians.

The industrial relations system is designed to protect the rights of Australian workers while allowing business to function. Minimum conditions and the minimum wage are based on hearings in front of the IRC and discussions between employee groups and employers. I fear that the time of basing these decisions on careful argument and the best interests of all parties is about to end. We hear members of the government suggesting that minimum conditions should be set at a national level. We hear members opposite expressing their belief that we should be legislating national standards independent of the IRC. Suggestions reported in the Sydney Morning Herald recently include cutting the number of workplace conditions determined by the AIRC to between six and 12, depending on who you ask. Once again the government is hoping that the Australian people will not look too deeply into its plans. There are already far too many Australians who have jobs yet exist below the poverty line. There are far too many people for whom the slightest financial squeeze will make a huge difference. The IR system is here to protect Australian employees, and now more than ever they need protection.

I note that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) contains extra funding for the Job Network. The Job Network will certainly grow if this government gets its way. The Liberal Party has continually made clear its intention to overturn unfair dismissal legislation as it applies to small business. Members on our side of the House, along with unions and employees set to have their jobs threatened, wonder how anyone could possibly be in favour of unfair dismissal and offer no protection.

The flow-on effects from the government’s IR reforms have the potential, in my view, to devastate families, local economies and the Australian culture as we know it. Instead of introducing legislation that blind Freddy can see is going to hurt employees and their families, why don’t we consider the following? Don’t take away job security when the economy is looking shaky and don’t believe for a second that workers rights in Australia were achieved through the random benevolence of employers. We need to really think where conditions for employees in this country came from. Rather than ridicule our history, we have to look carefully at how we can make our country better in the future rather than threaten it.

When you take interest rate rises, attacks on workers’ rights and the rising costs of health care and private health insurance and then throw in a slowing economy, the future is not quite as bright as we would like to see. With a greater amount of time, I could have covered many other areas that I believe need attention—for example, HECS increases, family tax benefit debts and effective tax rates that hinder welfare recipients in their attempts to move from welfare to work. These are just some of the subjects that have been canvassed by other speakers in this place and warrant further careful discussion.

I believe very strongly that this government needs to stop coasting on what it sees as its past accomplishments without recognising the massive economic reforms that took place under the Labor governments of Hawke and Keating—which is a statement of absolute fact, despite the present government’s arguments to the contrary. The government needs to stop squandering the opportunities provided by that history and to stop investing in Tumbi Creek dredging. It should be creating proper infrastructure in this country—real serious stuff that is going to have an effect on all of our families and all of our workers and on our economic prospects for the future. If we started to do that, I would have a far more positive view of the future than, sadly, I have at the moment.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and related bills. During the election campaign, the Prime Minister constructed a political campaign that gave the electors of this country the impression that interest rates would not rise under a Liberal-National coalition government. That was the subliminal message that the Liberal Party campaign pumped out only a few short months ago. Australia now faces the prospect of even higher interest rates and higher inflation, which is a direct result of the government’s complacency and sheer laziness. The government has always been aware of the skills shortages. The government has been aware of infrastructure bottlenecks. But it sat on its hands and has simply been smug, lazy and complacent.

speech.para: We have heard Treasurer Costello and Mr Howard continually deny that there is a problem with the current account deficit. They have blamed the situation on the dollar and the drought. The Treasurer would have us believe that the Labor states are the main contributors to the current worsening of the economy. He has set up a smokescreen to attempt to divert attention away from his incompetence by his outrageous claims that the states are in breach of the original GST agreement.

What the Treasurer has not said is that the Victorian state Labor government has exceeded its GST charter by abolishing financial institutions duty, quoted marketable securities duty and, from 1 July this year, bank account debit tax as per the GST agreement. In total, those tax cuts amount to in excess of a billion dollars a year. In addition, Victoria has abolished duty on non-residential leases, representing about $50 million or $60 million a year; abolished duty on unquoted marketable securities; and, last financial year, abolished stamp duty on mortgages, which alone represents approximately $230 million a year in savings for home owners.

The truth—something that this Treasurer avoids at all cost—indicates that by 2005 the states will undertake a series of other measures, including removing levies on quoted marketable securities, and also undertake to review bank account debit tax duties on leases, including on residential leases, duties on mortgages and stamp duty on business conveyancing—representing something in the order of $500 million per annum. As I said earlier, the truth is that the Victorian state government has already achieved—and in some instances exceeded—its requirements under the GST agreement and is well on the way to full compliance within the time frame set out in that agreement. Victorians this year will pay $9.4 billion in GST to the Commonwealth and will get back just $7.8 billion. The two states that drive more than two-thirds of Australia’s economy, Victoria and New South Wales, are penalised by this Treasurer’s method of distributing this huge Howard government GST rip-off.

And what a rip-off it is. What has worsened this appalling tax grab by the highest taxing federal government in our history is the squandering of over $66 billion of hard-earned taxpayer funds to buy their way back into government. We have already seen compelling evidence that the government used these resources to pork-barrel in their marginal and targeted seats. No doubt we will see more evidence over the coming months.

This could have been a good opportunity to start to address poverty, something more and more Australians are experiencing as a direct result of the Howard government’s economic policies. By any measure, poverty is a significant and growing problem in Australia. Over 2.5 million Australians are living below the poverty line. One million Australians have some work but not enough to lift them out of poverty. Labor is serious about tackling growing poverty and inequality. In order to put the spotlight on the issue and to canvass a range of solutions, the Labor Party established a Senate inquiry into poverty which concluded in March 2004, with a final report entitled A hand up not a hand out: renewing the fight against poverty. The report was tabled in the parliament last year. It represented the first thorough investigation of poverty and financial disadvantage in 30 years. It found unacceptable levels of poverty and hardship in our community. After 13 years of continuous economic growth, these outcomes should not be tolerated. In tackling poverty, Labor, as always, has committed itself to action, not just words.

Our nation needs to develop a whole-of-government agenda and a community action plan like that which Labor outlined for the 2004 election. The federal government should engage with state and territory governments, churches and community groups to develop a plan of action to tackle poverty. Former Labor leader Mark Latham wrote to all premiers and territory leaders last year to seek their support for a partnership—through the Council of Australian Governments, COAG—to pursue policies that would reduce the level of poverty we currently face. In July 2004, the then Leader of the Opposition and each of the state and territory leaders signed a communique committing to put poverty on the agenda of COAG. Labor had also agreed to hold a summit of political, church and community leaders to devise a national plan for tackling poverty. For years church leaders have requested that action be taken to address growing poverty in our community. Labor is the only political party that pledged to support such action.

The endless debate about poverty measures and poverty lines is used by those who try to deny there is a problem and a need for action. A future Labor government would be accountable for the level of poverty in our community. We are prepared to measure our efforts to tackle the problem. Labor committed to develop a comprehensive set of poverty reduction targets across all areas of government. The targets concern living standards, income poverty and income inequality; unemployment, long-term unemployment and employment security; skill and educational participation, attainment and competence; health status and access to health services; access to affordable housing; and available and affordable child care, aged care and disability services.

A future Labor government will again make a significant investment in services that assist in tackling poverty. For example, prior to the last federal election Labor announced $1.9 billion funding for health to boost Medicare and increase bulk-billing rates and $300 million for a Commonwealth dental scheme to provide up to 1.3 million additional dental procedures for people on low incomes; $2.4 billion funding for education, including an additional 20,000 university places and 20,000 TAFE places; and $1.4 billion funding for labour market and literacy programs and new affordable housing.

Affordable and accessible health care is essential in addressing poverty. For this reason Labor is determined to lift the bulk-billing rate from 67 per cent to 80 per cent so that every Australian can afford to see a doctor when they are sick. Poor dental health can cause other medical complications and it strips the unemployed of work opportunities and dignity. Labor’s national dental scheme would have ensured that people on low incomes did not miss out on basic dental health care. I will have more to say on dental care shortly.

Access to a decent education lifts children out of poverty, and post-school qualifications are the best safeguard against long periods of unemployment. That is why Labor announced a policy to boost the number of university places by 20,000 and the number of TAFE places by a similar amount. Labor also pledged to reverse the Howard government’s 25 per cent university fee hikes. Labor also pledged to provide rent assistance to students aged 25 and over receiving Austudy and to reduce the age of independence for Youth Allowance from 25 to 24 years. Labor pledged to invest $400 million to help secure affordable housing for low-income earners. This $400 million would have delivered an additional 11,350 new homes for low-income families and new housing partnerships aimed at delivering 9,000 units of affordable housing. Under Labor’s national strategy for housing, additional funding would have been made available for homeless people and for Indigenous housing projects.

Labor committed to a $700 million youth guarantee to assist young people who leave school early. Under Labor’s plan, all 15- to 18-year-olds would get support to either study at school, TAFE or university or be in a job or apprenticeship. Labor also committed to invest an additional $212 million in programs and support for the mature-age unemployed. Labor announced a commitment to a universal tax-free baby care payment for new parents which would have been indexed to net minimum wages.
