In addition to this payment, Labor announced an $80 million Read Aloud scheme which would have provided reading material for young children and access to literacy programs for their parents. Some $10.2 million was earmarked for playgroups for parents of young children and $33 million to fund 10,000 mentors for young Australians. Labor committed to providing more early childhood and preventative services to reduce the number of disadvantaged children who potentially end up becoming disadvantaged adults. Labor listened to the churches and front-line agencies like St Vincent de Paul, Anglicare and UnitingCare, who advocated for greater action in tackling poverty.

The Howard government committed one of its worst acts of vandalism when it abolished the former Keating Labor government’s Commonwealth Dental Health Program in 1996. It continues to ignore its responsibility to provide dental care for low-income Australians. The Howard government has a mean-spirited attitude towards low and medium-income families, especially those who reside in non-coalition electorates. Many Australians do not seek dental appointments because they simply cannot afford them. A national survey found that one-third of Australians in the $30,000 to $50,000 household income bracket had not been to a dentist for over two years, due to their inability to pay. Poor dental health means pain, inconvenience, poor general health, embarrassment and discrimination. Despite state governments’ increasing expenditure on dental programs, there is now a huge unmet demand for publicly funded dental programs.

In May 1998, the Senate Community Affairs References Committee report on public dental services found that when the Commonwealth Dental Health Program was abolished there were approximately 380,000 Australians waiting an average of six months for public dental care. By May 2000, that figure had blown out to half a million people waiting for between eight months and five years for public dental care. It has now blown out to over six years for clinics that service people in my electorate of Bendigo. The collection of national figures has since been scrapped so there are now no records kept at a national level.

Labor has always believed that Australia should use the prosperity that the coalition is always bragging about to help these people get the basic health and dental care they need and deserve. Labor had pledged to invest $300 million in Australian Dental Care, over four years. My colleague the member for Lalor was one of the architects of that great policy. I am sure it is a policy we will be happy to take into the next election as well. This would have resulted in $120 million per year for our program when it was fully operational. Labor agreed to work in partnership with the states and the territories to implement Australian Dental Care—a genuine partnership with the states and territories that would have delivered services to agreed national benchmarks. This would have provided up to 1,300,000 extra dental procedures for Australians, enough to clear the existing backlog and substantially reduce the waiting lists. Many people on the waiting lists for dental care are elderly. We can do better as a nation and a government to make sure that they have their suffering dealt with as soon as possible.

Labor’s plan would have revived Ben Chifley’s vision. He inserted an amendment into the Constitution in 1946 that said affordable dental treatment was as essential as other medical treatments. Dental care is a national responsibility—something the Prime Minister would have us believe he has discovered. The changes announced last year by the health minister are a weak attempt at a political fix in the run-up to the 2004 federal election. The Prime Minister has left Australia as a waiting list country with a waiting list government. The Howard government has allocated a miserable $5 million per year for four years, and only for dental patients with additional chronic health illnesses caused by their dental problems. These patients must suffer dental related chronic health problems for six months before they can get assistance. For pensioners and low- to middle-income earners this amounts to nothing less than torture.

Under Labor’s plan, the federal and state governments would have combined together in a great national effort to fix the dental health crisis. Under Labor’s plan, concession card holders—such as pensioners, health care card holders and their dependants—would have received free check-ups when they need them as well as subsidised dental treatments, restorations and dentures. Labor’s plan would also have assessed the dental health of every person admitted to residential care and put in place an action plan to provide ongoing care, something that Deputy Speaker Bronwyn Bishop would realise is badly needed, given that she is a former Minister for Aged Care.

On 28 June last year Frew abattoirs in Kyneton announced that they would shut down most of their operations, resulting in 150 employees losing their jobs. The company had succumbed to the pressure caused by large export abattoirs dumping excess export products onto the domestic market at a much reduced price. Frew Kyneton provided meat products totally for the domestic market. The company had always enjoyed a good relationship with their employees and the union, and the decision to scale down their operations was a bitter blow to the company, meatworkers and their families as well as the Kyneton economy. Kyneton meatworkers with families who received part of their termination payment in the previous financial year ran the risk of incurring substantial Centrelink debt under the Howard government’s unfair family payment system. Some former employees at Frew in Kyneton received part of their termination package in this financial year and obviously did not factor in the amounts when previously applying for family payment benefits under the current system. These workers could not have predicted the situation they found themselves in and, through no fault of their own, will have to pay back large sums under the government’s grossly unfair family payments system.

In letters to the relevant ministers and departments I requested some concessions be given, given these appalling circumstances. But I have now been informed that the Howard government, through the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration and member for Murray, Dr Sharman Stone, has rejected my request and refused to grant approval to waive these debts. This is yet another example of just how callous and unfair the Howard government’s family payment system is in its current form. These workers who have worked hard and under difficult circumstances have been penalised through no fault of their own because of this government’s mean spirited attitude to working Australians. This coalition government has about as much compassion as the Third Reich when considering the plight of Australian workers.

In conclusion, I want to take this opportunity to draw this parliament’s attention to a recent decision by the Australian Broadcasting Authority regarding an application to a test transmission from Strengthening Goldfields Community Radio in my electorate of Bendigo. They submitted an application to the Australian Broadcasting Authority for a temporary community broadcasting licence for the Maryborough community on 15 July 2004. A letter was received by the SGCR from the ABA on 15 September 2004 requesting more information about community support et cetera. A supplement to the application, including more support information, was submitted to the Australian Broadcasting Authority on 1 October 2004.

Notification was received from the ABA on 24 November 2004, via Telstra, rejecting the Strengthening Goldfields Community Radio’s application for a temporary community broadcasting licence stating that the frequency that SGCR proposed to use would interfere with Sunbury community radio. A letter to the Strengthening Goldfields Community Radio confirming the rejection of the application for a temporary community broadcasting licence was received on 17 January 2005. The reason given for the rejection is that the frequency identified by Strengthening Goldfields Community Radio has the potential to interfere with 3VYV Yarra Valley co-channel and government requirements for more ABC services in the area.

So this application was refused because, according to the ABA, it had the potential to interfere with another transmission emanating from miles away. All Strengthening Goldfields Community Radio asked for was permission to broadcast a low-powered test transmission to ascertain if the ABA’s decision was based on a fact, and it was refused. If ever there was a need for an investigation into an organisation, the ABA must be the perfect example. This organisation always seems to go out of its way to block worthwhile community initiatives and usually based on the flimsiest of evidence. It is time there was a worthwhile examination of its role to see if it is adequately serving the communities that it is supposed to.

talk.start.para: —I believe this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and related bills and the additional portfolio estimates for 2004-05 gives us an appropriate opportunity to review where the Howard government is up to with implementing its health policy platform. Before the 2004 election, people would have frequently heard me saying—in this place and also around the country—that the Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, was a political fixer, that he had been put in there to try and deal with the Howard government’s serious political problems in the health portfolio but that he lacked a vision for the longer term. It pains me to say that, surprisingly, I am now longing for the good old days when I could make that criticism of Minister Abbott. At least in the good old days—whilst I disagreed with what Minister Abbott was doing and whilst I thought it was all short-term, quick political fixes and fundamentally flawed—Minister Abbott was doing something. Now, post election, Minister Abbott has given up on health—his ideas and energies are elsewhere and he is doing absolutely nothing at all.

speech.para: For an insight into Minister Abbott’s thinking, I suggest to members in the House that they need to mark late January in their calendar as the time when they will receive the words from on high, from the hill—January is when Minister Abbott makes his annual address to the Young Liberals conference. Why Minister Abbott is always a speaker at the Young Liberals conference and other ministers do not appear to get a guernsey on the agenda is a matter about which I could only speculate. However, I notice that from time to time there is speculation in the media that it is something to do with numbers in the Liberal Party and recruiting. These are not matters for me to discuss, but I am sure they are things that members of the Liberal Party in the House might well have a view on. So Minister Abbott—year in, year out—turns up at the Young Liberals conference in January and he gives an address. On 18 January 2003 Minister Abbott—of course, he was then in his former portfolio as Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations—gave an impassioned address about the need to address the high effective marginal tax rates that people face, which discourage them from making the transition from welfare to work. It was an impassioned address, but in policy terms what actually happened? Unfortunately, the record shows absolutely nothing.

Then, in 2004, Minister Abbott came to give the address to the Young Liberals. At that stage he was the minister for health but clearly did not have a big health policy picture to outline to the Young Liberals. Instead, obviously inspired by having seen the Russell Crowe film Master and Commander: the Far Side of the World, he engaged in an address which somewhat heroically, you would have to say, and in a fairly laboured fashion, manages to compare the Prime Minister to Russell Crowe—not a comparison that would be top of mind in many people’s summary of the two. I do not think I have ever had anybody say to me that they found it difficult to work out which one was the Prime Minister and which one was Russell Crowe. Maybe there is someone who has laboured under that difficulty, but I have never met them. If there is someone who has laboured under that difficulty, then they would make a good friend for Minister Abbott, who said in this address:

quote.para: But if Crowe had played an Australian prime minister handling contemporary challenges in much the same way—

speech.para: that is, when he cuts a sailor down and loses his life to save the rest of the boat—

quote.para: it’s certain the moral guardians would have damned him for having blood on his hands, sacrificing another to save himself and looking after his influential mate rather than everyone else.

speech.para: We probably all remember the scene from the film and, if anybody chooses to get it out on DVD, I invite them to make the comparison between Russell Crowe and the Prime Minister and see how far they get.

Interestingly, the minister’s mind had turned back to federal policy by the Young Liberals conference this year—something for which I am sure we would all be grateful, given his ability to review films. In this, he manages to get out the following line of health policy. He says that he wants federal funding to be matched by federal control in a range of unspecified joint projects, beginning with hospitals. He specifically said:

quote.para: Once the Commonwealth Government is engaged in any particular area of responsibility, how can it avoid the demand to provide leadership? These questions are likely to consume a great deal of time and energy during the Howard Government’s fourth term.

speech.para: That was Minister Abbott in late January this year speaking to the Young Liberals conference, reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 January. So, there is Minister Abbott in late January filled with grand dreams about the Howard government, the federal government, showing leadership in the area of health, and this is going to be a grand project that is going to take much of the time and energy of the Howard government during its fourth term. Well, it was with some surprise that I found, basically a month and a day later, that Minister Abbott had completely changed his mind. The grand plan was abandoned—not the sort of stout resolve that I suspect Russell Crowe would have shown in comparable circumstances. Minister Abbott, in late January convinced of the need for a new grand plan for health, by late February—25 February to be precise—has come to completely the reverse conclusion. Minister Abbott, in his speech to the CEDA conference on that day, said the following:

quote.para: The Federal Government can’t make the states run their public hospitals better (at least during the life of the current Health Care Agreements). The Government can’t force private doctors, private hospitals and private health funds to act in their mutual self-interest if they’re determined to be hairy-chested with each other.

speech.para: There may be a small influence of Russell Crowe in that. He goes on:

quote.para: Often, despite the power of the purse, the Federal Health Minister is little more than a kind of constitutional monarch limited, in Bagehot’s words, to the right “to be consulted, to encourage and to warn.”

speech.para: We know that the question of constitutional monarchy is one that is always close to the heart of the current minister for health and, I know, it is close to the hearts of other members in this place. Whilst I do not share their view, I admire their enthusiasm for what inevitably will be a lost cause in Australian politics. But I do not think that I have ever heard a government minister before compare themself to being a constitutional monarch. Minister Abbott appeared to be having some sort of Princess Mary moment.

When Minister Abbott was having that Princess Mary moment, he was effectively saying that, even though he is the Minister for Health and Ageing, he is basically content to sit on the sidelines and do absolutely nothing; that he is going to be consulted and will perhaps encourage and warn but is not intending to act in any way, shape or form. I do not think the Australian taxpayers pay Minister Abbott as our Minister for Health and Ageing to be consulted, to encourage and to warn, and we already have Princess Mary, so we do not need a pale imitation. What we need is for Minister Abbott to do his job, which is to run the health system. But that is a job that he appears completely unwilling to do.

I wish for the good old days when Minister Abbott was at least doing something. Now he does nothing whatsoever. Let us go through the list of things that Minister Abbott is not doing. We know that he is not properly scrutinising private health insurance premium increases, because year after year—just as he did last week—he goes out for a press conference and with a self-deprecating shrug of the shoulders basically says: ‘All prices go up. C’est la vie; such is life. That’s very difficult.’ That is Minister Abbott’s approach. He does not actually do any of the things necessary to change the private health insurance system. He is full of criticisms of anybody who has a public policy solution to the sustainability of the private health insurance system. For example, he was very critical of Labor’s Medicare Gold policy, despite the fact that it would have decreased private health insurance premiums for Australian contributors by 12 per cent and would have saved $500 million a year in wasted expenditure because older Australians end up in public hospital beds when they do not need to be there.

Amongst the list of things that Minister Abbott is not doing, he is not doing anything about keeping private health insurance premiums down, even though the Howard government promised to do that—particularly at the 2001 election, when it actually promised to reduce premiums. Minister Abbott is not doing any of that. He is just standing by on the sidelines, shrugging his shoulders on cue. He most certainly is not doing anything to fix the fact that $500 million each year is wasted because older Australians end up in acute hospital beds when they do not need to be there; he is not doing anything about that.

His indifference to the task appears to be having an impact on the management of health issues by the department of health. During Senate estimates hearings only weeks ago the department confirmed that resources were being stripped away from areas such as GP research and work on quality and support for private health care. The secretary, Ms Halton, admitted to budget cuts in areas such as GP research and data collection and to declining support for quality initiatives in the private sector, but she managed to make a number of statements about ‘core business’ and doing the ‘important things’. One can wonder what the ‘important things’ are that the department is doing if it is not supporting GP research, work on quality and support for private health care and data collection. What is it that the department could possibly be doing that is actually an ‘important thing’ if it is not doing those things? We know that the department is not in the business of doing any modelling or policy development work, and it is increasingly not collecting data that would assist in those processes.

On the list of things that Minister Abbott is not doing is this: he is not reviewing the health system and working out the reform agenda, because the Prime Minister gave that job to someone else immediately after the election. Maybe the Prime Minister was the first to realise that Minister Abbott was going to adopt a constitutional monarch approach for this three years of his portfolio and so decided that if he wanted someone to review health and come up with some policy answers he needed to get someone else. He now has Mr Podger conducting the Podger review, and the department verified at Senate estimates that it is having nothing to do with the Prime Minister’s review which is being led by Mr Podger.

What more evidence do you need that the policy input of the minister for health is not only nonexistent but apparently not wanted, other than the fact that the Prime Minister is running the Podger review and the department of health, under Minister Abbott’s stewardship, is having absolutely nothing to do with it. If Minister Abbott objects to this apparent emasculation of his role in the future of health reform, he has not said it publicly—and he most certainly cannot have said it to the Prime Minister. At the same time we find that, when it comes to the PBS, health policy does not get run by Minister Abbott; it gets run by the Department of Finance and Administration. We know that when the government decided, in the middle of the election campaign, to make hundreds of millions of dollars of savings on the PBS and sought to impose a 12.5 per cent cut on the price of generic drugs to generate that saving—that saving being directed to funding a quickly cobbled together measure because the government was worried about votes bleeding off it from older Australians because of Medicare Gold—that was driven entirely out of Finance. That continues to be the case. Here we have a Minister for Health and Ageing who is not in control of health policy on an area as important as the PBS.

At the same time we have Finance apparently fattening up Medibank Private for sale. Once again, this is something that the minister for health does not appear to have anything to do with. You would think that, if you were going to sit there as the minister for health—as a constitutional monarch waiting for someone to consult you so that you could encourage or warn but not actually do anything—you would manage to run a pretty lean office and department because they would not be doing very much. But Minister Abbott is managing to pull a remarkable trick: he is doing less work. The work is done by others; it is most certainly not done by his department. It is done by everybody else but his department—by the Prime Minister’s department and the finance department. Minister Abbott is doing less work but departmental staff numbers are up and so are consultancy fees. This means that, while the department is doing less policy development work, it may be outsourcing more but with no apparent savings for the department. This would suggest that the minister has turned the department into administrative bureaucracy that outsources all new work but has managed to do that in a setting where he has achieved no savings and no apparent benefits in terms of the quality of advice or policy. I would think that these things are very concerning for those who follow the health policy debate.

We are going to have a complete absence of Commonwealth leadership on something as important as health policy during the life of the Howard government because Minister Abbott does not want to get it done. If he did want to get it done, there are certainly enough challenges on the minister’s table. In that regard, the following challenges need to be addressed, and need to be addressed soon. We obviously have a circumstance where better support is required for the public hospital system. That has been true since the Howard government ripped $970 million out of the health care agreements. It was even more true after the Howard government ripped a further $400 million out by revising the wage-cost index that it was going to use. More support is needed for our public hospitals from a minister who does not just talk about the need for reform periodically when he needs a one-liner and muses about the Commonwealth taking over the public hospital system. We need that reform to be diligently pursued by someone who is interested in doing it. We need reform of the private health insurance system to make private health insurance affordable for Australian families. No-one is doing that task. We need someone to do the hard policy work on the PBS to work out how we are going to sustain our PBS over time, not someone who makes some quick individual savings. We need someone who is prepared to stump up to the huge challenge of the health and medical work force and the complete crisis in that work force.

When people opened today’s newspapers they would have seen the absurdity that you can qualify for a bottle of Grange now if you can find a doctor. A work force agency is rewarding doctors with a bottle of Grange if they put them onto a lead which enables them to find an overseas doctor who might migrate to Australia. I do not think our medical work force issues should run off the provision of free and very expensive wine. I think our medical work force provision should run off proper planning, proper work force design, proper training and proper distribution. Minister Abbott is not looking at any of those issues and not making any policy changes that would make a difference to the lives of Australians when they need to see a doctor.

At the same time, we have seen Minister Abbott’s policies from before the election—in the days when he was being the political fixer and not the constitutional monarch—start to unravel in a way that is costing, and costing dearly. The blow-out on the safety net is now a matter of public record. It is enormous. Every day you open the newspapers there is a new source of the blow-out. There has been more publicity on the blow-out figures during the course of this week. What we legitimately fear is that one of two things will happen: either the Howard government will cut other areas of health to keep funding the blow-out on the safety net or, at some point, in complete contradiction to its election commitments, it will prune back the safety net blow-out.

I warrant that when that happens it will be Treasury that is in control of it, not Minister Abbott. It is a legitimate expectation for Australians that ministers of the Howard government diligently do their job using the powers in their hands to do so. That is not something that Minister Abbott has shown any predisposition to do since the last election, and Australians require that job to be done.

talk.start.para: —This debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and associated bills which deal with the budget appropriations takes place against a background of a slowing economic growth rate and a recent rise in interest rates. That is a rare conjunction of two events. Seldom in the course of the last 25 years have we seen a government so poorly manage events as to cause an increase in interest rates at the same time as our economy slows. It reminds many of us of the record of the current Prime Minister when he was Treasurer. He had an unchallenged record during that period. He is, I believe, the only Treasurer in the history of this country to record inflation and unemployment above 10 per cent at the same time. No other Treasurer in this country has ever managed to get things so wrong as to cause unemployment and inflation to both be above 10 per cent at once. There have been Treasurers who have presided over higher unemployment or higher inflation, but no-one else has performed so badly as Treasurer as to get both of them so wrong at the same time. That is what John Howard did when he was Treasurer. Events in the last couple of weeks have reminded us of that as we have seen interest rates rise at the same time as the economic data tell us that our economic growth is slowing.

speech.para: They also bring to mind the very dishonest way in which the government and the Liberal Party campaigned during the course of the last election over the question of interest rates. That has been a matter for some broader discussion in the parliament, so I will not dwell on it. But I do think that there are some important points that need to be recorded in this debate on the appropriations.

Whatever the crossing of the t’s and dotting of the i’s may show in terms of the record of events during the election campaign, there is no doubt in anyone’s mind about the message which this government, its members and the Liberal Party publicity machine sought to give to the Australian people. It was that record low interest rates would remain low under John Howard and the Liberal Party. ‘Vote for the Liberal Party and interest rates will not go up.’ That was the clear message being transmitted—I have to say by very sophisticated and effective means. I take my hat off to the people and the strategists in the Liberal Party who thought up some of that material; it was first-class but totally deceptive.

At the time those things were being said in the campaign, economists around Australia were being interviewed and writing articles about their views on these things. All of them said the claims of the Liberal Party, the government and the Treasurer about these matters were nonsense. I will refer to a couple of those. One of the economists during the course of the election campaign made this comment:

quote.para: Anyone promoting the forecast that mortgage rates will jump to 10 or 12 per cent is either dopey or dishonest or both.

speech.para: David Koch put it quite plainly in an article in August in the Sun Herald where he said:

quote.para: Any financial planner or stockbroker making the same claim as Peter Costello would go to jail under the current security laws.

speech.para: He did not pull any punches about the deception that the Liberal Party and their advocates were playing on the Australian people. Nor did 14 other economists who were surveyed at the time by Reuters. On 24 September last year Reuters conducted a survey of market economists, asking 14 of them whether they thought interest rates by the end of 2007 would be any different under a coalition or a Labor government. Not one forecast a difference in interest rates as a result of the election outcome.

I think the fair point to be made is that, whilst that issue was very effectively campaigned on as a political tool, it was done so dishonestly. The impressions that were given were clearly intended to produce fear and concern in the minds of people that were not substantiated by a thread of economic fact. The only thing from the election campaign that could possibly impact on interest rates was the extent of promises for spending commitments. Were the government of the day to go crazy and spend huge amounts of money beyond the nation’s capacity to pay, then of course that would put upwards pressure on inflation and interest rates. If you have a look at the detail of the commitments of the Labor Party on the one hand and the Liberal Party on the other, you discover that the Liberal Party promised to spend billions more than Labor.

talk.start.para: —Sixty-six billion dollars.

—As I am reminded, there were $66 billion in election commitments in the course of less than 12 months. To the extent that governments do influence these things, the upward pressure was actually coming from the Liberal Party. In a debate on appropriations we should not forget the way in which that campaign was so dishonestly conducted.

speech.para: I want to refer to a more recent revelation. The government have now discovered that there is a skills shortage. This is not news to people in industry, people in trade unions or people in educational institutions. Having created the skills shortage over the course of the last decade through their neglect of education and training facilities, they now tell young Australians to just drop out of school at year 10 and become apprentices. That is the solution that ministers have offered for this crisis that was created by their own policies and lack of proper management. True to form, the government will blame anyone but themselves for this dilemma.

The issue of the skills shortage and how we got to this point is reasonably complex. There are a lot of reasons why there are difficulties in some trades areas in gaining the recruitment that is needed. I have listened with interest to the comments of a number of ministers in the parliament and outside about the skills shortage and their plea for school students to simply leave at year 10 and take up apprenticeships. I think they have absolutely the most frightening response to this situation, which will not provide a long-term solution and will in fact exacerbate our long-term skills shortage problems.

The proposal that people leave at year 10 forces 15- and 16-year-olds to make life-determining decisions that frankly are difficult for most to alter later in life. This government’s approach to lifelong learning has made it even more difficult for these people to alter those choices further down the track. It places people in an economic and employment straitjacket. It denies them the life skills and the cognitive problem-solving skills that higher secondary education does provide and which are essential in the 21st century. It is the wrong prescription.

There is no doubt that we need more skilled people, but I ask those ministers, Liberal and National Party members of parliament and corporate executives who are urging 15-year-olds to drop out of school after year 10: how many of them sit down with their 12- and 13-year-old daughters, sons and grandchildren and say, ‘Dear, what I want you to contemplate is not aspiring to go university. I think you should leave school after year 10 and take up an apprenticeship, say, as a carpenter or an electrician’? I have to say that electricians are a highly skilled group of people. How many of them have said: ‘My dear, loved grandchild, son or daughter aged 12, I don’t want you to look at completing year 12. I certainly don’t want you to look at going to university. I think you should turn your ambitions to leaving at year 10 and becoming a hairdresser, a forklift driver or whatever it might be.’

All of these occupations are essential, and they are all undervalued, but there is monumental hypocrisy from the top end of town in this debate. The top end of town knows that the people who by and large drop out of school at age 15 or 16 come from families whose parents do not have a higher education. Typically they come from families with a low socioeconomic status. This is the worst possible form of social engineering. This is the ultraconservative management of our society telling people from working class backgrounds that they should not aspire to a different type of occupation or lifestyle from that in which they grew up. They are telling parents that they should not wish that for their children.

I happen to come from one of those families. My parents wished that for me, and I am very grateful that I had the opportunity. I am indignant that the government is trying to socially engineer a strict class-divided system that this country left behind somewhere in the 1960s—at least I hope it did. The OECD have done a number of reports on this matter, and the evidence is overwhelming. Their Education at a glance: OECD indicators 2004 report said:

quote.para: Employment ratios rise with educational attainment in most OECD countries. With very few exceptions, the employment ratio for graduates of tertiary education is markedly higher than the ratio for upper secondary graduates.

speech.para: A simple and understood proposition is that, if you have a higher education, you have a much better chance of getting ahead in this world and getting a well-paid secure job. Elsewhere in the report it said:

quote.para: Employment ratios for females with less than lower secondary attainment are particularly low.

speech.para: Girls are more disadvantaged than boys in a lot of these countries. There is more than ample evidence around the world, and there is more than ample evidence in Australia, to illustrate the point. The most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics labour market indicators report noted:

quote.para: For people without non-school qualifications, the unemployment rate was 7½ per cent. For those who had completed year 12, it was 10 per cent.

speech.para: There is a real difference in your employability, depending upon whether or not you complete year 12. Quoting further from the Australian Bureau of Statistics data:

quote.para: People who had completed year 12 generally experienced better labour market outcomes, as shown by higher labour force participation rates, higher employment to population ratios and lower unemployment rates than those who had not completed year 12.

speech.para: How much evidence does this government need to comprehend that turning people away from school at age 15 or 16 dramatically diminishes that person’s lifelong employment opportunities? Yet that was the answer we heard from minister after minister last week. This is not lost on our education community. The Australian Council for Educational Research, a highly respected body that is involved in education development, and research noted:

quote.para: Those whose parents work in manual occupations, students from trade, skilled, semiskilled and unskilled occupational backgrounds have higher rates of early school leaving, particularly for boys.

speech.para: It also noted that about 20 per cent of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander students in the sample left school by the beginning of year 11, over twice the rate of other students.

There is an overwhelming case to encourage all of our students to complete year 12. Within those post-compulsory education years 11 and 12, many schools now offer a variety of courses, some of which include TAFE training programs, as part of the school curricula. This is a very positive step and, as the leader of the Labor Party commented in parliament this week, initiatives like that should be supported by this government, rather than opting for a 1960s white picket fence solution and telling people from working class backgrounds and families that they should just drop out of school when they are 15 years of age and become an apprentice because this government has mismanaged the labour market so badly.

In the few moments remaining, I want to turn to the question of the government’s other passion over the course of the last few weeks—no doubt to be given centre stage later this year—and that is industrial relations. In the process of dealing with the skilled labour work force or the lack thereof, the government have said, ‘We’ve got a problem with the labour market and all we have to do is change labour laws and that will fix the difficulties that we’re having in providing skilled workers.’ The bell was well and truly rung by Ross Gittins in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald a couple of weeks ago under the heading ‘Porkies used to support industrial relations “reform”’. Ross Gittins is not somebody I usually quote, but I have to say this article really did hit the nail on the head. He commented:

quote.para: Mr Costello gave a press conference on the day of the release of the Statement on Monetary Policy that was packed with misleading propositions. One of them was that, to ensure we kept inflation and, hence, interest rates down, we needed a lot more industrial relations reform to minimise excessive wage growth.
That’s a non sequitur. It’s conflating a short-term macro-economic problem with a medium-term micro-economic reform.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: This is just Costello the dodgy barrister casting around for a simple, superficially plausible argument to convince the punters his IR changes will deliver instant benefits.

speech.para: Elsewhere in the same article he said:

quote.para: It’s possible Mr Costello spouts this economic illiteracy because he knows no better, being a barrister. But it’s hard to believe Treasury would have failed to brief him adequately.
No, it’s more likely he’s dreamt up his own bit of convenient bulldust in the belief it will make the nasty medicine of labour-market deregulation easier for the mug punters to swallow.

speech.para: He did not miss the government, he did not miss the Treasurer and he was absolutely right. Let us have a look at the record of this government in supporting wage and salary earners at one end of the spectrum and then at the other. Average yearly earnings at the end of 1995, when Labor was last in office, were $28,934. The most recent figures for 2004 show that average yearly earnings are now $40,061. Over the period of roughly nine years there has been an increase of $10,314 in the average yearly earnings of Australian workers. Meanwhile, at the top end of town, what are the CEOs pulling in? The CEOs in 1995 had a total average remuneration package of $294,000. In 2004, CEOs were pulling in $475,873. That means CEOs over the term of this government have increased their remuneration package on average by $144,291.

talk.start.para: —How much?

—By $144,291. The average worker in this country gets $40,061. CEOs have had an increase more than three times the total average wage—not three times the increase of the average worker’s wage but three times their total wage. If you look at it by any other measure, you come up with the same disparity. In 1995, a CEO’s total package represented 10.1 times average weekly earnings. Today, it has grown to 11.8 times average weekly earnings. The gap is getting bigger.

speech.para: But what do the government say in response to that? They say, ‘What we need to do is give people with average working conditions fewer rights. They are obviously getting paid too much, because there is a wage breakout, so we need to control those people on average weekly earnings.’ That is what the Liberal Party say, even though the figures demonstrate that, over the course of the government’s term in office, average weekly incomes have barely kept pace with the cost of living, while at the same time the top end of town have, under this government, done extraordinarily well.

And they do not do extraordinarily well just when times are good. In February 2003 there was a very good article in Business Review Weekly, of all places, which had a look at the performance of some CEOs against their pay. The article was headlined, ‘They receive multimillion dollar packages but some are wrecking shareholder wealth.’ The story detailed how CEOs were receiving not hundreds of thousands but millions of dollars a year in payments at the same time that their companies were going backwards.

There is a massive abuse of the Australian work force in the way in which the government have conducted their economic and industrial relations policies. It is time that the government took stock of that. In a couple of months, they will have the unfettered capacity to put through this parliament whatever they wish, and a range of industrial relations reforms will be top of the pops when it comes to that debate. This is just the tip of the iceberg in terms of the information that demonstrates the unfairness of the government’s past practices. I am looking forward to the debates and the campaigns after 1 July in order to expose some of the government’s harsher policies which have operated to the detriment of ordinary Australians.

talk.start.para: —Tonight in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and related bills I want to address a number of issues, among which, principally and firstly, is Indigenous education. This is an issue I have raised time and time again in this place, including quite a number of times during the last parliamentary term. I have also raised it since the new parliament was sworn in. The key issues I want to address in relation to it are the changes announced by the federal government in April last year to the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness program and the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme. It was announced that they would be abolished and replaced by new programs.

speech.para: As a reminder, ASSPA is a program that funds Indigenous parent committees, which arrange activities to encourage Indigenous students to attend and stay at school. Activities are wide-ranging and include nutrition programs, sports days and excursions, which are particularly important for kids in very remote communities. Funds also go towards classroom resources such as books, videos and computers and towards a whole panoply of educational tools and educational opportunities. But today, some seven weeks into the school term, no schools in my electorate have yet received funding from ASSPA’s replacement, the Parent School Partnerships initiative.

The PSPI funding process has been a complete joke. Very late last year, schools were sent application forms for them to describe how they would use funding. These applications alone include 11 pages of forms, governed by 121 pages of rules. The result of this complex and time-consuming process is that hard-pressed bush schools in my electorate—schools where English is invariably a second, third or even fourth language of many parents—are having trouble even applying for funding. The overworked principals and schoolteachers in these places are doing their best, but the Commonwealth Department of Education, Science and Training is already returning applications to schools all over the Northern Territory with the simple message ‘Rejected’. So these schools can no longer undertake activities they would have previously undertaken under the ASSPA program, because some bureaucrat somewhere who asserts that they know what is best for these school communities is making judgments about what these schools can do in terms of their education programs, and is making those judgments without, in my view, any detailed knowledge or understanding of the circumstances.

What I find particularly offensive about this process is that somehow the Minister for Education, Science and Training has the gall to say it will benefit bush schools or Aboriginal education generally. When I warned him of these consequences on 16 June last year, this is what he said:

quote.para: We particularly want to give priority to non-metropolitan Aboriginal students. I do not care what anybody says: that is where the need is greatest.

speech.para: Why then are the remote bush schools in my electorate—without question the most disadvantaged schools in Australia—being told they will miss out on PSPI funding? These schools are missing out and, no doubt, well-resourced metropolitan schools in some communities will be receiving the money that they are not. The reason, partly, for this is not necessarily a shifting of funds. It is because the bush communities are disadvantaged by their isolation and by the lack of human resources—the human capital—available to them to prepare and submit appropriate documentation to support their requests for resources. This is something which is ignored by the government, and I have warned about it previously. It is true also of schools in towns like Alice Springs. Most schools have lost thousands of dollars in funding following the government’s changes to this program.

For reasons I cannot understand—the government itself has given no adequate explanation—it has cut tutorial assistance to all students, except those in years 4, 6 and 8 who failed MAP literacy and numeracy tests in the previous year. I have mentioned this before on a number of occasions. We have had the changes to ASSPA and now we have the proposed changes to the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance program. These changes have wrought havoc on the education system in the Northern Territory. To give you some idea of the impact, 500 tutors at schools in remote communities have been left without work. Last year 3,800 Indigenous students were receiving tutorial assistance. This year, just 1,666 students will be helped.

I have received a flood of correspondence on this, and I have made this point before. The issue here is: what sort of educational expert has come up with a proposition that, somehow or other, an arbitrary MAP testing exercise or literacy testing exercise at specific year levels is going to identify people and then enable you to compensate people who fail that test by giving them tutorial assistance the year after they have failed? What happened to the idea of early intervention? What happened to the idea of school communities being able to develop their own priorities for what is best for students by identifying students’ needs and then establishing—through propositions developed in the school community—the best way to improve the outcomes for students? I can tell you what has happened: a very arbitrary imposition of a set of rules which will not work. As a direct result, literally thousands of students in my electorate and across Northern Australia are being adversely affected by the stupidity of these arrangements. There are any number of examples.

There is one school of which I have a particular understanding and knowledge. I have to declare an interest here in that I have a son who attends this school and my partner is the acting deputy principal. I am speaking of Ross Park Primary School in Alice Springs, where every fourth student is Indigenous. This school wrote to the minister about ATAS on 8 February, stating:

quote.para: Whereas previously 56 students from years 1 to 6 benefited from ATAS support, only 5 students in years 4 to 6 will now receive tutoring. Many will be left behind as a result of this decision.

The ATAS scheme has proven very successful at our school. Our dedicated ... tutors have not only helped students reach benchmarks over the four years they have been here, but managed to raise individual students levels above benchmarks. They have given students the confidence that they can do just as well as others.

speech.para: ‘Hear, hear!’ I say to that. That is as it should be—but it will not be as a result of these proposals put by the government. This letter goes on:

quote.para: In the early childhood years, literacy/numeracy support has resulted in more students achieving test benchmarks than ever before. Ongoing support is essential in these years to lay the foundations for numeracy and literacy skills, particularly where children come from homes where books, reading and education are not seen as high priorities or are not available at all...

speech.para: Let me be very clear about this: what they have said about ongoing support being essential to lay the foundation for literacy and numeracy skills is so obvious that it is beyond argument. But somehow or other this government believe that by shifting the finance in the way they are doing—in which they will get savings, of course—students will benefit. Students will not benefit. The community will suffer, the families will suffer and students will suffer.

I will give you another important example. Kalkaringi Community Education Centre has been devastated by these changes. It was here in the year 2003 that three students became the Northern Territory’s first ever year 12 students to gain tertiary entrance from a remote community school. Its principal, George Hewitson, who won a federal government award for leadership, was described by the minister as ‘inspiring’. But, this year, the centre has already lost excellent tutoring staff and $35,000 to $40,000 in federal funding. It could also face the prospect of losing a further $80,000, depending on the outcome of negotiations with DEET, who are going to assess their submissions. What sort of lunacy is this?
Willowra school in the central desert wrote me this note:

quote.para: We will only be able to target 12 students instead of the 30 plus students who used to get one-on-one assistance.

Our students come to school speaking their first language, they come from houses where books and reading does not happen so the only reading they get is at school. It is well documented that children cannot catch up to their English language peers in one year and need some extra assistance and time. This is further compounded when lack of home resources and regular school attendances are factored in.

speech.para: Hear, hear! That is fairly obvious, I would have thought. And from Nyirrpi school, also in the western desert, in the Tanami, comes this letter:

quote.para: For the first time in many years in 2004 we have had kids reaching and others very close to benchmark standards. This has only been due to additional tutors in school working one-on-one and in a small group situation.

Nyirrpi School, enrolment 25, is always going to struggle with attendance and targets as Warlpiri communities tend to be great ‘long distance travellers’ and take their kids with them when they visit family in other communities for long periods of time. We must have this concentrated tutoring to catch these kids up when they are in the community.

speech.para: There are many more examples.

There was a Senate inquiry into this, and the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Reference Committee visited Alice Springs last week. I want to mention something of the behaviour of one of its members—the deputy chair, Senator Tierney. Senator Tierney was the sole government member of the inquiry to take part in its public hearings in the Northern Territory last week. Put simply, certainly at one school, his behaviour was offensive in the extreme and a gross insult to those people who took the time and effort to travel to and address the hearings. I have not read the transcript of the hearings in Alice Springs as it is not yet available, but, from what I have heard from those who took part, he was entirely uninterested in their plight, did not bother to listen and was condescending in the extreme in those rare minutes that he did speak. One participant was so appalled, she got up and told him so. To me, the senator’s attitude pretty much sums up the attitude of the government to Indigenous people and their communities. Thank God, he is leaving parliament in July—good riddance to him when he goes.

There are other issues that I want to address. One of those relates to CDEP, which is another significant issue in Indigenous communities across Australia, but I will come to that if I have time. I want to briefly just address the issue of roads. A month ago to the day I was in the chamber outlining the flaws in the government’s roads funding system that sees unincorporated areas, which make up much of my electorate, miss out. I will briefly run through part of what I said then. I said:

quote.para: ... the Northern Territory has a uniquely different road system. This difference lies in the fact that much of the Territory’s road network cannot be managed by local councils because 40 per cent of the Territory roads lie outside town council boundaries. For years now, as a result of decisions taken by this government, these roads have been ineligible for Roads to Recovery funding which is distributed only to local councils. ... Without federal funding, they have been left to deteriorate, so much so that less than 35 per cent of the NT road network is sealed with bitumen.

speech.para: I have made these points time and time again in this place and outside. Imagine my surprise, then, to hear on the radio last week that the government failure was—do you believe it?—all my fault. That was the absurd claim by Senator Scullion, CLP representative from the Northern Territory, when he tried to explain his way out of a broken promise he made during the course of the last election campaign to provide an initial $20 million for these roads. On Thursday morning last week, on ABC Top End’s late morning program, the senator was asked why the government was providing just $1 million of the $20 million it had promised. This was his response:

quote.para: Well, I mean, if you look at history it was actually Warren Snowden when he was the parliamentary secretary that was responsible for roads, as I understand, and he was the one who said, ‘Look, let’s take the money off the Northern Territory Government, give it to local councils, forgetting of course there wasn’t any contiguous line that join the councils.

speech.para: Hang on? Have I lost something here? All we did at the time was ensure that Indigenous local councils in the Northern Territory got the same rights as other local governing bodies around Australia and were direct funded. That is all we did. We did not shift the bucket of money. We gave it to those communities on the same terms and conditions as every other local governing authority in Australia got it. I remember it vividly because I was insistent that it happen. What he has done is fall on his face. It is true. As I said, I was parliamentary secretary to the minister for transport at that time and had a great deal to do with making sure that this happened. But how does it follow that I am therefore responsible for the Roads to Recovery program, which became law more than eight years later, under a coalition government, on 21 December 2000?

It is no wonder that neither Senator Scullion nor his party colleague the member for Solomon have ever mentioned roads in this parliament—not once. What a burning issue it is for them! They think it is okay to blame me for their total failure to represent their constituents. This is the twisted logic that we are getting used to hearing in this place: somehow or other, I am to blame for the failure of the Roads to Recovery program. I know who is to blame; it is those people that sit on the Treasury benches—principally, and significantly, the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the Nationals, who ensured that in the first round of Roads to Recovery his electorate, which is one-tenth the size of the Northern Territory, got in excess of $40 million while the Northern Territory got $20 million.

As I said, this is the twisted logic that we are getting used to in this place. According to this government, the skill shortage is not its fault; it is the fault of those damned kids who want to go to university. Rises in interest rates and the record current account deficit are not the government’s fault; they are the fault of the Keating government. At least the government always harks back to the Labor years when asked why its policies are failing now. But of course it will not claim the merits, the profitable outcomes or the successes that have made this economy competitive as a result of the changes made by the successive Hawke and Keating governments. Now the government’s decision not to fund bush roads is not its fault either; it is someone else’s—mine.

I think it is a bit of a joke; in fact, I think it is beyond absurd. The government simply fails to understand the importance of these bush roads to the largely resourced based Territory economy. Cattle industry live exports are worth $330 million each year to the Territory. They are the third largest private sector industry in the place. The largest industry, which is the other major industry user of bush roads, is the mining industry. That is worth about $1.5 billion each year and employs about 4,000 people directly in the Territory. Then of course there is tourism. While the government does nothing, choosing instead to blame me, these roads—the roads relied on by the tourism industry, the pastoral industry and the mining industry, not to mention the thousands of Territorians who live in small and remote communities in the bush—are getting worse and worse by the minute.
On Friday of last week the Centralian Advocate ran with the following headline: ‘Shocking bush roads cost millions’. The story went on to say:

quote.para: The shocking state of bush roads is costing the Central Australian pastoral and tourism industry thousands of dollars ... The NT Cattleman’s Association executive director Stuart Kenny said that up to $40 million more was needed to address the problem.

speech.para: You do not have to be Einstein to work out where the problem is. In the case of Aboriginal education, the problem rests squarely with the government. In the case of the deficiency in road funding, the responsibility rests squarely with the government. We know this is recognised by the Northern Territory community. We understand that parents in schools understand what the problem is. They know that the decisions to affect in a negative way the educational outcomes for their children are the direct responsibility of the federal government. They know—they have seen the arrogance of Senator Tierney—that this government is not serious. They know that they are getting all sorts of excuses for the failure of the government to come to terms with its responsibilities in relation to Indigenous education—as is the case with CDEP.

Last week we had the government come out with its announced proposals to amend community development employment programs. A discussion paper on the future of the program was written by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations and launched in Alice Springs on the evening of 21 February. Believe it or not, the department gave Central Australia just 12 hours to consider its plan before holding official consultations.

Let me be very clear about it: this is happening across Australia. This government has produced a document which plans to change the way in which CDEP operates across the nation. It has held meetings in Alice Springs, Katherine and Darwin but not in remote communities. The second-largest CDEP project in Australia is at Maningrida. Has the government identified this issue at Maningrida? Has it gone to the people of Maningrida? Has it tried to sit down in the dust and talk to the people who are participating in the CDEP at Maningrida or anywhere else across Northern Australia? Has it talked to people who have English as a second language? Has it talked to them in appropriate terms and put this in their language so that they can understand what the government is about? Has there been any attempt by the government to do any of this? Of course the answer is no.

It has also abolished ATSIC, so any forums that Indigenous people might have had to express their concern about the way in which the government is carrying out its responsibilities in relation to CDEP or any other matter have disappeared off the face of the earth. So we have a centralised system where bureaucrats are dictated to by the minister and the minister’s office. Staff are told to trot around Australia and tell Indigenous people what the government proposes to do and what the government will do. Despite the rhetoric of going through a process of consultation, they know full well what the government’s blueprint is and what the government intends to implement regardless of the feedback it gets. That is the arrogance of this government; that is the stupidity of this government.

But it is not fooling me, it is not fooling my constituents in the Northern Territory and I believe it is certainly not fooling the Australian population. As time marches on, as it must, towards the next federal election, voters are going to see this writ large time and time and time again. They will inevitably agree with the judgments that parents at Ross Park Primary School, Nyirrpi, Kakaringi and these other schools are making about the way in which this government is dealing with Indigenous education. They will inevitably agree with what the cattlemen’s association is saying about the way in which the government is dealing with roads and the way in which it is dealing with the CDEP. They know that this government cannot be trusted and the quicker it terminates its relationship with the Australian people by being defeated in the next election, the better for all of us.

talk.start.para: —I am very happy to follow the member for Lingiari’s contribution. It is fair to say this government has failed in relation to Indigenous policies. I would like to touch upon another area which reflects the contempt and ignorance this government displays when it comes to a large part of this society—that is, the working men and women of Australia. This afternoon we had the Prime Minister attempting to convince those who were listening that this government cares for the men and women who are the backbone of Australia’s economy, but we know this Prime Minister and this government have been antiworker since their election in 1996. We know that from that time on, this government has attempted to diminish and destroy any entitlements afforded to employees in their workplaces and, in some cases, has succeeded. We also know a number of bills went through the House of Representatives last term but failed to find passage through the Senate.

speech.para: We are all aware that things will change in July this year when the Senate delivers to the government, by virtue of an election, a majority in both houses. We are well aware this is the first time we have seen a majority in both houses in this country at the federal level since 1981. Along with others in this place and the working men and women of Australia, I will be looking at the way in which this Prime Minister and the government’s minister for workplace relations deals with the IR agenda.

We know what Prime Minister Howard’s agenda for working people has been since he entered this place in the mid-1970s. We are well aware of his views about unions, collective bargaining and unfair termination by employers. His contempt for the Industrial Relations Commission is on the record, as are his views on Medicare and many social institutions. His views about the AIRC and the rights of employee organisations are extreme. Indeed, he is matched by his Treasurer. We are well aware that the Treasurer made his name—cut his teeth—on industrial relations cases in the mid-1980s. In late 1986, Mr Costello, then a barrister representing an employer, argued before the full bench of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission that all employees be paid no more than $171 each, with no other wage increment involved, and that each employee in the land should individually negotiate with their employer anything beyond that point.

It so happens that, at that time, $171 was well below the poverty line, but that did not stop Mr Costello from pursuing that argument on behalf of a pretty phoney employer body with very few affiliates. That was the Treasurer’s view in 1986. Almost 20 years later, if this government allows the extremists in the employer groups to have their way, Mr Costello’s submission to reduce people’s wages down to the poverty line and to have them negotiate individually upwards could come to fruition in the not too distant future. Certainly a system could be put in place to bring about the eradication of awards as we know them and the eradiation of every classification point in any award except for the minimum rate of the country. By virtue of other legislation, the commission could be compelled to prevent safety nets from being applied to that rate, and it could fall below the poverty line. Further to that, Australian workplace agreements—that Orwellian term: neither Australian nor workplace and rarely agreements—will proliferate throughout the country if the government has its way.

We are well aware that the Prime Minister’s ‘challenger to be’—the K-Mart Keating, the one who might challenge if he had the guts but we know he doesn’t—has to keep some of his very few supporters on side. Those two senior members of government, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, have an enmity towards working people and their capacity to collectively bargain. Their views are extreme compared not just with the Labor Party’s but with the Liberal Party’s position historically.

We are well aware of the Liberal Party’s views for the past almost 100 years. The Liberal Party supported a system of fairness and a fair and reasonable wage. I do not recall Menzies ever attacking Justice Higgins’ decision that there should be a fair and reasonable wage in this country. Justice Higgins, in the Harvester judgment in 1907, laid down the basis for our social wage, which reflected not only a decent outcome but also part of our culture. He was attempting to synthesise what people had come to believe in—a fair go. That ethos developed in the mid-19th century. In 1907 Justice Higgins summed up that matter by saying that working people deserved a fair and reasonable wage. He did so and that view has been held ever since.

We should also remember that Justice Higgins’s decision was based upon a provision of an act of the second parliament of this nation. That act of parliament, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, established the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, the then title of the federal commission. That act was supported in many instances by people who would see themselves as liberals in the traditional sense. That decision stood us in good stead.

I am a great believer in the fact that we had to change the system. I hold the view that we had to make the system more flexible. I have had arguments at every level—at the workplace and at other forums—about that matter, but I believe that there had to be some change. The Labor Party in the 1980s were right when they said that there had to be some level of devolution—that there had to be a capacity for employers to bargain at the workplace level with their workers. I agree with that. But I also believe that, when you set in train a capacity to devolve the system to allow employees to negotiate at the local level, you must also have some protection for those same employees.

I do not think that is the intention of this government. That is what really worries me. I compare this government’s views not with my own but with former Liberal governments’ views in relation to what is fair and reasonable. The Treasurer already foreshadowed almost 20 years ago his views on creating a minimum wage. An article from the Canberra Times in 1986 said:

quote.para: Melbourne barrister Peter Costello presents the AFE submission to the national wage case hearing ... called on the Arbitration Commission ... to cut the minimum wage to $171.30 a week. Mr Costello told the wage case full bench that the commission should allow employers and workers to negotiate directly for increases above the minimum.

speech.para: Effectively he suggested that we should have one single rate nationally—of $171, which I said earlier was below the poverty line—and everybody had to negotiate individually upwards. That was his dream; that is what he would like to see happen. Indeed, the Prime Minister has a similar view, as we know.

Against that backdrop, it is important for us to understand the extent to which this government will go to wreck a system that we have had in place since the beginning of last century. How far will this government go to strip away from the system what have been fundamental entitlements of workers now for 100 years—to strip away the ethos of the fair and reasonable wage that was enshrined in the 1907 Harvester judgment and to effectively take away the rights to collectively bargain in a fair way?

I am also most concerned by the current minister’s views on that. When we saw Minister Andrews succeed Minister Abbott as the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, I thought, ‘Maybe here is an opportunity for this minister to depart from a very radical position taken by his two predecessors—Minister Abbott and Minister Reith.’ I was hoping that this minister would at least show some temperance, some moderation, some balance and some thought for working people. The most important part of the economy, in the end, of course, is always the working people of this country. Unfortunately I came across this quote. Others, I am sure, have already seen it, where the minister effectively said that we might have to be careful about fairness. He said:

quote.para: ... as the Business Council of Australia recently argued, an emphasis on fairness only leads to regulatory excess ...

speech.para: He talks about an emphasis on fairness. Minister, we want to know whether there is going to be a presence of fairness and whether there is going to be an existence of fairness—not an emphasis on fairness. Indeed, if the government continues to strip away the entitlements of working people—by making it almost impossible to negotiate properly a collective agreement by allowing the employer to refuse to bargain; by not allowing the umpire—the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—to involve itself in at least assisting the parties to come to terms with an agreement; and by introducing AWAs which are not transparent, which are oversighted by the Employment Advocate and where nobody gets to scrutinise whether in fact the agreements are disadvantageous to the employee—without any balance or protection for working people then I think we are definitely at a tilting point. We are at a point where the Prime Minister and this government have shown an utter disregard and contempt for working people in this country. It is up to this government to see whether it can temper its own excesses—I am not confident that it can do that.

I have talked about some of the broader issues and historical matters that are important in the overall context of this debate, but what gets lost is the issue of what the priority should be when you are looking at regulating. I agree that you do not regulate for the sake of it. I consider that in a capitalist system there is a need to regulate, whether it is about regulating occupational health and safety or the rights of employees, small business, other bodies and citizens. That is the reality. No-one would want to see the outcome of a purely laissez-faire capitalist system because clearly that leads to monopolies and to enormous social and economic disadvantages for the majority of people. We have come to understand that—it is a pretty basic point. My priority in this matter is the millions of people effectively on the poverty line, barely able to afford to put food on the table, to pay for a mortgage or to pay rent to their landlord. That is my concern. I am not worried about union officials. I am not worried about an affiliate union giving money to the ALP. I am worried about those unionised, non-unionised, collective and non-collective arrangements that occur in workplaces which can leave people impoverished and a large proportion of Australian families struggling to make ends meet.

We know there have been some economic indicators that are very positive for this country and I applaud the government in areas where they have succeeded. There is no point disregarding reality when there are positive things to say about matters. I am happy to see the reduction in unemployment—of course we should all be—and it would be churlish to say otherwise. I am happy to see economic growth—the capacity for people’s incomes to grow. Of course those things are important. But there is a large proportion of this society that has missed out, and there is no point putting a post 1996 date on that fact—it has happened in Labor terms as well as, certainly, since this government was elected. When you have been around for almost 10 years you have to start taking some responsibility for what might have happened in the last decade. That is what happens. For the first two terms of this government all we heard about was what happened in the 13 years from 1983 to 1996.

Let us talk about the period from 1996 to 2005. Since 1996, whilst there has been some growth in employment, there has been a significant increase in casualisation of the work force. When you are a casual employee—and I am sure there are some in this chamber who have been casual employees—you do not tend to get a home loan very easily. You do not tend to get too many things that you might want. You may not even be able to get a credit card, not that they are always good for you.

The other problem we have had in relation to employment growth is that there has been a significant increase in part-time employment. That is not necessarily a bad thing. Part-time employment may well be the type of employment that many people want, and that is fine. We know about people wanting to opt for part-time employment. But the government defines part-time employment as someone having one hour a week under the current statistics used by the government. I am well aware of the fact that many part-time employees are desperately seeking further work. We know a large part of the Australian work force are struggling to make ends meet and are effectively on the poverty line while working 38 to 40-plus hours a week to look after their families—and in some cases working 60 or 70 hours a week in the household to pay their mortgages and so on—then we know that things are not that easy for them. We also know that they are not the beneficiaries of the changes that have occurred, when compared to others.

I heard the member for Brisbane talking earlier about the ratio between the CEOs’ wage increases since 1996 and the increases of people on average weekly earnings. There is a vast difference, with those people at the top end receiving greater sums in real terms but not even proportionate to their incomes. When a government considers removing the minimum wage or removing the capacity of the commission to make an order to allow for that minimum wage to increase, and when legislation is being introduced to the House that will compel the commission to not pay that minimum wage increase to certain people on the lowest rates in this country, then you know you have a government that has no regard for the lowest paid people. You know you have a government that has no regard for those working people. The battlers that this Prime Minister has boasted about are not, in the end, people he cares about if he continues with his very pernicious agenda to destroy the IR system and leave these people at such peril.

talk.start.para: —According to recent newspaper reports, it appears that the government surplus in its most recent budget might be in the order of some $10 billion, as against an anticipated $2.6 billion. I do not know whether that is in fact going to happen, but it is pretty obvious that the government is rolling in money. Yet, at a time when the government is rolling in money, in effect it wants to go after some of the most vulnerable people in our community.

speech.para: Today I rise to speak on behalf of the 3,260 recipients of a disability support pension in the seat of Banks. Given the increase in the number of people on disability support pensions visiting my office, I understand that the government is currently considering changes to the payments and conditions of those in receipt of a disability support pension. These people are very worried—and with good reason. An article by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday, 16 February 2005 has the headline ‘It’s disability pensioners’ turn to oblige’, and an article by Michelle Grattan in the Age on 28 February 2005 has the headline ‘“Work first” to be welfare aim’. A constituent who is intellectually disabled and who regularly presents to my office has been to my office twice in the last week voicing his concern over media reports. Let me say at the outset that these people are not all those who are stereotyped as having bad backs. In Banks these people include people with schizophrenia, those with serious depression, some with terminal diseases and others with debilitating diseases.

There has been considerable misinformation on the issue of how people actually obtain the disability support pension. From my experience in my electorate it is not as easy as many armchair experts would have us believe.
