Apart from age and residential requirement, applicants need to show that they have a disability, illness or injury which attracts an impairment rating of at least 20 points on the impairment tables. I have here in the House a copy of the impairment tables, which we pulled off the net. It is in the Social Security Act 1991, schedule 1B, ‘Tables for the assessment of work-related impairment for disability support pension’, by the Department of Social Security of 1997. There is an introduction and then 437 pages. It is not easy to achieve 20 points on the impairment table. This disability, illness or impairment needs to be such that a person must be unable to work full time or be retrained for at least two years. ‘Full time’ is defined as 30 hours a week.

Over a third of all applications are rejected. For example, one of my constituents, Bruce, is aged 47. He is a former labourer who broke both ankles in 1980. In 1990 he broke his back in a motorcycle accident. He also has a dislocated shoulder. Bruce has twice been rejected for a disability support pension. Of those whose applications are medically verified, 33 per cent have musculoskeletal disabilities—which is loss of mobility or limbs—25 per cent have psychiatric illnesses and 11 per cent have intellectual or learning disabilities. A good paper was produced by the Australian Council of Social Service in January 2005 called Ten myths and facts about the disability support pension.

These are the people that are being targeted by this government, not the top end of town, not the rorters who have the accountants, the lawyers, the trusts and the schemes to avoid taxation. It is a government which has, in its nine years of office, stopped looking at that section of the community who are avoiding tax at the rate of knots and which has, instead of tightening that area, gone after the vulnerable in the community.

Many people with illnesses such as multiple sclerosis or recurring mental illnesses are able to work part time but not full time. The fact is that the current system allows these people to work up to 30 hours a week. If they find employment and it does not work out, Centrelink will hold their information for a period of time so that they do not have to reapply. This does provide a safety net for people with disabilities as they engage with the employment market. For many people with psychiatric illness, particularly, there is considerable trauma involved in dealing with the doctors, the paperwork and all the paraphernalia which goes with applying for a disability support pension. There is nothing in the current system that discourages people from working. Yet, like the vast majority of those with disabilities, these people are quite often desperate to work within their capacity. These people are dependent on financial support not through choice but through circumstance.

I think it is important at this stage for me to outline a specific instance. One of my constituents presented at my office in March 2003. After a heart operation he had been made redundant, so he had no job to go back to. He applied for the newstart allowance, and after a number of administrative difficulties, including non-payment, he finally started to receive payments. Over a period of time he sought work until a Job Network provider advised that they could not look for work for him. At that point the possibility of a disability support pension was raised, with a doctor advising that the problem was not so much the heart rather my constituent’s body being unable to repair itself. My constituent started to suffer periodically from depression. In mid-2004 he was diagnosed with lung cancer and his doctor advised that he would be unable to work indefinitely. After some time he was put onto a disability support pension.

In January 2005 my constituent again attended my office in considerable distress that he may be required to work as a result of a communication from Centrelink. At this time my constituent regularly has appointments with a cardiologist, a respiratory specialist and his GP to monitor his blood pressure, cholesterol and overall heart condition. My constituent is simply not in a position to work, and the process of getting the disability pension was extraordinarily time-consuming and stressful. He is now on a disability support pension. The threat that he will have to continue to prove his illness has caused him constant worry and tension, exacerbating his condition. They are the people that this government goes after. Yet when it comes to tax avoidance and the promises the Treasurer has made in the past about tightening the scheme, because it is a vocal group in the community that can lobby successfully, the government has abandoned pursuit of those rorters.

For many people the lack of resources available to Job Network providers is the critical factor when it comes to assisting people back into work. I also point out at this stage that there are no Job Network providers physically located within the seat of Banks. My constituents are served by providers largely located in Bankstown or Hurstville. People with disabilities who are of work force age need access to appropriate levels of workplace assistance and the training required to help overcome barriers to employment. At the same time, the difficulties faced by those on disability support pensions do not rest solely on the low levels of government job assistance but are extended into the workplace. Many employers are reluctant to employ people with physical or mental disabilities. That is a fact of life. Often they need specialist services to find and maintain employment. There is little assistance available for employers, even if they are positive about employing people with disabilities.

Apart from this assistance, many jobs which were previously available to people with disabilities have been replaced by technology or other changes. For instance, I am aware of a person with intellectual disabilities who was able to regularly work serving petrol and cleaning windscreens at a garage. This option is no longer available. ACOSS, together with a broad alliance of supporting organisations, has recommended the development of a national strategy to encourage employers to remove work practices and other barriers that shut people with disabilities out of employment and to overcome discrimination. The paper is called Guidelines for disability welfare reform to promote workforce participation among people with disabilities.

Another of my constituents has experienced this discrimination first-hand. Michael of Padstow is just 60 years old. He is on a disability support pension because he has two damaged vertebrae, the neck and lumbar; osteoarthritis; calcium heel spurs, which prevent him standing for long periods of time; kidney problems and high blood pressure. Michael sent 61 job applications to government departments between 2001 and 2003. He obtained one interview. When he followed up two of the positions he was told that they feared excessive sick leave or aggravation of injury. He also received comments as to why he was applying for low-grade clerical jobs. Michael was trained as a pilot. He reads and writes three languages and speaks a fourth. He has also served in a UN peace-keeping force.

It is a great disappointment to me that this government does not set the example to other employers. This government has previously introduced bills that appeared to be aimed at making it more difficult for people to receive a disability support pension—the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Disability Reform) Bill 2002; the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Disability Reform) Bill (No. 2) 2002; and the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Disability Reform) Bill (No. 2) 2002 [No. 2]. I understand these bills were defeated in the Senate, but the government will be in a position from 1 July this year to do its worst. I seriously question whether the government intends to genuinely attempt to assist more people into employment or whether this is simply a cost saving exercise.

When the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Disability Reform) Bill was introduced, it was estimated that there would be $420 million in savings over the period 2002-06. Whatever the government is intending, it must consult broadly with those individuals and groups with expertise in the area of employment and support for people with disabilities. A key question is whether any proposed changes will be applied to existing disability support pension recipients.

I accept that there are people who may occasionally slip through the cracks and receive benefits they may not be entitled to. From observation in my own electorate, however, these are few and far between, given the hoops they have to jump through to be entitled to a disability support pension. I have not seen the detail of what the government may be proposing, but I do suggest that a sledgehammer not be used to crack the proverbial walnut. Early in February this year ACOSS, together with many other organisations, formed the Disability Participation Alliance. The media release that accompanied the launch quoted ACROD CEO, Mr Ken Baker, as saying:

quote.para: There are no quick fixes to get people with disabilities into the workforce—many want to work but they face employer reluctance, waiting lists for employment assistance and financial disincentives in the social security system. We’re saying the time has come to tackle these issues so more people can get work.

speech.para: With my staff, I deal with constituents with disabilities on a day-to-day basis. It is patently obvious that there are no quick fixes to a complex series of issues. Overall, most people are desperately trying to do the right thing, not least for themselves by allowing self-sufficiency and dignity under what are usually trying circumstances. The vast majority do not want to rip off the government; they want to work with the government to obtain appropriate employment and support in order to lead decent lives and to retain some dignity for themselves. This government would be best placed not by introducing legislation designed to penalise but by introducing legislation designed to support and enhance the lives of people who are clearly so disadvantaged in the employment market.

Until July the community have a safety net because the government has not had a majority in both houses of parliament. From July the government will have a majority in both houses of parliament. The pressure will be on those decent members of the coalition in that caucus room who for years have preached the compassion that they supposedly deliver to the community as against the Labor Party—those people who come into the parliament on the coat-tails of their religious credentials. I do not believe it is a government of compassion, yet I believe there are many compassionate people within the government.

I came into parliament not to protect or preserve the rich or those who can look after themselves. I believe that government should provide a safety net for the vulnerable, for the dispossessed in the community, because there is no equality in the marketplace. There are people who do not have the ability to make it by themselves because there is inequality in the community, and that is where government steps in—the hand of a good Samaritan, not the hand of survival of the fittest, where the money goes to the wealthy end of town or to those who are the most vocal. That is going to be the true test. I think we are a compassionate country, but in the past nine years under this Prime Minister compassion has gone out of government. I think we have taken the low road. With the insecurity in the world and the insecurity within, we are turning on ourselves and it is the vulnerable who are suffering. I do not believe that the average member of parliament wants to see that happen. But what it means is standing up in the party room. When you have got a government that is awash with money, it is no good saying at the end of your term, ‘There is nothing I could have done about it.’ There is. And the beauty about this parliament and this place and this country is that one or two voices can make a difference. You can have an impact. But, if you remain silent, it is no good finishing your term in this place and, at the end of it, achieving radicalism and then preaching to those that remain.

I believe that when a government goes after the most vulnerable—and we are getting that on the basis that this government wants to clean up the welfare system—then, frankly, it has to be held to account. If it wants to argue the case for change, it should not get away with glib headlines. It should be held to account. If it wants to make the case for change, it should make the case for change. You do not get impairment tables that go for 437 pages. It is not easy for people to get the disability support pension. It is very traumatic for people to have to come back year in, year out to continue to prove their disability. I say to those members in the coalition: I want to see action, not words. Words are cheap. What I expect is party room revolt and backbench revolt to hold this government to account for its approach. I commend my remarks to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am happy to follow my colleague the member for Banks. Together we cover 165,000 people in the City of Bankstown and have attempted to put the argument on behalf of our people time and again in this House. Here we are, dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and cognate bills, in a debate that one could say is, at the very least, extensive rather than intensive. Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I have had the privilege of sitting in the chair in the House and listening to your contribution to this debate. I marvelled at its extent and variance. When I went back and had a look at it I thought, ‘What is actually in appropriation bills Nos 1 to 4 and do they bear any relationship whatsoever to what the member for Scullin was arguing for and about?’ He quite rightly pointed out to me that you can say almost anything when it comes to appropriation debates. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may indeed at the moment be checking standing orders to work out whether or not I am actually casting aspersions on the Deputy Speaker or indeed on another member. It is a question of disorder under the new rules 89. I could not blame myself or anyone else—
(Mr Jenkins)—Order! I refer the honourable member for Blaxland to standing order 76(c), but he may continue.

—I shall, with alacrity, look it up as soon as I have finished speaking. Since 1996, what I have found over and over again is this—and it is important: we are elected to speak. We are expected to do research and then to speak to the appropriation bills. I want to thank not only our shadow minister, who has provided background information in relation to these bills, but also the person charged with the carriage of these bills through the House, in this case the Hon. Dr Sharman Stone, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration. In her second reading speech, she told us a little bit about what these bills actually entail.

speech.para: If you go to the four appropriation bills themselves and the associated statement of savings, as I did just before I began duty, and look at the tables, you will find that you cannot work out anything about what this government is actually saving money on. Also, you cannot work out what the appropriations were before. These are designed to confuse and to provide disinformation rather than information. I have made this comment a number of times over the years during debate on the appropriation bills.

This government introduced the Charter of Budget Honesty. It introduced the notion that people should be able to tell exactly what the government is up to. It is actually not a charter of government honesty; it is effectively a charter of dishonesty. What the government has done—not here with that charter but in terms of changing the way in which the budget papers are presented and the way in which the appropriation bills are presented—is to take a behaviourist approach. It talks about goals, aims and outcomes and, in the most general terms, says that there are inputs to the system and there are outputs—the sort of language which means absolutely nothing. It is entirely drivel. For any single government department, all you get is: ‘Here is a whack of money; it is either being spent or it isn’t.’ The documents no longer tell you what it has been spent on. How could you tell by looking at these papers? Certainly there are moneys to be appropriated for the Department of Defence, the department of housing, the Department of Family and Community Services and so on. But as to what they actually do with that money you simply have to go to the second reading speech and ask, ‘Is there anything here that is real in terms of what is being proposed?’

What happens if you rely upon the bill itself, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2004-2005? I will give a simple instance, taking a department at random. Let me take the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. We are dealing with ‘Operating outcome 2, Development of a stronger and internationally competitive Australian sports sector and encouragement of greater participation in sport by all Australians’. What a motherhood statement. That is what we are told this is supposed to be about. Under the column on specific payments to the states and territories, we are given a figure. There are no new administered expenses. We go back to the original figure. That is the money the department gets. What is this appropriation for? Who knows? How can you tell? There is nothing specific here. Departments have given up saying exactly what the programs are and how and why this money is being appropriated. That goes back to the old days—the Hawke and Keating government days. When you fronted up there was a cash basis for how the accounts had been prepared and you got a bit of information to say, ‘Here is the money we are spending and—guess what?—this is what we are spending it on.’ The House could make a judgment about whether that spending was real and sensible. Instead of that, when we get the extra bits and pieces of information from the parliamentary secretary, we can start to make a judgment about whether some of these programs are worth while.

There is a whole string of relevant examples. Given the time of year, being the end of the cycle and with the budget coming up in May, this is a tidy-up operation. There is about $299 million worth of savings to be made. What does that mean? It means that the departments did not spend everything they had. They found that they did not want to spend on programs at a particular time. However, there is also an adjustment for about $1,794 million of new moneys to be expended. Some of it they could not really forecast, and some of it covers adjustments for things that have gone wrong. But in some cases there are expansions to programs that are already there, or special provisions that had not been put in the previous budget bills. I commend one of them: $6½ million to the Department of Veterans’ Affairs for additional funding to commemorate significant anniversaries in 2005. What could be more significant than the 90th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings and the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II? That is an appropriate appropriation for this parliament to pass, but we should have been able to find it readily in the papers presented with these appropriations. You can only tell what it is for from the papers provided by the parliamentary secretary.

There is another provision which gives you some window into a fundamental problem that the government have and the steps they are taking towards covering it: Australia’s defence and its air superiority capacity in the region. In the appropriations, there is a net figure of $103.8 million to the Department of Defence, which includes $149.4 million to fund accelerated depreciation for the early withdrawal of F111 fighter planes and two guided missile frigates. This is a fundamental and important issue, because the whole question of air superiority within our region has previously rested on the platform of the F111, a fighter bomber that is capable of extreme range and that has given us the ability to project ourselves and our defensive strength extremely well and extremely capably. There is the question of how well the fighter that is meant to replace the F111 will cover the role that was undertaken by the F111 in the past, but there is also an indication here that there is an acceleration in the provision of this program. You cannot gainsay the appropriation, but it is one of those provisions where the decision was made within less than a year to speed it up.

Likewise there is a proper provision of $24.3 million for the childhood obesity package. Speaking from lifelong experience, I can say that obesity is a significant problem within the Australian community and it is rapidly becoming a much greater problem not only here but in most of the western world; indeed it has even spread beyond that. It is a significant and difficult issue that relates in good part to the way our diet is structured and to the fact that a fundamental part of the best nutritional advice for two or three decades was probably wrong—that is, the food pyramid that most of us have relied upon. There has been a great deal of change in that area, but it is also a case of there being a significant and fundamental problem that has to be attacked on different levels and with a range of different approaches. I commend the appropriation of those moneys on this program. We do not have a full explanation for it here, because the government do not give us full explanations of what the appropriations are about. You get windows into what they are up to and some indications of what those programs are about, but the government are covering up what they do, so we cannot get a proper appreciation of them.

Some of those windows are pretty interesting—for example, the appropriation of $30 million to the Department of Transport and Regional Services for the expansion of the Roads to Recovery program. That appropriation is an indication that that program has been successful, at least for government members. It is the most touted program the government has, apart from AusLink, their new initiative. It is clear they want to pour more money into it so that road provision at the local level is increased. The member for Lingiari quite properly indicated that they have done nothing in the Northern Territory; they have concentrated their efforts in particular places. In the Roads to Recovery program and other specific programs, the government have substituted for state responsibilities and work on state roads because they have not continued the work on national roads that past governments had undertaken. That appropriation also indicates that there is a critical problem for the government in terms of infrastructure and major infrastructure projects.

I have not been able to see from 1996 on, even in the bald statements given within these documents, any commitment by this government to really tackle major infrastructure problems in a series of country electorates where there are fundamental problems with water usage. One that comes to mind that I dealt with a few years ago—and there has been no development in relation to this whatsoever, as far as I know—is what to do in the Lockyer Valley in Queensland, the vegetable-producing heart of Australia, and what to do with the $200 million worth of investment that the city of Brisbane needs to put into new sewerage works. They need new sewerage works. They can spend $200 million and just pour semi-treated material into Moreton Bay or they could spend $200 million and have that put towards a larger program which would provide recycled reticulated water from those sewerage works through to the Lockyer Valley. If more money were put into it, a total originally in the order of $600 million, you could actually take that water from Brisbane and pipe the excess—because the Lockyer Valley could only use about 40 per cent of it—up to the Darling Downs. Farmers in the Darling Downs, who have a lot of infrastructure in the ground that they have paid for that is as dry as a bone, could be using water from Brisbane to make their farms more productive and to renew, increase and extend their productive capacity. But there is nothing in this lot of appropriations about that. There is nothing in past budget measures. I have to say to those people who have been waiting on a promise with regard to that, and also on the Elliott main channel in the electorate of Capricornia: you can just whistle in the wind and hope that this government might actually get the message that fundamental infrastructure projects need to be treated with alacrity and they need to be treated seriously. They simply have not done it.

There is a sensible provision of $11 million—and it is an indication of the nature of the times we live in—for the Australian Customs Service for new biological and chemical mail screening capacities, and another $6.4 million for the Australian Federal Police for specialist counterterrorism equipment. Both of those are, in fact, synergistic. They need to be done. We need to increase our capacity to deal with the threats at our borders and with specific terrorist threats within Australia.

There is another provision in the parliamentary secretary’s speech which tells a bit of a sad story. It is only a slight window into what is happening. There is $84.6 billion to the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources to pay the government’s loan guarantee to the Australian Magnesium Corporation ahead of schedule, extinguishing the $90 billion liability. It is another Australian government input into something we would have hoped would have worked. We have got a series of those, including BHP’s HBI complex in the west. The potential for the Magnesium Corporation project to provide great income for Australia in the future was significant, but to date that has not come to fruition. The government is doing its part. I just hope that somehow that situation can be turned around and it can be made positive. The underlying potential for magnesium produced in Australia to really revolutionise the manufacture of car parts in particular and for Australia to take a leading role in future car production through that is extraordinary. We have three projects on foot here. They are the sorts of projects where you want to do everything you can to try to make them work. It is almost a case of private industry not being capable of doing enough to bash their way through, to get a result that would be good for them and of course good for Australia. So there are some sad things in here as well.

The last one I want to point to is the $65.8 million for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Austrade to enhance security in Australian diplomatic missions, including blast-proofing windows. That is yet another sign of the times. While we are looking at blast-proofing windows in our missions, we are considering moving some missions, particularly the one in Indonesia—where they had in fact blast-proofed the windows—into more secure zones, because the world we face is a much more difficult one than it was 15 years ago.

Having comprehensively looked at elements of what the parliamentary secretary has provided information on, I just want to finish with a broader look, consistent, I suppose, with what many members have done in the debate on these appropriation bills. I want to have a look at the broader question of where we are. Two significant reports have come down recently. The first was the OECD survey of Australia in 2004. I just want to note this: it states, on the Hawke-Keating reform agenda, that ‘Australia’s reform program was remarkable, and is still producing benefits’. But it points out that despite the coalition having enjoyed ‘an extended period of rapid economic growth, Australia’s productivity still lags seriously behind that of many nations’.

Quite effectively, this government, in part, has been asleep at the wheel. The hard, difficult work of dramatically changing Australia’s economy was done from 1986 on, in particular during the Hawke-Keating period. This mob have relatively coasted. The realisation of what should have been done has come very rapidly in the last couple of weeks. Part of the knock on the door came in February 2005 when the Reserve Bank said: ‘Hang on; time’s up. We’ve taken this period of time so far and we haven’t increased rates. We’re not going to do it this month but we’ve got to tell you that we have to increase rates in the future.’ That is largely a response to the fact that this government has not been entirely profligate over the past year. As the Leader of the Opposition and the Shadow Treasurer have said, $66 billion worth of profligate spending has led us to the point where there has been a 0.25 per cent increase in interest rates. We expect there will be at least one more increase, to the detriment of ordinary Australian families. I commend the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer.

talk.start.para: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and related bills which are a very important part of the government process. As the honourable member for Blaxland has pointed out, these bills come at a time of great interest in the Australian economy and when certain elements of the Australian economy are receiving a great deal of attention in this House and in the wider community generally.

speech.para: We saw in question time today the government duck and weave on their promise to keep interest rates low. They now say, ‘All we said was: interest rates will be lower under us than they would be under Labor,’ and, of course, they quite successfully ensured that there would be no way of testing that proposition by ensuring that the Labor Party was not elected to government. They did that at the same time that the Prime Minister, in any speech he made and regardless of what it was about, had on his podium a slogan which said, in very simple language, ‘Keeping interest rates low’—not lower than they would be under the Labor Party, not lower than they might be in other countries but ‘Keeping interest rates low’.

That is not all they did. They sent out brochures in many seats across the country which had the capacity to check how your mortgage would go up with any increase in interest rates. You could pull out a little slide which said, ‘Interest rates under Whitlam and Hawke’ and ‘Check what your interest rates will be under a Latham Labor government’. They never said, ‘Interest rates would continue to be low but they might be a bit higher under us.’ They never said, ‘They’ll go up a bit but not too much.’ They said, ‘Interest rates will remain low.’

We saw this government engaging in its favourite tactic of dog whistle politics. It has done this time and time again on many issues and it has done it on interest rates. It blows the dog whistle; it has an alibi so that it can say in future years, ‘We did not really promise that 100 per cent. We promised something similar to that.’ I can confirm to the House from the doorknocking that I did that the message has gone through. Every electorate in Australia is under the firm impression that this government would keep interest rates very low. Members of the community do not appreciate the increase in their mortgages which has come about as a result of interest rate increases. As the honourable member for Blaxland has said, there are more increases on the way.

That would not be so bad if the economy was in decent shape while we were having these interest rate increases. If the economy was bubbling along, if we were managing from a position of strength and if our current account deficit was strong, then I am sure the Australian people would understand the need to have an interest rate increase. But instead we find the current account deficit hitting seven per cent at a time when our terms of trade are at a record high. If our terms of trade were at the levels when the current account deficit was at six per cent under the Keating government, then I think we would find a current account deficit well over 10 per cent of gross domestic product which, of course, would be not only unsustainable but disastrous. In my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration, I asked the Governor of the Reserve Bank when he appeared before us a couple weeks ago if he was worried about a terms of trade collapse which would see the current account deficit blow out to disastrous levels. He said that that was a scenario which he could well foresee happening and that it would be a worry if it happened.

There is a great deal of humbug from the government on the economy and on their economic management. They claim that their economic management is amongst the best in the world but, of course, there are other countries in the world which they do not talk about very much at all. I would like to bring the attention of the House to the Irish economy which went through a very similar reform process to the Australian economy in the 1980s. The Irish reformed their telecommunications industry; struck a social accord with their unions; brought in budget surpluses, just as the Hawke and Keating governments did for the first time; and brought their unemployment rate down from 17 per cent to four per cent. Their current account deficit is effectively in balance and they have continued the reform process by embracing research and development. This government has not only ignored but taken backward steps on research and development. It has abolished the research and development tax concession and has done absolutely nothing to embrace research and development. We are seeing the fruit of that neglect, with manufactured exports going backwards and not improving anywhere near as much as they did under the Hawke and Keating governments and in other nations across the world. In the years 1986 to 1990, 27 categories of manufactured exports increased by more than 10 per cent. We are now finding that the majority of categories of manufactured exports are declining. I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, in writing, on 2 December 2004:

item.para: Will the Coastal Catchment Initiative along the Great Barrier Reef conclude at the end of 2005-2006; if not, what sum has been allocated for (a) 2006-2007, and (b) 2007-2008.
Which are the ‘high priority’ regions and how are they determined.
When will preparation of Water Quality Improvement Plans commence, and who will prepare those plans.

What is the process the Australian Government and the agents preparing the Water Quality Improvement Plans will follow to bring this about (a) in reef catchments, and (b) specifically for each urban catchment.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr Truss

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: The Natural Heritage Trust Ministerial Board has yet to determine budgets for (a) 2006-2007 and (b) 2007-2008.

The Coastal Catchments Initiative will be implemented in high risk, high priority catchments according to the Catchment Risk Assessment prepared under the Reef Water Quality Protection Plan and where catchment communities have interest and capacity to develop plans at a suitable standard.

Contracts for the preparation of Water Quality Improvement Plans are expected to be let in 2004-2005. It is not yet known who will prepare the plans. This will depend on the outcome of contract negotiations.
The process for preparing Water Quality Improvement Plans is outlined in the Framework for Marine and Estuarine Water Quality Protection http://www.deh.gov.au/coasts/pollution/cci/ framework/.
